11.2 oz bottle from the Four Firkins.  Caramel colored pour, slight eggshell colored head.  Dark fruit aromas with banana being very prominent.  Flavor is more dark fruit with a nice smooth finish.

30cl bottle from 2006. Shared with friends.
Amber colour. Ages very well.

Bottle, 33cl. Pours a clear and dark amber beer with a firm offwhite head. The aroma is malt, sweetness, fruit and slight notes of alcohol. The flavor follows the nose. The palate is sweetness. Overall a really good, well balanced and complex beer.

Bottle. Dark amber, average and mostly lasting head. Moderate, malty and caramel sweetish aroma, some fruitiness and alcohol. Body is medium, malty and sweetish with raisins and caramel. Finish is average, malty and sweetish, some alcohol.  Sweetish and fruity strong ale with some alcohol in the aroma/flavor  not very special.

Le liquide dévoile une robe qui a une teinte ambrée particulière.  Le col mousseux est modeste.  Quelques traces collées sont observables.  Le nez est lourdement malté.  Des parfums de toffee, de fruits confits et de massepain partent en vapeurs chaudes.  Des notes poivrées accompagnent un alcool voluptueux, floral et légèrement boisé.  Le goût est une suite logique des choses : le liquide laisse fondre sur la langue des saveurs de malt sucré et de pâte damande fruitée.  Lalcool est toujours piquant et en fleurs.  En bouche, le liquide est rond avec une effervescence active et une texture liquoreuse.  En finale, on retrouve un alcool tout à fait chaud et assez affûté à la remorque dun malt doux et opulent.

750ml corked and caged bottle. Clear mahogany brown with a creamy thick beige head. Aroma of wet, dank cardboard, dark fruit, dark caramel and some musty wood. The flavor is more sweet dark fruit, slightly sour yeast and some light bitterness. Medium to full body with average carbonation and a smooth, soft mouth feel. Overall a decent Quad, but seems a bit oxidized, might have to try a fresh one.

Bottle. Pours a hazy, golden/reddish amber. Off-white head. Creamy, malty, dark fruit aroma. Wooden notes in the background. A bit cloying. Sweetish, malty and fruity flavour. Tart finish with a berry-like bitterness. Faint wooden notes. Lingering dark fruit notes. 17.11.10.
Pours very attractive dark brown.  Aromas of caramel, smoke, vanilla, citrus.  Very complex sweetness.  Alcohol gives it serious kick, makes flavours very intense.

intense fruity aroma, theres citrus, apple (like in the triple) and some darker fruits as well... furthermore i smell malts and hops and some yeast... this all comes back in the taste, along with some intense bitterness... it also is very lively in the mouth... finish is a bit bland, the bitterness fades quiet fast and obnly the sweetness remains for some time... good, complex beer... very special quad with an unexpected amount of fruitiness...
Bottle 330ml. Color red with small head. Aroma caramel, malts, fruit. Taste sweet, caramel, almonds, alcohol.

head: small,creamy 
colour: red/brown/amber 
smell: caramel, malts, candy, almunds, honey 
tatse: anis, caramel, second is bittersweet, bit irony, malty, next is some vintage taste , ended in grassy malty flavour

750 ml corked and caged bottle into Trappist glass. Beer #4 in tonights Trappist tasting. Though not side by side, Im going to try and compare this with the Westvleteren 12 and the Rochefort 10 that I drank earlier since all are quads. Pours less murky and is an orange hue with no brown. Has a small head that dissipates too quick, leaving an eyeball and collar of foam. Aroma is more fruity and funky than those other two; smells like carameled apples, banana, raisins, alcohol; seems more aromatic to me. Tastes like cotton candy; sweet with no bitterness. More carbonation than the other two quads, but still just at a medium level; full-bodied, not as creamy as the Westy; tangy finish. Wow, Im pretty impressed with this actually. Could it be better than the almighty Rochefort? I think so. Right up there with Westvleteren, in my opinion. Re-rate: the alcohol becomes a bit too much after awhile. I never had a problem with either the Westvleteren or the Rochefort with this. The alcohol in those beers never overwhelmed the taste. So, in revision, its obvious the other two beers are better made. This is still one tasty beer, though.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2010 10/2010, Zwolle, NL.  Color is warm, medium amber, with plenty of haze. Head is white, minimal and fades fast. Fruity, caramel aroma. Taste: medium sweetness and umami. Average carbonation with medium body and slightly oily texture.  Finish is lightly astringent.  Not bad.  La Trappes are good, but Westmalles are just a bit better.
Dark brown pour from bottle.  Aroma is sweet, with notes of burnt brown sugar.  Taste is figs, raisins, plums and booze.  Warm finish.  Very enjoyable.

10/17/10.  Bottle.  Cloudy red brown pour with plenty of small, suspended particulates.  Huge sweet bubblegum and candied banana aroma with hints of caramel, brown sugar, and booze.  Very sweet flavor with dark caramels, brown sugar, red grapes, and more.  Booze is much better hidden in the flavor.
12th February 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Dark amber beer. Very strong taste which offset by the smoothness of the palate but couldnt drink loads!

Bottle. Dark brown pour with a nice white head. Turns into a small foam after a while. Great aroma with dark fruits, caramel, syrup and raisins. Sweet, fruity taste with the dark fruits, some banana, syrup and some malts. Great, subtle bitter aftertaste which lingers on. Sticky but very nice. Alcohol well hidden. Great balance.

330 ml bottle. From Eindhoven, the Netherlands. Parallel tasting with La Trappe Blond/Dubbel/IsidOr/Quadrupel.
Reddish brown colour with small white head.
Aroma: Caramel, ripe fruit, solvent, alcohol.
Flavour: Sugar, alcohol big time, solvent.
Warming like hell. Straight forward booze. Trappist? Really?

UPDATED: NOV 1, 2010 Dark amber-orange colour.Aroma,dry fruits,raisins,banana,plum,spices.Taste caramel,spices,dry fruits,brown sugar,raisins,sweet malts,yeast,light metallic,alcohol,light bitter.A very complex beer.

330 ml bottle @ Gastropub Tuulensuu. Rated @ 11.4.2010.
Dark amber colour with a white head that fades quickly. Sweet malty nose with notes of banana and honey. Strong flavour of fruits, caramel malts and spices. Full bodied with a sweet alcohol finish. Great Quadrupel.

Bottle:
Off white foamy head.
Color is hazy dark orange to amber.
Smell malts, dust, sweets, fruit and sugars.
Taste is a full mix of fruit (apple), sugars, hint of vanilla, hint of alcohol, hint of malts and hint of hops.
Good balanced with bitters, fruit and carbonation.
Sticky and strong!
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text:
A: The pour is a dark amber/brown color with a fluffy khaki colored head.

S: Sweet dark fruits (such as raisins, plums, and figs) and dark candi sugar make up the bulk of the aroma. Plenty of sweet caramel maltiness, too.

T: The flavor is of the same dark fruits that were present on the nose. A hint of spice and plenty of yeast that almost seems sour at points. Sweet malts and candi sugar, too.

M: The body is medium with a lively carbonation, but not quite as fine as some other Belgian beers.

D: A nice beer, pretty easy to drink for such a high ABV beer, and not really any discernible alcohol on the flavor or nose, either.

As with all Belgium strong Abbey beers, there is alot of complex flavors going on with this beer.  A bit of sweetness definitely present in this high alcohol beer.  But another well made beer worth buying whenever you see it.   I purchased a case of it that had the dubbbel. trippel, quad together.

bottle.  Dark brown body which is slightly red, with big, nice, and persisting tan head.  Aroma of apples, pear, fresh bread, melon.  Flavor is very complex and features initially a spiced blast of pear and cake with a tart, fruity finish featuring cherries.  An almost wine like mouth feel, that is very smooth in spite of the sour, sharp aspect to the finish.  Overall outstanding, excellent, a great quad.  I would have to say there are some better ones Ive had but this is about as good as it gets.

Poured from a 11.2 oz. bottle into a Delirium Tremens snifter.

Appearance: Pours an opaque dark amber color with a 3 finger bubbly off-white head. Decent lacing.

Smell: Great combination of malts and dried fruits. Smells sweet and delicious.

Taste: Sweet dried fruit up front then a mix of spices and a hint of alcohol in the middle followed by sweet toasted malt at the finish. Aftertaste is mildly sweet with a little bit of bitterness. This is a delicious beer.

Mouthfeel: Medium-to-full-bodied with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: High drinkability for a beer with an ABV of 10%.

Overall: Excellent trappist quad. Buy it if you see it.

Bottle with the Brewmaster!  Lodewijk sat at our table during the tasting for almost an hour. It was a pleasure to heart his take on the Canadian and America brewing scene. I am glad they go their name back! Raisins, dark fruit, plums and a sweet yeast in the nose. Toasted caramel with a doughy, damp taste.. mild hopping.. Fantastic wide and expressive slightly bitter and coriander finish.
waht a mouthful.  delicious with lots going on.  10abv is well masked and had me wanting more

330ml bottle.  The La Trappe Tripel and Quadrupel were the the beginnings of my love for real beer about a year ago, now many ratings later I still found this one very pleasant.  Pours nicely into a Trappist glass with its amber hue, cloudy with plentiful sediment, the large light brown frothy head diminishes slowly, nice lacing.  To me my Duvel glass allows me to appreciate the aromas more than the Trappist glass but  nonetheless the very appealing sweet malty, chocolate, caramel, sugar, dates, spicy, yeasty aromas are heavenly.  Moderately to heavy sweet and moderately bitter, faint salinity.  Medium body, oily feel then sticky, soft carbonation, long alcoholic & woody finish.  Yum.
Bottle 0,3ltr: Hazy amber coloured with an mouth warming abbilty, quite sweet due the spices.

Sample at the dubbel and quad tasting at Blacklick & Wine Spirits on 8/19/10. Cloudy brown pour with a big beige head. Aroma of banana, caramel, banana, candi sugar and banana. Caramel sugary flavor with banana and a bit of booze.

Bottle, one year ago.
Dark brown, very cloudy, looks like a dubbel. Medium and short-lasting head.
Very strong aroma, it can be scented far from the glass. A lot of yeasty-fruity notes (mainly raspberries, some strawberries and blackberries) plus some caramel and chocolate. Strong alcohol in the background.
Massively full-bodied but with a lot of alcohol in taste (too much, it spoils the effect). Also a lot of fruity notes in taste, accompanied by caramel and nuts. The aftertaste is dominated by dried plums and a light bitterness.

Appearance:  dark amber with copper notes, medium bubbly head that shrinks to a collar; some lacing.  Aroma:  boozy and rich, with sweet caramel and some syrupy fruits.  Taste:  strong, burnt sweet malts; raisins and caramelized peaches.  Finish:  lengthy and on the dry side; a little sour, with boozy caramel and tangy fruit.  Notes:  A little too strong for my tastes. A complex and challenging brew.

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2012 33 cl bottle, pours a lovely dark amber with a nice white head, decent lacings, aroma of dark fruits, malt caramel and yeast, taste is caramel malt, fruity yeast and dark fruits with a hint of alcohol present, fairly long and smooth finish.

Pours deep amber with a thick white head which lows quickly to a long lasting lacing.  Nose is of sweet malts, toffee and caramel, with a fruity component that reminds me of grape cola.  There are faint  notes of apples, bananas and spices.  Though there is a little bready yeast and damp earth this is fresher scented than most other quads.  Taste is of the nose with a light alcohol sharpness and a prominent candied sugar.  Mouth feel is velvety with fine carbonation.  Finish is long with the first signs of hop bitterness, which here mixes well with the sugar.  Its well balanced and highly enjoyable, but ultimately is outshone by its Trappist cousins.

bottle from market street.  poured amberish with an off white head.  aroma was lots of dark fruits, toffee, caramel, and licorice.  flavor was raisin, plum, caramel, licorice, alcohol, with a bitter finish.  body was medium-heavy with medium carbonation.  pretty good stuff.  the cork was labeled 07/08.

[330ml bottle, Beers of Europe, Kings Lynn] Thick, dark amber beer that pours quite fizzy but very quickly reduces to total flatness. Sweet, woody aromas with some stone fruit. On the palate theres a predominant whack of sweetness, very warming stuff. Almost a root beer taste to it as it approaches room temperature (which may be the result of the oak aging)  along with the alcohol flavours. An evening sipper to be savoured. [15/08/2010]

Strong Belgian-style beers, I think, were my first big beer love and this is a good example of why. They are huge and alcoholic but still maintain a soft drinkability which is what makes them stand out against English and American brews of the same strength. Well, that and the yeast, of course. This pours a nice orange color, so deep as to be nearly brown, w/ a creamy head of white bubbles which wanes to a soft ring around the glass. Yeast bread and bananas dominate the nose w/ a sugary rum soaked raisin sweetness in the background. This is medium bodied and ever so slightly sticky but w/ huge amount of brisk but soft carbonation to cut the thickness. It is this kind of mouthfeel that separates the men from the boys as far as Belgians styles go. It has that feeling of crossing the tongue w/o getting it wet. Just lovely. The flavors here mostly follow the nose, just a big fruitcake of a beer w/ just a hint of bitterness to balance in the finish. This is a very nice and very well balanced take on a classic style. Take your time to enjoy it. I am.
Aroma is La Trappe (their yeast and hay). Taste is thicker than the siblings, caramel, sweet, figs and raisins.

Aroma of fruit, spices, apples, light caramel, and pilsner malts.  Love that Quad bite.  Spicy, sweet malts, plenty of fruits, brown sugar in the flavor. Finish is tingly. A nice Quad for a nice evening.

on draft @ redlight redlight.  Spicy caramel aromas with hints of dark cherries and cooked apples.  Pours a reddish amber with a thick billowy off white head.  Rich caramel malts with caramelized sugars with vanilla notes and hints of cherries, dates and figs.  Rich malt flavors with spicy yeast notes.  Excellent.

(also had this one 5 years old on tap in Den Bosch...wow)
Poured dark brown with foamy head. Much to sweet with only mild bitterness. Flavors of caramel, bread, earthy, cloves.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2010 Nice brown body with lasting tan head. Full bodied. Aroma of dark fruits and caramel. Sweet, strong taste with notes of dark fruit, vanilla and candy. Bitter, strong, lasting finish. Excellent!

Bottle. A hazy medium amber/reddish beer with an average sized, frothy, fully diminishing beige head. The aroma is moderately malty with notes of caramel, raisins, pear, plums, banana, sugar and alcohol. The flavour is heavily sweet, lightly to moderately sour, lightly bitter. Fruity, but too sugary, sweet, and boozy. Medium to full body, average carbonation, long finish with light to medium bitetrness at best, moderately alcoholic at least. Some interesting fruity aromas and nice appearence, inspite of the short head retention, but too much sweetness and alcohol presence. Disappointing.

Draft at Sunswick, during Belgian Beer Fest 2010. Pours a ruby-gold with a filmy white head. Some spice and fruits in the nose, along with some booze. Slight Belgian funk. Flavor is sweet and mildly syrupy, with plenty of brown sugar, some raisin and grape. Medium bodied with light carbonation. Very good.
750ml bottle-pours a tan head and amber color.  Aroma is apple cider, medium malt.  Taste is medium fruit, sweet medium malt-caramel/molasses, then some dark fruit-raisin.  Slight warming.
on tap.  deep orange/amber with a light cream head.  nose is dried fruits, alcohol, yeast, and more alcohol.  nice thicknesses, flavor is yeast, lots of dried fruits and alcohol.

Bottle. Pours an amber/ruby red beer with a beige head, gorgeous. Aroma is sweet, fruity, strawberry, bread, vanilla. Taste is quite sweet and malty, caramel, alcohol, citrus, yeast. Enjoyed it very much!

Bottle.

A - Scarlet mahogany color, a bit lighter than others Ive had of the style. Large, light, foamy, bubbly, light beige head with average retention and a nice thin foamy, sticky lace left.

S - A fruity and slightly tart sweet aroma that reminds me a bit of a dark fruit liqueur or something like a cognac. Dark berry, fig, date, and a bit of a citrus/melon aroma. Alcohol is quite present. Hints of dark malt and some sweetness and a bit of spice. Dominated by the fruit with some tartness and by the alcohol.

T - Rich malty taste consisting of some bread and caramel taste provide the initial taste and a base for the beer. Soon after, some dark fruit comes out with raisin, plum, fig, and apple coming out. Also some cinnamon amongst other spices. Overall a sweet, fruity beer with a fair amount of spice and a touch of alcohol. A bit of earthy bitterness mid sip, but not much. 

M - Medium body with slightly above average carbonation. A bit thin, especially for the style, but fairly creamy and smooth.

D - Pretty drinkable beer with a flavor that isnt too big, and is fairly well balanced. It is sweet, but not overly sweet.

Notes: Best before 05/2012. Pretty good Quad, not my favorite of the style, but a solid one. Like the other beers Ive had from the brewery, it seemed a bit on the thin side for the style. 
This was a bit more of a subdued Quad. Good beer that is worth a try, even if it isnt the best Quad out there.

een troebele amber kleur. een redelijke zoete  en licht bitteren smaak met ook een fruitige tint er in. het palate is ook redelijk zoet met een zeer lichte droge afdrong. aroma= zacht en licht fruitig

.33l bottle at Brasserie Henry in Budapest. Rosy, mahogany body with low, swirling head. Very proper and stunningly pretty in its glass. Ripe, fresh nose of alc, cherries, fudge, wintery spices. Cider, cinnamon-apple, banana bread, oat. dark bread and yeast. Carbonation is understated but finishes with a bite. Absolutely worthy of being in the class with the best Abts out there. Really wonderful.

29-MAY-2010, bottle @home.
Very high off-white head on brown body.
Malty and yeasty nose with bread and oranges .
All the usual malty notes in a quad. Very high carbonation, not overly alcoholic.
Very fine beer.
Pretty sweet aroma, lots of candi sugar. I did not feel that this beer was quite as complex as most quads.

Pours cloudy gold-amber big froathy head. Tropical fruits hit your nose, mostly banana-mellows out to raisins (dried fruits). Aromas transfer to palate along with brown sugar (maybe sweet cinnamon/ginger spice) but mostly candied banana/mango/raisin. Super, super sweet no noticeable alcohol. Great brew if you can handle the sweetness - have it with or as dessert!!

Bottle 750 ml thanks to The Jester. I kept this for long. Cloudy red with floaties and a ring of foam. Aroma doesnt disapoint:pear cherry, belgian yeast and candy sugar. Flavor is definitly on the sugary side. Gummy bears, pear, banana. Velvety palate and soft carbonation. Nice aroma profile nd palate but the sweetness is a little too much.

@ Capones, 10 oz. draft into a snifter
Poured a dark, muddy amber with a one-finger head.
Theres a lot going on in the nose - pepper, brown sugar, raisins, plum, cherries, apple with a bready, malt combining to create an almost fruitcake-like backbone. The taste is sweetness of the dark fruits hit first (cherries, raisin, plum), the malt and breay foundation and then a light hop background, especially in the finish that makes this complex and delicious. Mouthfeel is medium and smooth. While this was served too cold, I allowed it to sit long enough to get more of what was a very tasty, very complex sipper - good thing at 10%. I will seek this out again absolutely.
Rated the Konings Hoeven Quad bottle. Dark brownish pour in glass. Nose and taste is very sweet raisin, brown sugar and molasses. Rated 1/29/03

Amber orange cloudy pour light head ..... aroma of dark fruits, earthy yeast ... taste of dark fruits like plums and figs with a pear like taste as well .... sweet and mellow with a light spicy herbal hop to it .. a great quad .. tasted a little abv as it warmed but excellent

750mL bottle, Trappist Tasting at Joe T.s. Pours a bright, deep, orange-amber color; hazy; medium-bubbled light-tan head with decent retention and lacing. Strong estery notes of cotton candy, vanilla-tinged yeast, light alcohol, and ripe dark fruits in the aroma; hugely aromatic esters and alcohol here; inky, expressive dark fruits; hugely perfume-y and aromatic. Medium-full body; lively, fluffy carbonation; quite creamy, non-astringent, moderate levels of alcohol; lightly warming; medium-high levels of cola, brown sugar, and solid levels of cloves; light peppery notes; a prominent, estery quad with lots of dark fruits, vanilla esters, and cloves; very creamy overall. Medium finish: brown sugar, cloves, and dark fruits; balanced ending.

Bottle from LCBO aged since 2008. This pours a cloudy amber/orange color. Head is dense, large off white colored that dissipates quite slowly. Aroma is sweet, mostly orange with a touch of spice. Taste is quite sweet and alcoholic, but not overpoweringly so. Body is medium. Aftertaste was quite mild. A nice brew.
dark amber colour with little head aroma is fruity with hoppy nottes. alcohol and moderate bitterness come at the end

33cl bottle. Pours a dark amber color with little head. Interesting aroma: fruity alcohol, dark fruits, and earthy yeast. Mouthfeel is very soft, slightly watery, and barely carbonated. Malt flavors are cakey and sweet. Alcohol shows up in the finish, but not oercomes.Bitter finish. I expected more complexity from this quadrupel.

75 cl bottle, Fargo, ND, USA. Almost transparent deep amber colour, active head that quickly dissipates. Candied aroma, some raisin and clove. Sweetness that fades to a slightly bitter alcohol infused finish.

Exceptional- Pours a muddy amber fades quick to a ight rim. smells of sweet candy sugar and malt caramel, notes of sweet syrup. Taste is malt light caramel and candy sugar. Finishes with a light fizzy sweetness. Beautiful.
33 cl bottle. Dark amber/brown body with off-white head. Flavour is caramel, fruit and alcohol.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2010 Bottle pour to Trappist glass gives dark reddish-brown cloudy color with off-white medium head that disappears quickly.  Nice sweet fruity aroma.  Taste - wow really good with dark fruits, malts and chocolate flavors.  The alcohol is quite apparent..  Mouth feel thick and smooth with unassuming finish.

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2013 Bottle. Small off white foamy head over a clear red brown body. Subtle aroma of spices, ripe banana, toasty with a solventy "higher alcohol" quality. A portlike taste, sweet brown sugar, followed by a subdued bitter finish. Dry, light bodied thin. Nice.

great looking reddish brown beer, not as dark as most quads. very strong alcohol flavor and nice carbonation. the fruity and spicy flavors are strong and delicious. not yeasty like some Belgian quads... this tastes more like a fruity barleywine
Awesome quad! Beautiful dark brown pour with fluffy white head, classsic notes of bread and dried fruit. A lighter body than I am used to in a quad, but very well balanced and flavorful.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2011 Wonderful beer, big,  imposing, warming and complex. Medium to dark amber with a decent smooth head. The aroma is of sweet caramel malt, some dark fruit and a hefty amount of warming alcohol. A lot of spice in the flavour, sweet and toasty. Some fig and plume present, balancing bitterness and the alcohol gains in presence leading to a very warming finish.  

Re-rate, new scores, notes the same

Beige weak head. Cloudy deep amber-reddish colour. Aroma is malty, fruity (raisins) with vanilla and candy notes. Flavor is malty wth dark fruits, candy and caramel tones, ending in a fruity sweet finish. Full bodied.

750 ml corked and caged bottle poured a clear reddish amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of plum, dates, cxarmel, toffee and brown sugar. Palate was full bodied and smooth. Flavors of toffee, brown sugar, dates, plum and light spice with a smooth lingering sweet fruity finish.

750 ml thanks to Craig. Pours a murky brown/copper color with a medium white frothy head. The aroma is sweet; nutty and fruity- festive. The flavor is very nice; fizzy, fruity, dark fruits, nutty and sweet. A nice quad. Light banana esters.

750ml bottle, says Koningshoeven Quadrupel Trappist Ale on the label 
Appearance: Pours clear copper with a nice off-white head and some lacing in the glass 
Aroma: Bananas and malts 
Taste: Sweet malts, banana and yeast 
A very nice Quadrupel, good balance.

Nice deep amber color. Decent white head, stays lacing around. Coriander, honey, bubblegum and alcohol aroma, but the taste isnt as sweet, it actually finishes quite bitter. Has a medium body, not much carbonation, but goes down smooth. Will not be my favorite, but its certainly a strong brew.
great brew. had at belgian cafe wih james and andrew. pours a medium orange. little head but nice lacing. aroma is fruity. some malts and alc. flavor is sweet. barley and mild alc. tough to pinpoint.

I underestimated this beer.  I thought it was dutch so that said it all... My excuses!  
Nice beer.  Have still a dozen to try again... look forward to it.

On tap at MacNivens. Nose is full of sweet and spicey fruits like apple and peach. Poured tanslucent burnt orange with quickly fading pale head.  Soft and full of spice, this beer rolls around the tongue revealing a new layer at each corner. Mostly apple with lots of cloves and possibly some nutmeg.  Very interesting, as Ive never had this style.

Tap @ MacNivens. Shiny clear red body with creamy beige head that fades. Nose is berries, cherries, figs, plums, raisins, on top of soft sweet malts. Flavor is velvety smooth malts accompanied by all fruits mentioned. Very strong with a finish that pleasantly reminds you this is in fact 10%. Very nice!

750 ml ..Slightly hazy ,deep amber pour with a thin white head . Decent lacing. Huge aroma of  dark fruits and yeast . Flavor is moderate sweetness , with notes of dark fruits and chocolate . Moderate bitterness . Mouthfeel is oily , vinous notes and slight alcohol in the finish . Very well balanced .
Dark prune color with a small head. Aroma is weak for a quad. SOme fruit and faint spice. Flavor is sweet and the alcohol is well hidden. Carbonation is a bit high for me. Drinkable quad.

750 ml bottle from Total Wine & More in Tustin ($9.99).  Pours a clear light brown with some red mixed in.  Two fingers of beige foam has good retention and lacing.  Nose of fruit (cherries stand out), yeast, caramel, and spice.  Taste also (somewhat strangely) has a noticeable cherry flavor along with other dark fruit, caramel, peppery spice.  Not so sweet unlike some other quads.  Dry finish with a little bit of alcohol in the finish.  (1176, 253)

Had this in a bottle named Koning Hoeven. Pours a dark amber with a red tint and a big fluffy head. Wine like aroma with fruit, sweet malt and some spice. Nice flavor with the sweet fruits followed by a nice peppery feel and a warm burn on the throat. Finishes quite dry. Very nice after taste. Good one.

On tap at Beer Bistro in Toronto, served in a Trappist glass. Appearance is clear reddish-golden with a rocky white head. Good retention and good lacing. Aroma is sweet toasted caramel malt with perfumy hops and moderate yeast. Some clove and pepper also present. Flavour begins with honey sweetness with a hint of yeast. Spice develops through the middle, leading to a nice spicy finish. Finish is average-long. Palate is medium-full in body with a syrupy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, very fine. A very pleasant sweet and spicy ale. 2010-03-13

Excellent - banana bread flavors - nice sweetness, but not overdone - well hidden alcohol - reminds me of the overpowering malted flavor of Alpha Kong, but much more subtle to the point of being easy to drink.
This is a strong beer. Not only in alcohol, but in flavor. Kind of overwhelmingly so. Flavor is fruity. Plums, Blackcurrants, Brandy, etc.
malty,earth,brown, clear, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, medium body, creamy, average carbonation, long finish, good beer.

Provdatum:  Inlagt: 2009-06-06, 10 grader, tapp (Delirium, Göteborg)
UTS: Härligt mörk rödbrun med fint skum
D: Jäst (inte lika påtaglig som andra trappist), torkad aprikos, vanilj fudge
S: Jäst, torkad aprikos, vanilj fudge, stor fin kropp, inga alkoholtoner kommer fram - fantastisk att de 11% döljs så väl. 
ES: Lätt, lite kärv - som rödvin
Storebrosan Quadrupeln - var bättre än dubbeln 
Anteckningar:

Purchased a few of these at the LCBO, December 2008 and cellared them. Now, it is time to open one up and rate it. Written 23/08 on the cork. Caramel-orange in colour, slightly hazy, foamy-soap off-white head that disappears pretty quick and only a bit of lacing is left, here and there. Full of big bubbles are stuck to the glass and a few pop-up to the surface for carbonation. The nose has fruit (like oranges, apples, cherries and some other darker ones too), nuts, rust, alcohol, spices and candy. Yes, lots here, but not sure how well it mixes together. Caramel malt is in the taste with a lot of the things that were in the aromas. The alcohol warms a bit (which is great for winter) but does not burn. Lots of fruits present. So, pretty good overall, and nice to have from time to time, but there is just that little thing that bugs me with the blend of everything. It reminds me of paint (or something close in that range). I sure do not feel it at the end of the 750ml bottle though.
A well made beer. Pours with big head on it, exploding out of the bottle. Overall it drinks nicely with high malting and little taste. A typical dutch brew.
Drank from a sniffer poured out of a 22 oz. bottle.  Taste is a medium bodied banana flavor with a tinge of alcohol.

Agift for valentines day from my wife.  An explosion of aromas on the pour.  Intense smells of bananas, cloves, and cherries with the colour of southern iced tea.  Sweeeeet up front with raisins, cloves, bready yeast, and red wine flavours.  Nice creamy palate with a lingering wine finish.  A very complex brew that gives different flavours as the ale warms.  
very good, cheers!

This ones not from Belgium but still a very good trappistbeer. You can taste caramel during the whole tasting. It leaves a very nice aroma over the tongue. Not as good neither as complex as Westvleteren but a smart way to replace this one if you cant find it.

This beer smells of caramel and hay.  Earthy with not a strong alcohol smell. I liked its look which is a dark brown with a thin tan head.  Tastes a little sweet with a little bitter after taste. It has a medium body with a creamy texture.  It has a lively carbonation and a bitter finish.  Not my favorite but very drinkable.

I found this beer to be disappointing. It poured a redish brown with a one finger head. Smelled a bit like bananas and clove. Tasted a bit like Robitussin cough syrup. Not what I was expecting from a quad.
Amber/cognac  with small head. Aroma fruity, caramel. Taste is sweet cider from fruits and caramel and a heavy alcohol impact. Reminds of a cocktail drink based on rom.
Intense quad with lots of raisins and dried fruits on the finish. Very alcoholic and a little thin.

Sweet and malty aroma with notes of banana on the head and grapes on the beer.  Pours a deep copper color with a nice off-white/tan head that fades.  Malty and grapey taste, some dry fruit as well and nice alcohol finish.

Recently tried a bottle of this and wish I wouldve tried it sooner!  Colour... deep amber with no head at all. Nose... lots of candi sugar and medjool dates. Palate... little CO2, quite sweet, candi sugar comes through as does brown sugar, golden sirop, yeast, dried peach and pear, a delightful dollop of caramel and a soothing bit o alcohol to round out this wonderful sipper. A nice tipple on a chilly winters eve!

Somewhat cloudy dark amber with minimal head and retention and little in terms of lacing. Wonderful aromas of pear, apple, cherry, and alcohol. Flavors match, but include caramel and candy sugar, and the alcohol is warming. Effervescent carbonation, medium body, lingering alcohol warmth and dark fruit sweetness.

stonebottle. Sweet aroma of dates, brown sugar, vanilla and grapes.  Deep redbrown colour with small beige head. Nice sweet flavour in accordance with aroma and plenty of barley malt.  Low carbonation. Aftertaste almost like portwine.
Bottle thanks to Tran at Perrys. Clear light brown pour with a foamy head. Aroma is caramel, raisins, leather, Belgian yeast. Flavor is caramel, Belgian yeast and bread.

33cl bottle
Light brown to dark amber colour. White fine head. Sweet caramel / roast flavours. Light pearling. Heavy start, a very flat mouth feeling. Alcoholsweetness and caramel flavours, with a nice touch of bitter in the end. Lightly burnt malt in the aftertaste, yet very little hoppy flavours. Not very inviting for more.
UPDATED: SEP 3, 2010 While Im not a big fan of the La trappe trappist, the Quadrupel is one that I can drink from time to time.
bottle at home ... about time i got round to this ... deep red copper ... sweet deep yeast toffee nose... deep fruits ... plum raisins ... some toffee ... juicy ... nice

Dark brown, slight hazy with ruby red glow. Small head which instantly dissipates. Very sweet aroma, fruits, sugar, alchol and spices.
Mildly sweet flavour, vanilla, fruits and sugar, somewhat yeasty.
Long bittersweet aftertaste of fruits, vanilla and yeast.

Pours a deep reddish amber color. A small short-lived off-white head.  Nose is very, very sweet.  Vanilla, candi sugar, dates, and a bit of woodiness.  A very full flavor of butterscotch, toffee, alcohol, and some fruity esters.  Its been a while since Ive had a decent Belgian and I love that strong yeasty flavor.  The body isnt quite as heavy as I would have expected but there is a nice creaminess.  A very tight and surprisingly present carbonation considering the age of this bottle.  This is a very solid beer for a considerably reasonable price compared to a lot of the Trappist beers.
You experience a good and soft fill with the taste of strong beer and a smell of sweetness with nutty hues, the color of rough amber and nice creamy foam.

Serving: 330 ml bottle.
This one pours a deep amber color with an active off-white head.  The head is up then down in no time.  The nose is spicy with notes of cinnamon, sugar cookie, raisin, and molasses.  I feared that this one would be overly sweet and fortunately its not.  The taste takes on more of a perfume like note with touches of spice, caramel malt sweetness, a hint of tobacco, ripe fruit, and a slight booziness.  The taste isnt bad, but it lacks complexity and depth.  The body doesnt bring anything exciting to the party.  It has a medium body and a high carbonation.  The finish leaves a hint of sweet malt and boozy fruit.  I am left with a "meh" sort of feeling and wish I had something more memorable.  You can certainly do worse, but this one isnt great compared to its higher rated peers.
Bottle. Clear amber colour with fine head, Sweet and strong alcoholic. Rich carnonated and berry flavour (backlog).

Bottle. 25.4 oz. Split with Vinny. Pours a rich, hazy chesnut brown with a thick, creamy off-white head. Rich floral aroma, with notes of lemon zest, orange, hops, barley, toasted malts, cinnamon, pepper, and grapes. Velvety, full body with a rich, tasty mouthfeel. Little boozy in the finish, but not biting or too sour. Perfect balance of flavor and alchol. Excellent Belgian strong. Certainly one of the best Ive had.

Bottle 330ml. Exceptional beer. Wonderful aromas of fruit (cherry and apple), yeast, caramel, and alcohol. Taste starts sweet, and bitterness takes over for a long-lasting bitter finish. Palate is syrupy, full-bodied, and highly carbonated. Brown colour, frothy white head.

Aged 1 yr, 750mL bottle. Sweet and slightly boozy aroma with hints of grapes and raisins, caramel. Pours with a voluminous head which dissipates slightly more quickly than desired, although nothing to complain about at all. Taste is sweet, grapes, and palate is amazingly smooth. Slight warming sensation from the alcohol content, but perfectly easy to drink with no alcoholic flavour or burn whatsoever. Quite good, not as complex in character as the other quadrupels Ive sampled.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2014 Bottle, 300ml. Pours a very nice amber/reddish colour with an average head. Aroma is complex indeed and very nice, lots of spices and clove there. Yeast, grains, citrics and a subtle alcohol touch are all there once you taste it. Formidable. ////////////////////////////////////////////////// 750ml (06/14). Orange/Copper with a modest offwhite head. Aroma is of banana, clove, sweet malts and yeast. Medium to heavy body and carbonation. Well balanced for such a high alcohol volume. Classic.

(Draught at Libertine) Pours a clear dark brown with a 1/2 finger head that recedes quickly. Lacing on the glass is nice. Smell has some dark fruits, but mostly alcohol. Grapes are the only fruit I can actually pick out here. Taste is an alcohol bomb. Some grape characters come out as it warms, but still pretty hard to tolerate. Palette is pretty thin really for the style, but the carbonation and oilyness are nice.

Need to re-rate in the bottle as Im sure it is better.

Bottle - A huge disappointment, I really expected a lot out of this beer. Pours light amber with a very small white head. Smells boozy and sweet, with cloves and spice. Real sharp smelling. Taste is over the top boozy with too much sharp spice. Real bready, doughy, and yeasty, and it just tastes syrupy and cloying. A sweet, boozy mess. Did I get a bad bottle?

Great body, and fruit, strong taste in order to simulate a classic trappist beer. Of course is missing a real procedure to be a real flamish abbey beer... too industrial. Please I accept comments. Salud !

The best beer from the trappistes of Koningshoeven. Nice sweet aroma of malts, yeast, spicies and dry fruits. Taste is the same sweet with fruits, raisins,sugar,yeast and some spicies with hints of alcohol. Finish is long lasting with a bit of biterness. Medioum to full body. Very well balanced.

33cl bottled as Koningshoeven Quadrupel.  Pours amber/copper with a small off-white head.  Very little lacing.  Aroma is fruity, banana, apple, green grapes, yeasty, with some spice, caramel and toffee.  Flavor is caramel malt, some yeast, slight fruit and spice, a bit underwhelming.  Mouthfeel is oily and slick, moderate to high carbonation.  OK, but I had higher hopes.
330mL bottle, pours a dark reddish brown with a medium head. Aroma of caramel malt, yeast and fruit. Flavour is caramel malt, sweetness and alcohol. Excellent quad.

Poured into snifter from bottle.  Light cognac colored pour with very little head.  Aroma is lovely: a very refined banana scent that isnt artificial but mellow.  Flavor is a lighter version of the aroma and boozier.  Smooth but not slick over the palate.

30cl bottle into a Westmalle tulip: Shimmering ruby red in colour. Yeasty, lightly vinous with a touch of honey and dark caramel - reminds me of taffy apples, perfect for Christmas Eve. Initially sweet taste with banana-like esters and lots of melanoidins, followed by a bittersweet, herbal finish. The alcohol is not very well hidden, but still acceptable. A bit shy for such a big beer.
300 ml bottle from the supermarket a dark brown/red colored beer with a medium size head aroma of fruit malts sweetness and yeast taste sweetness sweet spices little bit bitter and some fruit

It pours dark amber brown with a nice robust off-white head. It is extremely carbonated. The aroma is of golden malts, honey, wheat, I cant smell the alcohol at all. The taste is very similar to the smell and quite nice all around: honey, dark malts, dark fruits, and has a slight alcohol sting at the end.

330mL bottle.  Pours a clear amber-gold colour with a head that quickly diminishes.  More or less a bigger version of the Tripel, the extra alcohol is very noticeable on the nose, with malty aromas (particularly toast and caramel) dominating the yeast, and very little hops.  Fruity, spicy, good balance of flavours.  Smooth on the palate with medium to high carbonation.

Koningshoeven bottle. Pours a murky rusty brown color, with off white head.  Fragrant sweet malt aroma; notes of banana.  Taste is big, malty and sweet.  Banana and honey are the most dominant flavors.  Also notes of caramel, brown sugar, plum and dark chocolate.  Astingent bitterness at the end.  Alcohol well hidden.  This is a good quad but seems a little sharp and cloying compared to other quads.  May be better with some age.
Decent Quad. Pours amber with white head. Lots of fruity notes in this one, even some banana and mango. Aroma is must and fruit. Finishes clean.
Bottle. Pours hazy amber with a impressively long lasting head and nice lacing. Flavor is of candi sugar dark fruit and it has a smooth minimal finish.

Nice aroma of plums and pears.  Dark amber with a one-finger head that lingers.  Carbonated, full-bodied mouthfeel.  Fruit taste hits first but has a strong alcohol aftertaste.  Alcohol is way more obvious than with the Belgium Trappists ales.  A good beer but not as good as the Belgium beers.  I would drink it again.

Bottle. Pours hazy dark amber with a beige head that quickly diminishes to a ring around the top. Aroma is fruity and a little boozy with notes of malt, raisins, rum, figs and stone fruit. Flavour has notes of caramel, chocolate, sultanas, raisins and toast as well as a strong hint of alcohol. Mouthfeel is smooth and creamy with a long sweetish finish including a slight alcohol presence. Despite the noticeable alcohol it is not offensive and does not get in the way of the flavour. Overall a quite impressive quad that is easily worthy of comparison with the other Belgian trappist abts.

Pours dark amber with a huge foamy and creamy head with good retention. Appealing aroma of dark malts, honey, cherry and caramel. Taste is wonderfully rich, moderately sweet, slightly bitter, and of fruits, spice, caramel and chocolate. Has a slight alcohol edge to it, but it doesnt get annoying. Good carbonation and very smooth, creamy texture. Very warm, sweet finish. Very enjoyable.

Bottle from Corks, Bristol. Chestnut/red in colour with a tight, moderate, off-white head. Plenty of carbonation. Sweet, caranel and red fruit aroma, with some yeast and alcohol spirit. Flavours were big and very sweet, with toffee, nuts, cherries, grassy hops and bitter finish. Alcohol was over-prominent throughout. Ok.

Poured from the Koningshoeven bottle; malty caramel and floral aroma with a presence of alcohol, dark reddish brown color light tan head,heavy cloying sweetness again with an alcohol presence, full body, smooth, lively carbonation,
Hazy brown colour nice head. Aroma of yeast, alcohol and candy sugar, with subtle notes of cherry. Flavour of cherry, bread, and spices, some banan late in the palate. Very nice.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2010 Small bottle, poured into their chalice . Reddish amber. Apples, berries and barely-ripe stone fruit. Fresh bread, earth, grass. Mellow. The alcohol is quite prominent but not offensively so. The carbonation is soft. The finish is persistently bitter and complex. I was ready to hate this, but I think Ill go and get some to put away for a while. [4.0]Bottle, 13C. Almost glowing chestnut; beige head fades to a coat. Aroma of doughy yeast, stone and orchard fruits, pineapple, mace with quite prominent alcohol. Lots of fruit and doughy/ slightly cheesy yeast with some spicy bitterness at the end. Lovely yeast character stops the booze from being too sharp but its never far away.

Dark reddish brown with a small beige head. Aroma is simplistic caramell malty with light green apple esters. Flavour is very sweet caramell with notes of dried fruit. Simple, straight forward and too sweet to be considered drinkable. Still ok with no flaws just not complex enough.
heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, red, brown, full body, caramel, coffee, roasty,

11.2oz bottle poured into a tulip.  LTQ pours nutty brown and fairly clear.  The head is quite large and fluffy and just a bit off-white.  The aroma on this beer is very metallic with malty undertones.  Normally this indicates a beer that is too cold but this one has been warming up for quite a bit.  Whew!  This is a sweet beer.  The body is very thick and cloying.  The taste reminds me of brown and brittle leaves along with a very prominent alcohol taste.  Bacon wrapped dates in a sweet sauce dominate the flavors though.  Im not overly enthusiastic about this beer.
ammbrata schiuma non abbondante non molto persitente noter maltate alciliche frutta secca frutta brandy cosi in bocca amro non pronunciato in bilanciamenmto al dolce alcol un po bruciante

Poured a ruddy brown with about a finger thick white head.  The smell was pleasant with aromas of plums, fruit, apricot, and a bit of that cookie bakery smell.  The flavor was also nice with much of the aroma coming though in the flavor.  The plums were most predominate leading towards the malty cookie flavor.  This was a nice quad that offered plenty in way of complexity.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2009 From bnensonb. Thanks again, man. This years bottle as a Konings Hoeven and Im starting to wonder why I have been drinking all of those huge, hoppy beers and all of those imperial stouts. This beer pours a thick, tall head with a very dark, hazy brown liquid under. The nose is a sweet caramel-apple maltienss and the initial taste is the same. There are only slight hints of hops, and the mid palate and finish are just dry enough that this doesnt leave a sugary-sweet after taste. This is a style that I am coming to like more and more, and I have been regularly surprised by the quality of this and other brews of its sort. Another keeper!

33cl bottle - shape and label different (and classier!) than the one pictured.

Pours a nice hazy amber with a big, creamy off-white head with good retention and decent lacing. 

Aroma of yeast, orchard fruit and malt. 

Medium carbonation, smooth mouth feel. Heavy-bodied Belgian, err, Dutch, ale. 

Flavour is, again, orchard fruit, some caramel, and raisins. Nice citric note to improve drinkability. Different herbal spices in there, too. Sweet, but not overly so - and the finish is sour and dry. Lingering sour after taste, too. Alcohol is present (well, at 10 % abv), but not overwhelming. 

Agreeable Trappist quadrupel, "healthier" than some overly sweet dubbels and tripels I know from Belgium. Sessionability is, at this abv, necessarily limited. Complex, nicely balanced beer.

UPDATED: JUL 18, 2010 Bottle 33cl. An amber brown ale with nice head. Smell is on fruit and sweet alcohol. Aroma is sweet with fruit, cassis, orange, bubelgum, banana and spices, anise, clove, typical trappist yeast aroma too. Finish is amazing on fruit and nice hops quite round, notes of resin and candy sugar.

bottle. Poured reddish brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is fruity and alcoholy. Medium mouthfeel with average carbonation. Flavour very sweet with roasted malt and raisin notes. The alcohol taste really overpowers this beer.

(Bottled) Poured deep amber and almost clear with small white head. Aroma contained malts, treacle, lightly chocolate and fruitiness. Full bodied and warming palate with lot of carbonation. Tasted of malts, chocolate, molasses, bitterness, treacle and lightly hops and alcohol. Malty and bitter aftertaste. Taste was a bit harsh, too. I think the beer would improve when aged.
Bottle. Pours amber, with an off white head. Aroma is caramel, malt, and dark fruit. Flavor is fruit, caramel, malt, spices, and alcohol. Medium body.

Bottle.  Dark cloudy brown pour with a thick tan head.  Aroma of raisins, caramel and Belgian yeast.  Taste of roasted malt, raisins and other dark fruit, and sticky sugar.  Full body hides the alcohol.

Pours a amber red color with a nice tan head.  Strong aromas of dark fruits, of plums and raisans with caramel and spices.  Flavors of sweet roasted malts, dry fruits, pears and raisans with spices.  There is something else I really cannot tell in the taste.  The feel of alcohol is present, with a sweet and bitter dry and creamy finish.  This beer is great and full of flavors, but still far from the other Trappist beers.

bottle - Chiaravalle monastery Milan. Dark amber color, creamy head. Olfactory explosion of plum, brown sugar and lightly spiced alcohol. Full-bodied Caramel, spiced plum and buttered raisin bread flavor, can taste the alcohol a tad bit more than other beers of this style. YUM!!
Massive and bold.  Sweet and alcoholic.  Darker in color with plums, apples, brown sugar, Christmas spice, etc.  A really full bodied chewy beer.  Nice.

Labeled as Konigshoeven Quad so this may have been an older bottle. This beer poured a dark orange-brown color with a huge orange-khaki head. The aroma was sugar, ripe fruits, caramel and had a touch of alcohol showing through. The flavor was sweet caramel, toffee, cocoa, candied pears/apricots and ginger. Alcohol again showed through a bit. The finish was long with notes of fruit and caramel. The body was thick and full. Complex, full, deep and rich. Excellent.

Darker brown cloudy body with a cream colored head. Great lacing. Aroma is very flowery with some raspberry, yeast, and caramel. Taste is full of flavor and thick with raisins, vanilla, and brown sugar. The mouthfeel is thick and creamy with carbonation. What a great beer!! I love this one and will go back to get more very soon!

This is the last Trappist brewery I have yet to try, until right now. 750ml corked and caged bottle under the Konings hoeven label. Pours a dark red/orange with a large gray head. The aroma seeps out of my Trappist glass and slowly fills the room. Plums, raisins, figs, black licorice, white vanilla flavored cake, toffee, wet hay, and cherry on the nose. The flavor is pleasantly complex. Initial sweetness of plums, raisins, figs, apple, and vanilla. Then a slight tart cherry flavor. Followed by a surprisingly bitter finish (for a Trappist any way). This truly is a great beer.

Huge head. Deep orange, slightly murky, yet inviting. Aroma is sweet bread, dark fruit. Obviously sweet but reasonably balanced. Fruity up front with a hint of banana, then raisins; finish is bitter licorice, pleasant and lasting. Smooth mouthfeel and delicate taste. Low spiciness but decent depth nonetheless.  10% alcohol adds warmth without spoiling the flavours. A very drinkable, gentle, if not too subtle or complex specimen of the genre.
UPDATED: SEP 23, 2011 33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex brew, yet heavy, balanced, hazy, good head, very good Trappist

750ml bottle poured into a tulip glass.  No matter how hard I tried, I could not get a head on this ale.  The body was a beautiful reddish-brown.  The alcohol was warming and pleasant and went well with the sweetness of fruits and spices.  I agree that this was more barleywine-like than I expected.
Found somewhere in Odessa, Ukraine. A real gentle giant: fruity, malty, caramelly, sweet and very intense all the way. Alcohol is persistent but it is so warming and delicate. Nice.

.33L bottle, small pale coffee coloured head, deep dark orange colour which is a touch hazy, malty aroma with notes of dates, figs,  brown sugar, vanila pod and some fruits, fruity sweetness with some banana and dates presence,  also some light caramel, alcoholic presence but not overpowering and turning suprisingly and pleasantly sour, syrupy texture and coating your mouth. A pleasure.

330ml bottle into eponymous branded Trappist glass. The beer pours a translucent dark brown with a dark red hue and a medium lingering tan head that provides excellent lacing. Complex aromas of caramel, burnt brown sugar, figs, plums, vanilla bean, cherry-flavoured cough syrup, alcohol and warming peppery spices. Tastes not as sweet as the nose would suggest with a rich full body and a syrupy mouthfeel. Certainly plenty going on here to keep you occupied. A pleasure to drink - the slower the better.

750 ml. bottle. Pours a exuberant off white head,  minimal lacing, over a clear, amber (SRM 13-15) body......nose heavy with fruity esters including plum,dried  cherry, bit of Belgian funk, toffee, caramel.....taste is sweet initially and throughout, with balancing dried fruits including cherry, raisin, bit of pepper, finishing slightly dry and with mild hop bitterness....mouth feel is medium, body surprisingly light, carbonation medium. This is a nice example of the style, fruity esters dominate, alcohol is obvious, sweetness is slightly subdued, hop balance is used with a light hand. The BJCP  has called this more "Barley Wine" in style, I cant get to there from here.

12 oz bottle served in a tulip glass.  Pour looks brownish, but when held up, is really deep amber.  Four thick fingers of wet, light tan river foam set atop of this brew.  Nose is not overbearing at all, its mostly Belgian yeast and some light spice.  Taste is quite pleasing.  The yeast is prevalent, with the spices dancing around your tongue as the finish turns into a warming sensation in the chest.  There is also something sweet that surfaces about 30 seconds after the swallow  not really sure, but I think it is candied sugar.  Although most of the categories wont get the highest of marks, I really enjoyed this one.  Great companion to a chilly evening!

A nose of raisins, yeast, sugars and pear. The taste is of yeast, sugars, mint and fermented fruit - at least you get a hint of those flavors before a massive taste of amaretto/björnklister/marzipan takes over completely. Too much alcohol in the finish. I probably shouldnt have opened this already. Its not awful, but it clearly doesnt live up to my expectations. I have one more bottle in the cellar = rerate in a year or so.
Seemed like the alcohol content was forced - ABV over taste and texture. Pretty good, but could have been much better.
Dark color. White head. Good sweetness from fruit and raisin. Nice bitterness. Balanced

Aroma of fermented fruit, yeast and toffe. Apperance is red-orange with small white head. Flavor of fermented fruits, raissins and yeast, the alcohol is shining threw. Overal a quite weak quadrupel with to much taste of alcohol.
Bottle: malty, vinous, fruity, some over ripe apples, loads of caramel, very sweet and alcoholic, good beer but a bit too much alcohol in the taste.
pours reddish orange with little head and no lacing.  smells of sweet fruit and bread.  taste about the same thing with slight alcohol aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUL 30, 2012 (bottle) pours a clear ruby-amber colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of bubble gum, dark fruit and powdered sugar, heavy caramel, a hint of marzipan, pineapple and herbal hops. flavour is mostly caramel, gently roasted pale malts and mellow yeast, with only a hint of dark fruit and bubble gum in the finish, no alcohol detectable. medium to heavy-bodied with lively carbonation.

Deep dark and heavy beer. This beer is made for a great dinner but to drink it solo, it is too heavy for me. Great palate.

Nose contains a lot of alcohol. Next to that some fruits, sugar and a few hoppy notes.

Bottle. molasses/plum aroma with a deep dark amber hue...  taste of plum, fruit, spice and some molasses and raisins... a bit dry but still smooth... well balanced with the alcohol flavor and sweetness... great quad

Tastes like deep frozen banana icecream, even the palate is sort of similar. A very soothing beer that should be served not too cold. Very warming but doesnt immediately taste as the 10% that it is.
Readily available, got this one at the Albert Heyn supermarkets, have seen it on Tap at the Arendsnest as well

Draft at Ebenezers. Pours a lighter look than I would anticipate. More ambery. Nose is vinous and grapy, slight funk to it. Mouthfeel is lighter than Id like. Finish is dry and spice. Bready, though not super rich. Alright.

Labeled as Koningshoeven Quadrupel:  Perfect aroma consisting of bread dough, sweetened plums, raisins and dark cherries with a heavy dose of buckwheat pancakes, spicy clove, honey and even some molasses.  A plethora of layered aromatics.  Cloudy amber-brown body, lasting 1/2" off white head that looks like a warm blanket.  Thick lacing covers much of the glass.  Sweet and dry body with a strong kick.  Flavor has a lot of dark, fermented fruits, cherry and raisins stick out.  Hints of anise and clove lead way to a nice thick taste of fresh sticky buns and multi-grain bread.  Aftertaste is of a mild port wine with some brown sugar.  This is world class.
Dark amber coloured, white head, staying for a half cm. Hints of candy, caramel, roasted nuts. Lots of carbonation, tastes bitter, sweety, with coffee and the bitterness of cacao.

Drank on tap at Burp Monk in New York with Tim Dziubek and Anuj Kumar. This was a very nice mildly bitter and full bodied beer. The color is a deep and dark amber with a creamy off-white head. The aroma is hoppy with a very sweet underlying flavor. 

I wish this were not my last beer of the night. The full alcoholic body knocked me out!

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2010 750 ml Koningshoeven bottle -- corked with metal cage. Pours a a hazy dark amber-brown with a creamy white head. Aroma is hoppy with a maple character. The aroma is relatively complex -- other elements are noticeably present but difficult to distinguish -- and culminates in a sort of earthy, fresh smell of the outdoors. Flavor comes in three stages: initially a strong maple character, then a wave of fig and dark fruit that crescendos to a strongly alcoholic, malty finish -- a flavor that is sweetly balanced and symphonically complex. Very strong with a light-to-medium body. A distinctly earthly character that resonates with the sound of silence.

Poured into goblet, had a nice finger of sodaesque head that slowly becomes a small island with a nice lacing ring around the edges. Carbonation rises to continue to create pockets of head.

Smell is damn good; fruity, sweet like a champagne, scent of grapes, rasins, malt. No detectable hop smell or any defects.

Taste is good. It is very strong, light bodied, and a dry feeling. Very earthy flavor with a tiny bite of bitterness at the end. Very good, though probably the least favorite of the quads that I have had.

Drinkability is medium, I probably wouldnt be able to do more than one of these and would just go to another quad if I could.

750 ml Konings Hoeven bottle.  Nice amber color with a sweet aroma.  Another great Trappist Quad.  This one is from the Netherlands and is just a bit sweeter and thinner than the Belgians.  A very nice beer and a solid choice anytime.

1995 bottle. Pours a hazy orange color with nearly no head. Malty toffeeish aroma with fairly some oxidation including sherry and faint cardboard notes. Taste is raisins, chocolate, spicy notes, sherry. Faintly tart finish. Medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Holding up pretty well after all these years.

Dark amber, retaining head. Medium bubbles - nice.

 Aroma: Argh! Seems I have  a cold comming - no sense of smell. Wife says not strong aroma, sweet.

 Alcohol in the initial taste, but quickly dampened, then a little sweet and watery for the rest. Impressive given the ABV, but somewhat boring.

 Watery, thin bodied. Flat.

 In the end not so bad. Sipping ends with a licorice dry tongue. Quite nice.

 Purchased in SuperBest.

BeerBaron617 picked up this bottle a few days ago and shared it with me today :)  I sure am glad he did.

It poured a really pretty golden amber color with a white head that left really nice lacing in the glass.  Aroma and taste both were quite complex.  It had a slight scent of tropical fruits with mild spice.  There was definitely a bit of alcohol on the nose as well...considering when I smelled it, it sort of burned the inside of my nose.  Taste was just the same, tropical fruits, as well as a bit of a white wine flavor, alcohol warming and spice.  Overall quite tasty, I wish I had more.

Shared a 750ml bottle of this with MereLikesBeer, and my father. Pours a light amber, with a darker core, really nice color in the light. The aroma is classic Belgian, with some slight honey notes on the finish. The flavor is also classic, with some melon and tropical fruitiness. This was also accentuated by the carbonation, which was perfect. Really great stuff! Cheers!

Bottle at Stellas cafe. Nose is very bright and citrusy. Grapefruit rind, mild spice, banana, brandy, ripe red fruits, a touch boozy. Palate is softer and mellower than the nose. Still plenty of syrupy red fruit, a bit overly boozy, and a bit thin. In no way the equal of Roquefort or other top quads. Below average.

750 Koningshoeven bottle, at-least a year old, could be up to two, 08:32 K26D7, whatever that means.   Pours a darker glowing orangish red with a tall foamy beige very thick creamy froth.  Aroma is strong of fruity esters, alcohol, hint of banana phenols, some vanilla, quite rich.  Flavor is much the same, hot and rich, touch of banana, caramel, toasted light brown sugar, touch of sweet white raisins, a bit doughy, rich and sugary but mostly without depth, little bit of vanilla towards the finish, some lingering burn.  Develops more of a Gulden Draak candy sweetness and burn along side a Unibroue yeast quality.  Medium/full bodied,  creamy and fluffy with some sharp fine carbonation and leftover stickiness.   Actually quite good for a  Quad, still prefer any Abt though.

This is certainly an enjoyable beer, but trying the Dubbel, Tripel and Quad together, Im highly confused about the Quads significantly higher ratings.  True, its a bit better.  The flavor is fuller, the malt is richer and the beer is a bit more warming, but the flavor profile is in line with the rest of the lineup with the smaller beers.  Im even lowering the rating a bit in deference to style comparisons.  On a flat rating scale, this would be more highly rated than the Tripel or the Dubbel.  At any rate, the Quad pours a deep medium red. Its translucent with amber highlight at certain angles.  Its actually less murky than the Tripel (maybe a function of the pour).  Theres a bit more lacing, though.  The aroma has more banana bread and clove than I noticed in the previous Koningshoeven beers.  There are also aromas of vanilla, brandy and apricots/plums.  The flavor is similar with peppery spicing.  Im again impressed at the depth of flavor these Trappist brewers are able to get out of such simple ingredients.  Its one hell of a strain of a yeast that can impart this depth of flavor.  If not for style comparisons, Id bump up my ratings in every category.

From bottle, pours ruby stunnig color with a nice off white head, caramel, raisins, vanilla and alcohol in the aroma, flavor is intense with some caramel, lots of alcohol and tones of butter, sweetness is high body is medium, finishes with some spices like cinammon and coriander. I might be mean if I would say that it reminds me of a malt liquor, but it does.
woody, amber, light sweetness, medium bitterness, light body, thin feel, soft carbonation, long finish,

Poured dark brown color with a medium white head to it. Has a bit of fruity smell to it. Has a fruity flavor to it with a boozy finish to it. Needs to have a little more body to it for the abv it has. Maybe it just needs to age a little bit. Thought this would be better

Dark amber colour, i tasted many trapisstes so i can judge thismuch better. Quite medium head. Nice caramel, honey, sweet malt. Very well balanced malts and hops. Bittery finish mix with sweetness. Such an amazing beer.

Bottle in São Paulo - Very strong beer... however... this not affect the good taste of honey and fruits (malty beer indeed)... it is not as complex as other Quadrupels, however, it is a good and decent beer.

Cool aroma! toffee, candy, wet bark, dark dried fruits, sweet and very interesting spices, dried bananas (faint), pink bubble gum of lower quality. The taste is pretty good but quite sweet, plums, sweet malts which hold up the body of flavour, yummy soft candies, something resembling lemon meringue - no crust, soft, acceptable spice with hints of weak pepper, sour apple on the finish. There is a shit load of carbonation here that is perfect, medium bodied, leaves a bit of a pasty coating

Once I cracked this one, it filled the room with the scent of fresh apricots. Darkened amber. Apricots dominated the flavours with notes of honey. Thick in body in addition to lots of sediment. Mildly sweet, not too bitter.
Amber in color with a medium head. Aroma is strong and sweet with a lot of malt. The taste is rich and sweet with an ok balance between malt and sweetness.
Aroma is bready and sweet malt.  Sweet flavor with no appealing notes.  Became a challenge to finish it.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 11.2oz bottle into a goblet. 

Appearance: The body has a dark crimson amber color with bright ruby highlights and good clarity. It forms a small light tan head on top that fades out fast leaving little to no lacing.

Smell: Its nose has some fruity, raisin like estery notes with some honey like sweetness and dark sugary notes.

Taste/Mouth: The flavor starts on a somewhat thin on a medium body with sweet candy and a honey malt base with simple mild fruity notes. Raisin is the stand out. The presence of alcohol is very mild and adds some brandy like complexity to the finish. Hop flavor and bitterness are not noticeable. The texture is slick and thinner than I would expect for a Quad. The carbonation is light and somewhat fizzy.

Notes: I was really under-whelmed by this beer. It tasted fine but it lacked the complexity and body of other Quadruples I have tried.

Tasted from a 500 ml bottle. The fact that this one is a strong beer doesnt seem to affect its taste. Its nice amber red color makes a good impression at the beginning. Its sweet bitterness confirms that impression. Very nicey treated beer. My congratulations to the brewery!!!

UPDATED: APR 20, 2010 Re-rate 4/20/2010. Somewhat dark with small off-white head. Aroma is very faint. Thin mouthfeel for a quad. The last bottle I had was really heavy on the alcohol taste. This one has very little alcohol in the flavor by comparison... and overall the "quad-ness" just seems weak this time. Weird.

Amazingly good.  Starts with an elegantly embossed bottle leading to the rich copper colour and a big foamy head, tan in colour.  The aroma was slightly "fruity" and also of spices; for the life of me I know not which ones.  Taste and mouthfeel were just superb, with more fruit and spice.

Translucent hazy orange body (very light for an abt it seems); medium beige head, doesnt last long. Deep aroma - bread, alcohol tones, apricot hints. Initial kick of alcohol, finishing kick of alcohol; doesnt come off particularly boozy however. Missing the range of dark flavors typical of the style; rather this seems more of a tripel/quad hybrid. Bread, mandarin orange, fruitcake, reminds me of Abbaye des Rocs brews. A well made and respectable monastic beer.
Taster at Seattle International Beer Festival.  Orange brown with no head.  Smells of caramel apples, perfect for fall.  Tastes of slight banana, apple, and caramel.

Colore marrone con riflessi arancioni o ambra,schiuma marroncina e spessa.Aroma quasi vinoso,zuccheroso.Il gusto è fruttato,di mora,dolce ma un pò alcoolico,con qualche nota di cioccolato.Una buona birra.

Bottled.
Brown with beige head. Aroma and flavor of caramel, roasted malts, coffee, dried fruit and chocolate. Alcoholic
Smells of orangy fruit, tastes bitter, like dark fruits, vaguely soapy and with a slight alcohol burn. Color is a rich clear orange with thin head. Light med. body and a bitter finish.

Beautiful, poured dark amber, reddish highlights, thick tan foam.  Velvety sugary, slightly boozy mouthfeel, oh so nice.  Bit warming and a bit of brandy in there too.  Nose is spicy, with plums, a bit of sour and bananas.  Very nice and very enjoyable.

Pours kind of ruddy dark reddish orange. Aromas of dark fruit and yeast, a bit of a rum based tropical cocktail. Flavor is fruity with  a slight earthy yeast musk. Very full flavored and nice to drink. A bit of alcohol in the finish but it works. Obviously, nothing on westy, rochefort, or st bernardus, but still a very good belgian Quad.

The nose is lovingly caressed by layers of brandy soaked fruit, apples, pears, with a touch of banana.  Like the other darker offerings from Koningshoeven this beer leans heavy on sweet malt and ester fruit.  The alcohol is slightly less than bracing and lingers long on the finish.  FIne beer for salty cheeses.
Tap at the Muddy Pig.  Very fruity aroma with dark pited fruits, yeast, and alcohol.  Sweet, solid mouthfeel.  Very very delicious.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2014 Dark amber with a small, but lasting off-white head. Aroma of malt, sherry, almonds and a touch of alcohol/solvents. Big flavour, rather sweet and vineous, fruit and caramel , and lasting, warming alcohol.
UPDATED: NOV 4, 2011 This is a strong beer. Not only in alcohol, but in flavor. Kind of overwhelmingly so. Flavor is fruity. Plums, Blackcurrants, Brandy, etc. Not as great as some other Quads. Nice.

Popped the cap and it overflowed, but this time I was ready and had it over the La Trappe chalice. This is the second one thats burst when I opened it so Ill assume I got a bad batch or theyre just meant to soak your table in beer. Pours very fizzy and pop-like, no head aside from what overflowed from the bottle. Very alcohol-sweet cognac smell, nice dark red colour. Very good smooth fruity flavour though - cherries, chocolate, dark grains. Average mouthfeel. Aside from the initial explosions, pretty good.

Hazy dark amber, large foamy beige head. Nose of berry, toffee and almond, also some bubblegum and grass. Flavor is maltier, sweeter, some alcohol coming through. Rather dry body, moderate in size and carbonation but somewhat syrupy. Finish has some yeast and fruit. The alcohol and body are somewhat off-putting, but the malts and fruits are nicely balanced without going overboard into Candy Land.
Lovely beer. Full, little bit fruity taste. Gives a warm feeling in your throat. Not to bitter, very good.

11.2 ounce bottle - $5.29 at Total Wine & More in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Clear, dark brown body with a reasonably well-sized, off-white head. Random bits of lacing on the way down.

Smell: Sweetish, earthly spiced, and ripe fruity notes all come together to harmoniously provide notes of candy, caramel-covered fruits, dark loaf bread, and even alcohol. Yes, even alcohol, friends.

Taste: Sweetish, dark maltiness with very, very light tastes of chocolate and even cinnamon-flavored Breakfast Blend coffee. Touch of dark breadiness. Hearty spread of gooey dark caramel. Dash of earthy spices, mainly clove. Another pinch of table sugar. Fruity tastes of green raisins, ripe figs, and green apples marinated in spiced rum. Touch of bitterness. Sweetish, earthy, warming finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium-full body. Medium carbonation. Smooth mouthfeel.

Drinkability: Worth a try. The worlds greatest quadrupel? Heck no! A decent, okay-inducing quad? Sure.

50cl ceramic bottle poured into a Chimay Trappist glass.  Dark amber with ample creamy tan head.  Aroma is bubblegum.  Flavor is bubblegum, spice, alcohol.  Medium carbonation.  Finish is alcohol.  This one is very much like the dubbel but with stronger alcohol.

As Koningshoeven Quadrupel Trappist Ale. Pours a cloudy ruby red/brown with a medium head that quickly recedes to a thin layer of lacing. Aroma is mostly of banana and spice. Flavor is a lot more complex and robust; The banana comes again with the spice, but also comes the trappist qualities of breadiness, yeast,  and a lot of flora. Again, very complex. Very creamy in mouthfeel and finish; Just perfect on the palate. Im really enjoying this one a lot. I put it third behind Bernardus and Rochefort in the Quad department. Overall, excellent to world class.

Enjoyed from a 11.2oz bottle in a whiskey snifter.  The beer pours a nice deep brown, with a just barely off-white head.  The aroma brings notes of yeast-derived flavors of plumes and some lightly toasted raisons, along with a slight pilsner malt-type graininess.  The beer is full on the palate, bringing a sweetness that is pleasant and not cloying.  While I have had some examples of the style that offer more rounded and complex malty flavors, this beer was still extremely enjoyable.  A great quadrupel and a must try from the worlds only non-Belgian Trappist brewery.

33cl bottle, La Trappe glass.
pours dark brown/ruby, off white head.
Aroma of candi sugar, dark fruits and malts
Taste, malty, dark fruits with raisins, currants, candi sugar with yeast elements, starts off light and becomes more complex as the warming abv dissipates.

Had on tap at Julians in Providence, RI. To me, this was a very pleasant, drinkable, and spot-on example of the style. The nose possesses a desirable fruit ester and mild spice aroma, along with toasted grain and fresh bread. The fruity ester I identified in both the aroma and flavour was most similar to black cherry, as it was sweet, not all tart, and was the first suggestion that came to mind. The bready malts and dry finish (which I attributed to the Belgian yeast) let me know this was a true Belgian Quad. There was a medium, warming alcoholic presence and a tingly carbonation that accompanied the medium, airy body well. I was pretty stoked!

Bottle. Pours reddish brown with a medium head that diminished. Fruity aroma with notes of bread and alcohol. The flavour is bread, fruit and alcohol. Theres a harshness present in the mouthfeel from the alcohol phenols and lacks the smoothness Id like to see in a quad.
This is hands down the worst trappist beer. It tasted like alcohol and feet. This one needed more carbonation and greater complexity. A real letdown.

Appearance:  Pours a cloudy plum color, letting a little bit of light through. On top is a 1/4 inch of white head.

Aroma:  Belgian yeast, spices, bread.

Taste:  Bread crust, fruity belgian yeast, dark fruits, spicy hops, and a little bit of bitterness.

Mouthfeel:  Fizzy, and perfect thickness.

Overall:  Very enjoyable, not overly complex, and would pair well with roasted meats.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2009 Starts with a nice head, but this increases quickly. Though I must say a rather nice head for a Dutch beer! The colour is lovely: amber and a bit hazy.
Flavor is fruity (little pinch of banana and other exotic sweet fruits), grains and alcohol. Nice beer!

bottle, nice but small stable white head, amber/dark orange colour, smell: alcohol, fruity. The beer gives you a warm feeling because the alcohol rate. But most important is the delicious fruity taste: bananas, pear, mango. Also notes from grain, yeast, alcohol. This may be the best Dutch beer?

Molasses like aroma with a hint of yeastiness. A more brown than orange pour with a fluffy off white head and lace.
An almost mediciny sweetness that lingers lightly on your mouth. Mild carbonation and medium bodied. Nice sipper. A tad boozy but not bad on that front.

Bottle. Pours clear deep amber with generous off-white head. Tons of fruits going on here... why name them all? Some banana, golden raisin, apple, pear, peach, as well as Belgian sugar and some yeast notes, which I wanted a bit more of. Still pretty damn tasty.

On tap at La Trappe in SF (no relation).  Reddish-brown color with an off-white head.  Aroma of banana, fruity esters, and sweet malt.  Flavor is complex with banana and other light fruits, sweet caramel malt, Belgian yeast, and spices.  Smooth, creamy palate with medium-full body.  Great stuff.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2015 In a La Trappe goblet ;  Bright purple/brown with a good white foam that morphs into beige ..nose of Chocolate covered grapes , chocolate covered brownies , banana esters , rich caramel malt , hop spice...Grate little aroma ;  On the palate its very lively , robust booze showcases through out and this makes it rather peppery in texture -notes of caramel , chocolate , all spice , raisins , yeast expression . Ends dryish and cloying .   A quality Quad ... would like to age one as id speculate the boozy edges would mellow !

On tap. Poured a dark brown with a red tinge and an beige head. Aroma is complex,  hints of dark fruits, malts and some sugar. Flavor is complex as well and bring out the components of the aroma well.

330 ml bottle. Dark, reddish brown body with a fair off/white head. Aroma of sweet malt, dry fruit and a hint of alcohol like sherry. Flavor is sweet  malt, dry fruit, vinous alcohol, chocolate and spices. Complex, rich and very pleasant.
brown with orange highlights.nice white head.the aroma is chocolate,leather,dark fruits,sweet belgian candy,and brown sugar.flavor does much of the same.nice and complex with the alcohol well hidden.
Bottle. The Rover. Gothenburg. Deep golden colour. Sweetness, banana, pears, yeast, spices, sugar, caramel, alcohol.

Though my palate is not as refined as the senior members on the site, I can definitely taste a banana nut bread component to this beer.  beautiful color and a very nice smell.  Large and lasting head too.  $8.99 for 1p 9.4fl oz in my neck of the woods.  Overall a good beer from the trappists!

This is a big beer at 10% it smells like bubble gum, raspberrys and other hard coated candies. The taste is very much like the cheap hard candy raspberries with the gooey center in them that has the fake printed beery on the outside of wrapper that twist only at the top.  This beer would get you drunk with out you even knowing it. It really is that smooth.
Had it at the dig pub in cedar park on tap

Bottle shared by Andreasen11. 
It pours a mahogany colour with a medium tan head. 
Aroma is sweet malt, caramel, prunes and raisins with notes of banana and alcohol. 
Flavour is like the aroma but the alcohol is almost completely hidden. 
Well balanced, a very good beer!

Sweet nose of banana and cloves.  Pours a lovely deep golden copper with a persistant tan head.  Flavour is slow to develop - starting gently sweet with more banana and some mulled wine spice but then develops a richness anda  bitterness that pleases and contains hints of nutmeg and fresh baked bread.  The lingering flavour is malty and rich with a big fat kick of alcohol on the back of the tongue that adds rather than detracts.

33cl bottle, dark amber colour with sediments floating, minimal but persistent beige head, caramel and dark fruits (mostly raisins) aroma, sweet chocolate flavor, full body, finish with spices and warming alcohol presence, better than la trappe tripel tasted at the same time
