Bottle, 33 cl.  Clear reddish-brown color with beige head that diminished quickly. Fruity aroma. Thick, smooth mouthful. Sweet fruityand caramel taste with some alcohol. Long warm feeling after taste.

One of my wifes favorite beers. Her description is absolutely delicious!!!
An excellent example of a Quadrupel. Even though it has a high alcohol content, the alcohol flavor is subdued. The flavor is very smooth and somewhat sweet.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2009 From a Koningshoeven label at Coastal Wine Connection beer club.  Deep copper-red.  Big and sugary with apricot/peach, raisin and moldy fruit, brown sugar, medicine and very much warming from the alcohol aspect.  At the end it almost had a green apple tingle.  This was a young one, would like to do a vertical tasting of this one.  (#2672, 2/1/07) -- Separate impression from draft selection at Cheeky Monk, Denver -- definitely tilted toward the brown sugars, with a spicy bent.  But still a damn fine beer!

Bottle of Koningshoeven Quadrupel.  Will state up front that I had this one night after enjoying a Rochefort 10, so it had some stiff competition.  Vibrant, lasting off-white head with beautiful residual lacing.  Somewhat high on the carbonation, and a bit hoppier than I expected it to be, this bier definitely softened as it sat on the palate.  Very spicy and yeasty, this was a good, not excellent Quadrupel...would drink again!

This beer pours a crystal clear red-orange jewel with a thin, frothy white head thats mostly diminishing.  The aroma is like sweet baked goods in the oven... maybe apple crisp?  Once in the mouth, the medium-bodied ale starts with the twang on malt that turns into green apple and perhaps melon... with the slitest hop bite to set it off.  It has a very fresh, bright aftertaste of small, shiny green apples.  Nice!
cloudy dark orange with beige head, the aroma is of sweet fruit.  malty and alcoholic, the flavor is straightforward: toffee, sweet, yeasty, and slightly spicy.  thick.

Bottle (marked Koningshoeven): pours medium craggy head, retained for long time. First aroma is phenols and bananas.  Bananas recede and alcohol comes through stoutly but pleasantly, mixed with sharp malty sweet gentle mulling spices.  Flavor is smooth with plenty of alcohol taste and malty like a very well aged single malt whisky:  sweet, smooth, lightly biting.  Enjoyed from start to finish, moreso as it warmed.

bottle at Castros in Toronto. 
whoa is this boozy, right off the bat, im getting alot of yeast and fruit, but the booze is right there. definite alcohol burn. takes away from the flavours.

11.2 oz bottle labeled as Koningshoeven Quadrupel Trappist Ale enjoyed at the Winking Lizard Tavern (Crosswoods) in Columbus, Ohio on 1/23/2007...   Pours a deep reddish gold color with a very dense, rocky, long-lasting head that was beige in color.  The aroma was sweet and had some fresh banana, spice, malt, and yeast characteristics to it.  Sweet caramel malt dominates the flavor at first and then some fruit, real banana, and spice flavors begin to show.  The alcohol stays in the shadows at first and then rushes out just before the finish.  The alcohol seems a bit strong at first, but quickly retreats and assimilates with the rest of the flavors and lets the moderately bitter finish balance the beer.  The beer is thicker than average and quite smooth.  I really enjoyed this particular Quad!
Bottle: Cloudy, reddish amber in color with a big off white head. Aroma, fruits, some bready yeast, and some spice. Flavor, caramel, bready notes, some spice, raisins, prunes. Pretty solid brew.
Pours dark amber color with fizzy white head.  Aroma of peach, pear, fig, apple.  Flavor has a little banana mixed with the aforementioned pear and apple notes and yeasty finish.

Blind Quad 07.  750 ml bottle thanks to drewbeerme for this brew.  Looks great in the glass  fizzy off white head on top a slightly hazed amber orange body but a whiff of it.  Whew phenols is taking it over.  Perfume, chemicals, phenols, and a little lemon and yeast some where in there.  Im not sure why Im pickin up these more than anyone else.  Due to the lack of similar shaped glasses mine is taller and maybe concentrates those aromas so that I cant stand this one.  Very sugarry sweet peachy yeasty so much alcohol, this is hard to drink.  Why did we start off with this one?  Fizzy and astringent finish.  Cant finish my sample.  7 out of 9 over all but dead last for me.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2008 750ml, part of our blind "Better Know a Style: Abt/Quadrupel" tasting, big thanks to jimbowood for getting this to me in time for the quad tasting. pours a good fizzy head with nice lacing, a hazy amber/orange. nose is caramel, cookie, very yeasty, raisin, plum, and very peachy. this is a  very sweet beer with notes of peach and plum. finishes long, dry, watery, and lots of alcohol. finished 7th, out of 9 quads.

Bottle - January 2007. Beatifull clear deep full amber-organe color with a frothy, creamy slight beige head and vivid carbonatation. The head stays there, half an inch thick all my chalice. Aroma is strongly peaches, some yeasty phenols, some burnt sugar, caramel and fruits. Splendid.
Taste is very rich and comlex, confirms what insinuated in the nose. Full fruit flavor, some apricots, a bit of plums. Alcohol amazing and deceively conceibed. Mouthfeel is really creamy, full but no so mucho for a beer this size. Great drinkability for a 10% abv brew. Really nice and arguably the CEO at La Trappe.
750 ml bottle.  Oak and light fruit notes predominate w/ a mild alcohol finish that lingers on the tongue.  Very drinable.  A nice beer.

750ml bottle, dated 2000/2001 - Pours murky amber with a thin head and some lacing.  The yeast and malt aroma includes some dark fruit notes.  The flavor is very sweet with the 10% abv almost completely buried.  Given some other reviewers saying theirs was hot, Id guess age had something to do with it.  There are also some good spice and dark fruit notes.  Its full bodied and quite easy to drink, though almost too sweet and it doesnt seem to be as complex as some of the trappist ales.

750ml bottle.

Pours a dark red, with a frothy one finger head that fades quickly to a thick cap. The cap lasts throughout the entire drink, and leaves behind a spotty lace.

Smell; lots of dark fruits, with plums, grapes and maybe a little fig. Theres also a fairly strong sugary, candy like aroma, as well as alcohol.

Taste; very sweet, and candy like upfront. Once you get past the overbearing sweetness, theres some dark fruits, and a pretty nice bready maltiness. The alcohol is very much present, and actually becomes a nit to much after a while.

Mouthfeel/Drinkability; mouthfeel is thick and on the syrupy side, and when combined with the alcohol, makes this a bit of a chore to finish.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: Poured from bottle. Very fruity beer. Sweet. Tasted grapes right away. Tasted to me like a watery, carbonated wine, almost. Very unique. Very drinkable.

Bottle at Winking Lizard - Pours caramel in color with a short offwhite head.  Aromas of candi sugar, yeast, raisin, and cinnamon.  Flavor is candi sugar, raisin, some plum, brown sugar, and light spice.  Palate is very airy and medium bodied.. Pretty drinkable quad overall..

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2007 On tap at the Happy Gnome.  Aroma is spicy and sweet, very warming like breathing in a hot cinnamon cider.  Not too astonishing but pleasant like the holidays.  Flavor is brown spices initially, then a very bubblegummish cotton candy taste rubs my mouth the wrong way with processed sugar, but there is some mild bitterness in the finish that saves it.  Slippery, molten hot mouthfeel.  Vaguely lacking in complexity.
Bottle (from Bitter Virtue). Sweet caramely malts some fruit and nuts. Hot alcohol, sweet with some liquorice in the mouth. Lacks subtlety but its not too bad.

Woow, this beer was in a hurry to get out of the bottle. The head is huge, smooth and creamy and the color is dark brown. The aroma has notes of yeast and fruits, the mouth feel is oily. Flavour, well I admit that La Trappe has a very, special place in my heart, I simply like their beers!! At first its sweet, the I get notes of ripe mango, plum, fermented fruit, malt and some hops. The bitterness is developing in the long and fruity/citrussy finish.

Pours a nice orange-red into the glass. Heavy nose of candy, yeast ,bread, fruit, bananas, spices, a hint of cloves and alcohol. Thick and syrupy mouth-feel. Sweet and spicy on the tongue with hints of bubble-gum notes that is well balanced with a subtle bitterness. Warming alcohol finish. Delicious!!

0.33l bottle from supermarket in Amstelveen. Clear reddish-brown color with tall beige head that diminished quickly. Some lacing remained on the glass. Fruity aroma. Thick, smooth mouthful. Sweet fruity taste with some alcohol. Long warm feeling after the sip. My bottle was very young but this beer is excellent. Luckily I live in Belgium so it was easy to taste all trappist beers. This was my trappist  #7, the last one, it didnt disappoint me.
Draught at Ølbaren. Deep red - white head. Candy - (Vingummi), a lot of sweetness, dried fruits, raisins, malty, light bread, caramel, too much candy - with an alco-burn...

750ml bottle. In Brazil, beer lovers are just now discoverying the wonders of classic beer styles. Until some years ago, we only had pale lagers... So, being my fist Quadrupel, I was looking forward to this one. It is a strong beer (of course), the aroma is overwhelming with alcohol, fruits, malt... and it is very beaultiful to look at. It is sweet but also bitter, a nice balance. The alcohol is very present, but doesnt spoil the party. I shared it with some beer lover friends and some that drink plain lager (water), and they liked it, but one of then said it tasted like "cachaça" LOL!  A nice experience, and I am going to repeat it soon, cause I still got a 330ml bottle.
Old bottle labled "Koningshoeven Quadrupel Trappist Ale". Dark brown with small head. Odd spicy/dusty aroma. Sharp fruit. Bit of alcohol warming. Tasty.

Reddish brown, not as dark as one might think before pouring. Huge sweet banana aroma hits the nose right away. Taste is much better, sweet, pleasant, smooth, sweet again. Alcohol blends in surprisingly well. La Trappe is not my favourite trappist brewery and this is not my favourite abt/quadrupel, too sweet.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2014 First ratingInitial Rating Date: 12/15/200630 cl bottle from a friend from Holland.Smells of candy and some alcohol. Clear brown color, huge beige lasting head. Sweet alcohol taste, almonds and Belgian ale yeast as well. Long warming alcohol feeling. Spicy of pepper aftertaste. Smooth mouthfeel. Low bitterness.7/4/7/4/16=3.8Reratecl bottle thanks to Ingo! On May 24, 2014. BB 2015.Clear copper oxide color, small teal head. Sweet, amlty, alcohol, some cheese scent. Sweet, alcohol, light bitter taste. Warming. Fizzy mouthfeel, low bitterness.7/3/7/2/13=3.2

Drank in a trappist glass.  Dark brown poor with a thin sticky light brown head.  Aromas are very sweet. butterscoth, cereal, bread, chocolate, floral hops, dates... and the list goes on...  Extremely well balanced beer.  Flavors of cotton candy, allspice, caramel, plums, dates, a hint of cherries and apples.  You can feel the alcohol.  Bitterness is just perfect for this type of beer.  Vinous feel to it as well.  Might i add, it has aged for 4 years in my cellar.
lotsa sediment nice tan head amber colour, almost brown, lotsa dried fruit aroma, raisin plum taste, cellared and fresh all good

Bottled, at Belgian Beer Café, Rio de Janeiro. Dark brown color with a thick head. Fruity and spicy aroma, with notes of malt and yeast. Dry fruits and heavy malt flavor. Alcohol notes. Sweet finish. A very good beer

Cellars Tasting.  Im so glad this is back in town!  Never had a chance to try it the first time out and now I get it for free at a tasting.  What could be better?  Dark brown color with a medium tan head.  Nice aroma of malt with a bit of hop bitterness.  The taste is really the same.  Its not a ton of different flavors blending into one, but a simple strong malt taste thats lightly hopped.  Not hugely special, but very well made.

Bottled, bought in the Netherlands. Fine brown ale, lasting rocky head, with lots of carbonation.
Too much alcohol flavour, but there are lots of nice dried fruit, cherry and other goodies here too. Almost there, but not quite my type of ale.

Bottle (Volo)
Fine haze, amber brown, very fine medium crown (3+)
Solid, full bodied quad with highly drinkable palate. Light earthy touch with heavy malt base. Alcohol noticeable but well build in. Pleasure to drink. This ale shows the way to others how to make 10 % ale that is fun to drink.

(Draught at Monks Café, Stockholm, 17 Nov) Dark amber colour with small, brief head. Fruity, spicy nose with notes of dried apricots and underlying sweetness. Slightly closed. Fruity and spicy taste with dried fruit and apricots. Full body, rather sweet, with a spicy finish. Alcohol and sweetness shining through a tad too much. Nice though, and very warming.

30cl bottle pours a toffee colored brown into a trappist glass.  The aroma is sweet with rasins and plums, with small hints of alcohol and a little yeast.  the flavor is lacking in the hop area.  It does have a rich malty depth but it lacks balance.  nice palate that coats the mouth and tickles the tongue.  Good beer, but doesnt compare to lots of other quads.

Pours a murky dark amber with a medium head. Aroma is a pleasant blend of raison, plum, banana and spice. Body is medium with mild carbonation.  The flavor has a strong alcohol presence, with sweet fruit making an appearance. The finish is mostly spice. A very good sipping beer.

Bottle at home.
Mahogany with avery large off brown head, mostly lasting, good lacings. Aroma heavy malty (dark fruits), light hoppy. Flavor heavy sweet, light bitter. Medium/full body, soft carbonated. Really a pleaure to drink.

Bottle. Aroma of deep cherry, oak and walnut. The is some foam left in the glass, and the colour is hazy mahogany. The taste includes oak and grapes. Its quite dry, but it could be a lot stronger. The finish has a warmingly alcoholic touch to it, which raises the grades for this one.
Bottle at home. A good quadrupel. A sweet taste, with lots of fruit flavors in evidence. Also bitter. Doesnt hide its alcohol content too well. Bit strong kick at the end.

Bottle. Colour is dark-golden. Slightly creamy like thick head or though it felt very fizzy carbonated. Aroma is very candy and sweet, some notes of banana, dry fruit, yeast, apricot and maybe even marzipan. Body medium-full. Flavour is sweet with slight bitterness to it. Smooth sweet finish.

(Draught at Monks Café, Stockholm) Pours clear dark red. Candy sweet, ripe bananas and canned pears aroma with some marzipan/allmond paste. A bit spicy. Sweet, canned pears flavour with total lack of heavy quadrupel features. Some liquer feeling. Allmond. Medium, spicy body.

Slightly cloudy dark amber with a large light brown head, great retention and lacijng. Aroma of toffee, alcohol, plum, yeast, apricot and banana. Very alcoholic body, but reasonably smooth and very sweet. Flavours of caramel and plum, nowhere near as complex as the aroma. The finish is warming and candy sweet.

Bottled. Clear, amber, carbonating, with a lasting, dense, creamy beige head. Banana, caramel, prunes, raisins, alcohol, candisugar and hints of cigars. Lovely, silky, warming mouthfeel with flavors of alcohol, dried fruits, yeast, candisugar, caramel, spices and ripe pears. Full-bodied and sweet. The finish has alcohol, spices and sugar. A hint of bitterness as well. Finally, when this quite quaffable beer is drunk, the lacings are still there. I love it. A lot. (061011)

Has a big fruity aroma and a soft fruit taste that is initially very sweet but then mellows a bit. A few spices near the end. Taste is actually ill-defined, nothing I can actually pick out. Reminds me of chimay rouge and not just because of the colour.

Bottle in Tallin. One of those bottles you just dont want to finish... every sip reveals something a bit new you missed the first time. Toffee, caramel, berries, touch of malt.  Marries the attributes of a great dark beer and a great dark beer, like a half-half with everything perfectly in balance. Deserving of waffle.

750ml bottle.  Pours a reddish copper color with a moderate, foamy head.  Nose is fruity, with floral hops, brown sugar, spice, perhaps malts.  Flavor is sweet (overall), with an initial taste thats heavy on the malts, then smooths out and lets some caramel, as well as spice, come through.
Bottle and Tap! Strong (10% alcohol) with a sweet taste and great dark red colour. Rasberrie and plums malts. Prefer the tap than the bottle.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2009 Bottle from the SAQ, in a trappist glass. Poured a hazy caramel colour with a medium head. Aroma is spicy, with sweet malt, apple, red fruits and raisins wtih notes of yeast and alcohol. The 10% abv is well hidden, it is dominated by spices and sweet malts, with notes of dough and fruits and a somewhat bitter aftertaste. Very good!
Bottle. Cloudy brown colour with a nice head. Aroma of fruit and alcohol. Flavour of malt, fruit and alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 29, 2016 Copper coloured beer with a huge beige head. Aroma of dried fruits and roasty malts. Flavor is dominated by dried fruits, caramel and some toasty notes. Heavy palate, and finish. A good slow beer indeed.
Im going to have to look back at my notes, but as I remember it was on the sweet side, with a finish that was a bit alcoholic not as balanced as say Chimay would be.

UPDATED: APR 28, 2009 On tap @ tardenest, Amsterdam. 
Served in those beautiful stembowl glasses. Clear dark reddish-brown color. Tiny tanned head. Aroma-o-rama! Sweet malts, raisins, figs, melon, pears and apples all over the place. Taste is sweet malts, warming alcohol and fruits. Velvetly mothfeel. A great beer.

I tasted "blind" to RateBeer and got a 3.8, right on the money.  I was told going in to expect caramel and spices, and I suppose theyre in there somewhere, but it biased my expectations.  Light amber, ample head, has fruit content, little nose, soft and smooth on the palate.  A very drinkable, almost session Quad, but not top of the heap for the style.

Bottle. Poured cloudy brown color with an average fizzy off-white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Heavy tart citrus, raisins and alcohol aroma. Medium to full body with a smooth texture. Heavy balanced sweet flavor with a medium bittersweet finish of long duration. This is a standout beer.

Poured toffeee brown with a huge head that laced quite well. Aroma of bugglegum, alcohol, some licorice and a bit of grainy malt. It also gave me a bit of a burn in the nostrils for my trouble!! The alcohol was thankfully well contained on tasting, and it was reasonably easy drinking. Quite sweet, but manageable. The aftertaste was fairly light, which was surprising. It definitely did not live up to its expectations. (Thanks to highlandlad).
An sweet, alcoholic smell, wich it also taste like together with some bread, amber looking, little cloudy

UPDATED: JAN 30, 2008 Dark brownish red with thick tan foam.  Beautiful cherry malt aroma with alcohol apparent. Flavor is same with dark fruits, vigorous carbonation and vanilla in the finish Fantastic at $2.30/12 oz

Bottle.Pours a hazy amber with a nice lasting head.Aromas of dried fruits,sweet malt,spices and hops.Flavors of fruit ,dried fruits,malt,spice and hops for a little bitterness to cut the sweetness.An alright quad but Ive had much better.
Nice head with yellow/grey colour. Roasted and hints af rye. Taste is slight sweet with almond and raisin.
Bottle. Nice big head with good duration. Color is amber. Aroma is spices and some fruit. Taste is spices and malt. Alcoholic finish.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2006 Thought it would be a cold day in hell before I tasted an Australian ale and a European quad side by side and preferred the Australian. But here we are. It has me wondering just how much the running order during a tasting session influences perceptions of a beer? Drank this one immediately after a seven-year-old Hahn Special Vintage 2000 English strong ale and the juxtaposition did this no favours. Not to say this is a bad quad, but it seemed sugary-sweet and frivolous after the austerity of the Hahn. This looked divine: hazy chestnut with a tall, loose sudsy head that laced magnificently. However, the aroma seemed teeth-rottingly sweet and artificially perfumey. It was all Bazooka Joe bubblegum, cane sugar and Parma Violet candies. Much simpler than the tripel and very sugary. Great creamy mouthfeel, nice and full. Carries its alcohol very well but too sweet for my taste. Bubblegum again, toffee and a big warming brandy finish. Ive enjoyed the La Trappe range more than most but this seems like a weak link. Ill take the tripel and dubbel over this. (33cl bottle from IBS, Perth; best before JUne 2008)

I started to add this rating and realized I was adding it immediately following a fellow Oxford rater. And weirder still, I too found this bottle at the same "Dogdy Deli" aka Classic Beer & Wine on Cowley Rd. Interesting little hole in the wall shop. On to the beer: Huge cap of beige on a deep chestnut pour. Rich plums, spice cake and vanilla, with a high-frequency vapor hum. Rounded brown sugar and plum flavors. Clearly a substantial beer, but still very delicate around the edges, with a soft dry finish and a little lingering raisin flavor. Im stoked to have found a solid quad I can get here in town!

330ml Bottle Picked up from the Dodgy Deli on the Cowley Rd, Oxford. Dark brown in colour which probably should have had a smaller head than the one I gave it with my careless pouring, crikey this is strong and yet the alcohol never tasted harsh. This is a lovely beer, wonderful fruitiness and spiciness, very rich and complex vanilla overtones also present, this was a very good find most impressed.

Bought it in a  Koningshoeven 4pk with a Trappist Glass.  This is the big daddy.  Very strong!  Dark nutbrown color.  not much of a head.  Maybe from the alcohol.  Aroma of molasses, dark fruits like plums, prunes, figs, and dates.  I recommend this Drupel!
Dark beer, smallish head (the girl could pour, thank estonia) with a rich malty flavour, with light hints of chocolate. A nice start to any day.

The aroma is of sugared dates.  Overly carbonated and foamy feeling on the palate.  As with other quads, you can tell that there is a high standard of quality applied but you can also tell that there are better non-Trappist versions out there as well.

750 Konings Hoeven bottle.  pours a chesnut brown with a quickly dissapating, creamy head that left a little lace around the rim.  nose is of roasted chocolate and caramel with a bit of dates and yeast.  tastes nicely toasted with caramel, chocolate, semi-sweet fruits, and mild alchohol.  pretty good.
Pours a hazy copper with small whie head.  Toffee aoma. Malty with notes of cloves and bananas and other fruits. Some alcohol burn.  Dry, bitter finish.   Pretty lively beer.

Bottled. Amber color. Fruity aroma with toffee, melon and some alcohol. Full bodied and sweetish flavor with strange spiciness (cumin?), warming alcohol, toffee, melon and pineapple. Sweet finish with pineapple.

750ml "Koningshoeven Quadrupel" version at the Bier Garden, Portsmouth, VA. Amber pour with a white head. Lots of fruit and bready scents in the nose. Fairly sweet, toffee and fruit. Some spiciness emerges as it warms. Solid quad.

Pours a hazy mahogany with a fluffy yellowish head that collapsed quickly. Alcohol is immediately evident in the aroma, followed by fruity and bready fragrances that are quite inviting. Medium body that is quite rich with a mouth coating feel. Complex flavors that start off sweet with dark brown suger, sweet dark fruit, and followed by the alcohol and then some spicy flavors. Finish is somewhat sweet, with a lingering stickiness, and just the slightest amount of bitterness.
Hazy gold, minimal head. Huge, sweet fruity aroma. Very malt dominated with an almost cloying sweet mouthfeel. Very high alcohol presence. Seems like a barley wine to me.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2007 Wow, I really like the smell and taste of this beer.  It has heavy overtones of fruits in both.  As previously stated, there is really no head to speak of, but thats not really a quality I care about when dealing with a trappist beer.  I enjoy and recommend this beer.
user_location: The United States of Texas, Texas, USA

text:
UPDATED: JAN 26, 2009 Bottle. Hazy amber color with minimal head. Fruity aromas and sweet citric fruit tastes with some notes of red fruit (plum, figue). 
Very nice and enjoyable beer.

poured a amber-brownish mix with a tan head which had some retention.  Aroma was a mix of bread, spicy, and chocolate malts and some alcohol.  Taste was sweet but not overpoweringly sweet. Had some spicy hop notes almost like pepper and corriander.  Nice alcohol presence throught out the glass. Really smooth and rich.

Koningshoeven label. Pours dark amber into a trappist glass.  Off-white medium head with nice staing power.  Jaegermeister notes -- fizzy and light with Jaegermeister coming through in the palate.  Lasting alcohol finish.

Off-white head floating on top of amber pour. Subtle nose of fruit - apricot, plum - and coriander spice and alcohol and bready malts. Flavor dominated by sweet malts and alcohol warmth. In between are notes of overripe fruit, especially plum. Finishes slightly bitter and peppery and full of alcohol. Full body with syrupy mouthfeel and moderately long finish.

I actually think its a little light for a quadruple. But I dont really mind that. The aroma is sweet and fruity with some spice. There is brown sugar, coriander, bananas, and yeast. The palate is a little thin. There is a nice malt aftertaste but the alcohol is not well hidden in this one. Also I detect a metallic element but overall it has a nice taste.

UPDATED: JUN 25, 2006 Aroma is somewhat lacking, bit of caramel, mettalic, nutty.
body is brown but a thick white head.
Taste is very caramel oriented, with copper, and a bit of alcohol.
Good Dutch brew, but not spectacular.
Dark brown with a reddish bubbly white head. Sweet fruity aroma opens your nostrils. Very sour fruity spice burst turns into a tingly caramel malt.
Sweet, malty aroma... flavor was sweet, malty, spicy, yeasty, and slightly tart.  This style of beer isnt really my thing, but it is clearly a quality product.

Dark brown appearance with a thick off-white head. Taste is sweet, caramel and slightly nutty. Alcohol is a little to prevalent in taste compared to some other quads. Overall, pretty decent quad, but for the price theres definitely better ones out there.

Despite what people are saying this beer is not an "official Trappist Product" and you wont find the the Trappsit Diamond anywhere on the label. The beer is pretty good. Its no Rochefort but it does have some very nice features. A great dark walnut color and nice smooth malt flavor. Head retention is ok but I think it could be better, and the beer does not do a very good job of hiding the strong alcohol presence in the taste.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2007 Batch K0584, 12:39. A very nice quad, a tad below the St. Bernies 12, Westv 12, above Roche 10 and 3Phil. Mmmmmm good. Poured a nice brown to amberish tinted brown with a pillowy soft and creamy head. The aroma was a good mix of some light and dark fruits. The flavor was nice caramel and chocolate over top of all sorts of complicated fruits (maybe some apples and bananas with figs and raisins). Spicing wasnt significant, and the mouthfeel was nice and creamy (nothing thin about my batch). Re-rate on draft at Half Moon, 12/07: Slightly less solid than my first great experience, but the caramel, light chocolate, and fruits were all present and this was enjoyable. A little flat and lacking any spicey zing to make it excellent or above a 4 rating.
Light nut brown color with a tall tan slightly rocky head. Oily, hints of prunes and dark corn syrup. Slight orange hoppiness. Dry and warm finish with a touch of coriander.

UPDATED: FEB 13, 2007 11.2 oz Bottle - 2000: Sampled at 7-years-old. This stuff has held up very well. Deep brownish amber pour with a creamy tan head. Fruity aroma, slightly vinous. Lots of plummy notes, grapes, and a touch of sweet fig. There were slight hints of oxidation in the flavor, but still robust. Vinous qualities, fruity and sweet with hints of grapes, berries, wood, and roasty toffee notes develop late. A nice, fruity Quadrupel.

Mondial de la Bière de Montréal; Sorryyyyyy, this beer is way overated. This beer is maybe good to wake up or good for hunting in the winter, but thats it. It smells like ham, it taste like ham. If you like strong alcohol like Gin, Whisky, then you will like this beer. Its better than piss beer, but way overated.

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2006 330ml bottle. Label says Koningshoeven. Pours a dark reddish brown with a thick white head. Aroma of apples, bananas, and yeast and malts. Creamy mouthfeel, tastes of fruit, malts, yeast, and a light touch of alcohol. Lingering taste of apples. Amazing beer.

Had it under the Koningshoven Quad label. Beer was a hazy medium yellow-amber color with an average-sized, frothy, off-white, mostly diminishing head. The aroma was malty with a light note of cookie and moderate toasted grain; moderate note of herbal hop; yeasty with a light note of dough and a moderate note of cellar; moderate note of spicy alchs and a trace of damp cardboard. The flavor was heavily sweet, lightly acidic and lightly bitter with a long, lightly-to-moderately bitter finish.  The body was light-to-medium, the texture was watery and the carbonation was lively. Light-to-moderate alcohol warmth.
A strong trappist ale indeed at 10% alcohol, yeasty and bitter, a good beer for the cold winter evenings up here in the Great White North.

Caramel color sets the tone for this beer.  Brownish head, some lacing.  Earthy, peachy, cane sugar aromas.  Kind of a muddle, until you taste it, when everything comes together.  Good bite of alcohol, lots of caramelly malts, molasses and pit fruit, and a sweet, but not so sweet, finish that lingers pleasantly.  A unique beer that retains a lot of its compelling natural ingredients.

Had in Holland..big head, cream coloured..bananna brandy dust smell...sweet delicous framed tangy flavourful taste....thick lacing...masked A+++....nice bitters....prunes,candy,sherry,choc,raisens...a good smooth full trappist.
<!-- br --><!-- br -->
rerate in houston,about 3-4 months later...orange rust colour...sweet fruit candi smell,great lacing of course...amazingly smooth for the 10%...and also very tasty, like a bitter piece of melon carameled brandy raisen snap.
again, very very good, the taste is like a ......secret spicy kiss from the girl next door....wicked!!!....this is what all trappist beers should do to you..!!!

Bottled.  Pours a slightly hazy red amber with a pillowy beige head.  Sweet (very sweet) malty aroma, vaguely of fruits.  Cloying taste, alcohol felt more in the throat than in the mouth, but its there, too.  Sticky and syrupy but less so than some Doppelbocks (Doppelböcke? ;) ) Ive had.  Not a big fan.

Caramel colored head. Really clings to the glass. The aroma is strong, slightly fruity, and not especially pleasant (...or unpleasant). I feel the same about the flavour - its intense but not ultimately rewarding. The alcohol does not overpower the mouth but it does the head.
My bottle is not called La Trappe, merely Konings Hoeven Quadrupel.
Clay bottle. Amber coloured with a medium off-white head. A bit too sweet. Notes of earth, wood and citrus. Also slightly yeasty and a bit too high carb for me.

Pours a dark golden heading towards amber color with very some tanish head.  Honey and alcohol dominate the aroma.  Very sweet candyish character.  Slightly fruity and very alcoholic.  Rich and smooth mouthfeel.  Tingly carbonation.  Just kind of so-so.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2007 This beer pours a deep amber color with a LARGE tan head.  The beer has a very floral aroma and flavor.  This beer is quite well crafted.  Kinda reminds me of what I would think a monastery would smell like if I had been to one.  Cheers!

Candy aroma but great. Amazingly tasty head. Has the alcohol in it but not in a way that is too much. This is one fantastic beer.  Would definitely buy again if I could find it. Had at Tapwerks in OK City.

Bottle: (Konings Hoeven Quadruple) 
Pours a  nice medium amber topped with a slow fading off white head.
Aroma was intensly vinous as soon as the cap was lifted,  and a little bit of felt marker as well.
Flavour is nice a fruity smooth start, raisin, faint sour cherry, with the alcohol asserting itself  in the finish.

Tap
Color - Dark / Brown
Head - Withe
Aroma - Fruit, hops, Malt
Flavor - Fruit, sweet, hops
very smooth with a very subtle alcohol flavor, which is good for a big beer.  This quad drank as smooth as silk and finish nicely, Ill buy this one again
UPDATED: APR 26, 2006  Bottle split with Stegosaurus. Pours  amber with a tan head. Aroma of caramel malt, spices, and alcohol. Flavor is  caramel, citrus, fruit. Not as good as i expected.

Poured a bright copper with a quickly disappearing off white head.  Very complex profile.  Banana is most noticable but raison, toffee, date, caramel, and some peach.  There is a significant hop presence for a belgian style beer, though i wouldnt call it bitter by any other standards.  Sweet, medium bodied palate and finish.
brown with medium head. Very warm from the alcohol and filling. Lively carbonation. Great long finish. Perhaps the best of the "la trappes".

Pours a dark copper and had a great looking off white head...that went away a little fast, but still some nice lacing.  Aroma is yeast, raisins, bananas, malt, and alcohol.  Taste is pleasant...spice and belgian yeast...alcohol, caramel, nuts, and vegetable oil.  Mouthfeel is kind of sticky and actually decently hot from the alcohol...which I usually dont get from quads much less belgians.  I dig this beer...and I think it saves the la trappe label from being too marginal.

This is an 04 that Ive had in the cellar for two years.  Nice half inch, light brown head, excellent lacing.  Color is dark brown.  Aroma of moderate malt, toasted, moderate yeast, dough, banana, vanilla, and cherry.  Initial flavor was moderately sweet with a long finish.  Really malty taste, but not as much cherry and vanilla that was indicated by the aroma.  There was a moderate a level of alcohol in the finish.  I think this could;ve stayed in the cellar for a coupld more year.

12 oz bottle.  Murky brown pour with medium sized floaties.  Very small head turned to nothing before I finished smelling.  Aromas of banana, honey, molassas, and roasted malts.  Very sweet flavors.  More banana, and molassas.  Alcohol warming on the finish.  Good Beer
Bottle.Orange colour. Very hazy beige head.Malt and alcohol aroma.weak spririt but mostly cellar flavour,Very nice beer.

very large, lasting light brown head. A very noticeable alcohol aroma and flavor which was prevalent in the finish. very aromatic with heavy maltiness and grape scents and flavors. If you like wine, and you like beer, meet your new best friend

Bottle.  Cherry/peach malt and medicinal alcohol aroma.  Cloudy orange-brown color with moderate head.  Sweet apple-peach flavor with fairly strong alchohol and bitter finish.  A tad rough but overall nice.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2009 Pours a hazy amber in color with a quarter-inch off-white head that quickly fizzes away. VeryBelgian aroma: yeast, fruit, sweet malts, a slight sourness. Flavor is sweet malt, apricot, yeast, and banana bread with a warm alcohol burn. Fizzy mouthfeel due to high carbonation. Very flavorful, very strong - almost a whiskey-like burn as it goes down. A great beer.

Enormous offwhite creamy head with some larger bubbles. Hazy amber body. Intense sweet aroma with marzipan-like notes, also some fruit and alcohol. Sweet, fruity, spicy taste with somewhat musty notes and lots of alcohol warmth. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2007 Pours a dark brandy copper color with a full, semi creamy froth.  Hangtime is superb w/ full, sticky residual lacing. Minimal residual effers in the glass, almost flat by sight. Aroma is mild w/ dried dark fruits and Belgian granite. Full nectar w/ ample residual effers that only reveal themselves on the palate. Quite explosive. Flavors of cherry, fig, raison, plum, apricot, kiwi, and a light push toward rootbeer. Other nuances of tobbacco and leather. The sweetness factor is moderate yet gets a lending hand from the tart kiwi for balance. The alcohol is mildly noticable. Finish is long with w/ a moderate sweetness and a slight tartness that lingers. Overall: an interesting specimen worthy of mention. Highly recommended.

Dark amber colored, medium beige head. Banana, fruits, mild spices and caramel in aroma, banana fits here well. Medium to full bodied. Banana, fruits, mild spices and alcohol in flavor, banana dominates. Strong sweetness in aftertaste.

This beer introduces itself with a hearty aroma consisting of yeast, malt, and wheat.  It is a copper colored solution with a thick cream colored head and heavy lacing.  This moderately thick beer has a full taste that is smooth and mildly sweet.  This beer has a gentle hint of orange as it first enters the mouth then the flavors of wheat, yeast, and caramel proceed to entice the palate.  A mild biscuit flavor can be detected right before this beer fades smoothly away to leave a nice caramel taste lingering in the throat.

Deep copper-coloured with a huge, off-white head, leaving lacing. Wonderfully strong, sweet caramel and fruity aroma. Some liquorice. Flavour start sweet with lots of caramel and caramel, but is balanced towards the middle by good, spicy (and somewhat earthy) hop bitterness. Dry and long, earthy finish. It is wonderful as a young beer (and has it become even more complex lately?), but gets irresistable after 5 years careful aging. The rating is for the young beer.

Bottle at the Upper Campfield Market Hall, Manchester 24/01/2002
Mid brown coloured and very strong in alcohol. Sweet and rich on the palate. Warming finish.

Heavy malty aroma reminds me of apples, pears, and raisins with a little bit of yeast. Huge rocky white head on top of a mostly clear brown beer. Very sweet stuff. Apples and raisins continue into the flavor. Creamier mouthfeel than a lot of the Quads I have had. Carbonation is somewhat soft compared to the size of the head. Very nice.

"Batch K0584, 12:39. wow was i surprised. Poured a nice medium brown, nice fluffy head. Aroma was fruity and malty. Flavor was of caramel and fruits some chocolate mabye. What i was surprised about the most was the creamy mouthfeel. Nice Nice beer."

UPDATED: JAN 16, 2009 (750 mL bottle) My first ever rating, so I thought it would be appropriate to rate the first Belgian I ever had.  Pours a nice deep golden brown, slightly hazy with noticeable sediment.  Large frothy head, dissipates slowly.  Aroma is light bread, moderately yeasty.  Nice perfumey hops with a hint grapefruit.  Initial flavor is a sweet banana clove almost like a good Hefe finishes.  Mouth feel is smooth, slightly oily,  with moderate carbonation.  Hides the alcohol VERY well. Left a bit of a metallic taste in my mouth after a minute or two.  Overall its pretty much your standard Quad, not necessarily amazing but a good solid beer.

(corked and caged bottle - 750 ml) Dark ruby pour with not much of carbonation and a lot of floating sediment. Aroma is lots of malt with hints of raisins, apple cider and some alcohol. Taste begins with a sweet and malty flavor that goes quickly to a sweet middle with hints of apples, raisins and cherries and a very evident alcohol presence at the end. Loads of sweet malts and dark fruits throughout. Medium bodied with lots of sweetness and alcohol. Not too bad.

Massive rocky tan head on a deep brown body.  Fruit and malt aroma.  This clean and malty with raisin and brown sugar notes.  Hop bitterness was indeed present but the finish was dominated by alcohol.

750 ml bottle.  The first pour of this quad poured up an absolutely beautiful crystal clear dark amber into my snifter.  The second pour from the bottle had the same color, but was very cloudy as the yeast had mixed in.  Both pours had an inch worths of a creamy white head that lasted a good while and settled into a thin foam for the entire glass.  There was a speckled lacing on the glass.  It is highly carbonated and feels light on the palate.  The aroma is of candied fruits and spice while the 10% ABV makes itself known.  I find this very tasty and refreshing.  I was expecting a sweet taste that Ive found in other quads, but it wasnt here.  There is in fact a slight sour bite to this guy.  I like it and until I find something better this is my Quad of choice.  I hope to find it on-tap somewhere.

Muddy brown with nearly no head.  Aroma of apples, grapes, brown sugar, and rum.  Quite fruity flavor - apple and pear predominately.  A bit of tartness with some spiciness which is vaguely like ginger to me.  Aside from the slight hint of rum in the nose, i found the alcohol to be quite well masked in this.

UPDATED: MAR 4, 2006 12 oz bottle.  Medium light brown head settles into pocked lily pads with splotchy lacing.  Fine, active bubbles.  Aroma of figs, raisins, whole wheat bread, porcini mushrooms and melon.  Tastes of creamy leather, raisins and slivovitz (plum brandy).  Medium carb but a tad watery for a quad.  Dry finish with moderate alcohol.
On tap 1-year-old. Pours a beautiful, clear nutty brown. Sweet and sour. Lots of fruit... lots of apple aromas. Smooth CO2 mouthfeel. Also notes of alcohol warming all the way down.

Bottle from Tapwerks in OKC. served ice cold. Poured orange/amber with a medium beige head. Light varnish aroma with some black walnuts poking through. Quite the full flavored beer with a moderate blast of alcohol. Walnuts and a little fruit- peach and apricot- in the taste. Decent.

Bottle from Jims Foodmart - Houghton, MI Enjoyed warm from a new flask at hockey game. Pours a opalescent brown pearl, with a frothy tan head. Soapy. Aroma of pears, figs and a hint of chocolate. Flavor is rich with sherried raisins, port and candy. But then searing alchol that bites pretty heavily. The flavor has some rich bready spice, but it gets washed away quickly by brandy alchol. Shows its heat just a little too much. Finish is sweet and caramel, with more alcohol. But then, thats why the beer was put in a flask.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 Pours a hazy dark amber with a thin, fully receding light tan head. Aroma of phenolic with notes of apples, apricots, plums, toffee, Taste is sweet and yeasty with notes of plums, cherries, toffee, and alcohol. Mouthfeel is full bodied and sticky with lush carbonation. A bit too alcoholic and medicinal. Too rough around the edges, this might be the worst of the Trappist breweries.

Bottle. Cloudy russett colour wiwth thin white head. Heavy candy sugar aroma with some spice and choc. Quite good flavour with sweetness balanced by thick smack of hops. Fine finish with more candy sugar/toffee. I think I was expecting something a bit better. Bit boiled sweety.

Pours a hazy brown/orange color, great creamy head the entire time. First sip its very sweet, lots of sugar, fruits and a big alcohol kick. The alcohol really seemed to overpower this beer, and the sweetness was about all that was there other than the alcohol, not bad, but not my style to drink all the time.

Weird thoughts passed my mind as I sipped this. Unbeknown to myself the origin of these visions of summer and winter cascading over each other in images as if it was slide night and the pictures were in fast forward. It wasnt a complex brew by all means, but the time involved in drinking a bottle, it seemed, would transcend me beyond my evening of throwing a ball to my three dogs. Poured into a chalice at just on cool, I half expected a dark brew as it appeared through the brown glass, but was greeted with a fiery bronze ale, with very fine lines of bubbles flitting up to surface beneath a thin, rocky white layer of whipped cream. Head held its ground for the length to trail a fine lace down the glass. Rich and sharp, ripe fruits on the nose with apricots, oranges and strawberries. Candi sugar offers a sweeter edge whilst a good dose of peppery, spicy hops give it some needed bounce. Juicy citric fruits dominate the palate with undertones of peaches, biscuity malts, light earthy and spicy hops, and a little doughy yeast. Medium bodied and smooth as silk with very soft carbonation giving the flavours a nice roundness. Alcohol was close to non-existent for a beer of such strength offering only a light warmth in the swallow. Creamy finish has more fruits and a very gentle tangy astringency, with a long quenching citrus aftertaste. Its only flaw was a lightly metallic edge that grew near to the end, about the time I awoke from my weird trance. This was a lovely and unique beer that what it lacked in complexity, it just made up for in control and balance. Absolutely delicious, another bottle and Ill be back in the happy space. (30cL, BBE 06/08, Intl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)

Looks good - crimson, clear and a nice head. Aroma reminded me distinctly of a weizen - cloves and caramelised bananas. Aventinus! Some figs, sultanas, rich malt, muesli, orange rind. Loads of fig flavour, Xmas cake, earthy, spicy, soft maltiness with quite a bit of alcohol. Some grainy brown bread in the middle there. Nice mouthfeel, marred a little by the alcohol. This was obviously in very good nick - but is it not bottle-conditioned? I might have to rethink cellaring a bottle... I certainly didnt expect to like this as much as I did. Yum!

11.2 oz bottle is few years old. No date given. From a 4 pack that had the blonde, dubbel, triple, and a nice trappist glass. Foggy, light brown. Small, tan head quickly disappears. Aroma of dark fruits, caramel/toffee, rich malt, yeast, candi sugar, anise. Flavor matches the aroma up front, then transforms to dry, roasty, slightly bitter alcohol. Finish is yeasty alcohol. Aftertaste is a combination of the two phases with a bittersweet licorice flavor standing out. Full, creamy body. Rather tame for what it is. Nothing about this brew is looking to stop you from dinking it in excessive quantity. Way too easy to drink. Probably 12% by now and alcohol is only detectable in the finish.  Very nice beer.

En lisant la discription commercial (oui, je li langlais mais je lécris mal), il cite que cest une bonne bière pour lhiver. Donc, moi qui vie au Québec et que je lai eu à Noël 2004, ils ont raison. Cette bière chaleureuse, épicé, alcoolisé, lhiver nest pas si pire que ça avec cette bière.

orange amber color with a small off white head.  aroma of alcohol and dark fruits and spices.  full bodied.  spices and alcohol in flavor.  very fizzy mouthfeel.  i cant get in to any of the beers from this brewer.  they are consistently too sweet and alcoholic.

Bottled. Dark reddish amber colour, mediumsized beige head. Raisins, sweet malts and caramel in aroma, with hints of alcohol. Flavour is raisins, sweet malts, fruits and caramellish. Alcohol also present here. A very complex brew, with sweet malts and hops coming clearer in aftertaste. Wellbalanced, but still has a bit too strong sting of alcohol in it.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2006 My recent trip to Amsterdam was the occasion for my first encounter with Dutch beer. As a start, I decided I couldnt go wrong with La Trappes Quadrupel - and I was right. The friendly barman at In de Wildeman poured it in its proper glass producing a beautiful dark brownish red body, reminding of wet cherry wood. The creamy puff of light beige foam slowly descended to a thin cap, leaving incredibly sticky lacing on all sides. In the nose, dusty dark chocolate, figs and plums immediately appear suggesting the familiar trappist combination. However, other lighter notes are also prominent: caramel, berries, cream and particularly pear which was even more emphasized as the beer warmed. A sweet and inviting aroma. On the tongue, Irish creme, cherries, caramel, apple, pear, coffee and slight bitter malt flavor are the protagonists. Again pear is very much the key element, which I distinctly enjoyed as it conjures up the delicious desert, Poire Belle-Hélène. I found the palate a bit overcarbonated but the finish is ultra creamy which makes up for that small annoyance. Some time after the swallow a surprising and unmistakable marron glacé flavor materializes on the tongue. Just wait for it. Overall, an outstanding effort; but I must warn you: do not drink it under 12°C!

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2007 pours an amberish light brown color with a small  tan foamy head, aroma of caramel malt, belgian spices and alcohol, flavor is also caramel-like with citrusy dark fruits present, decent body, good brew.

330 ml bottle.  Banana aroma.  Low carbonation, the bubbles are fine.  Almost no head.  Great tasting.  Caramel like tasting.  Strong alchool taste but enjoyable.  Personnaly, I prefer the tripel than this one but would drink again !!
Bottle. Off-white head. Orange unclear body.  Aroma of black berries. Rather spicy flavor with rounded alcohol taste, yet still pleasant for such a strong beer. .

Bottle, BB "I184"??  Poured a deep, murky brown with a fizzy, quickly-dissipating beige head (uh-oh).  Deep, dark fruits abound in the aroma (plums & dates), rounded off by some Belgian yeast, alcohol, and spices.  Flavors followed the aroma well, with the fruits and alcohol leaving some sticky resin behind some teeth.  Alcohol was a tad bright on the tip of the tongue and at the finish.  Dark fruit and spices joined the hotter-than-necessary alcohol at the finish.  Couldve used better balance.

(bottle) Hazy ruby amber colour with a big and stable tanned foamy head. Yeasty-fruity bubblegum aroma with peppery spice. Sweet flavour, full bodied, almost fizzy carbonation. Initially sweet malty, fruity (oranges, plums) and caramel. Sweet malty, spicy (coriander) finish with notes of herbal hops. I had to sneeze more than 50 times after a few sips (dry hopping ?  I´m very allergic to hops).

30 cl bottle. Amber colour with a small head. Aroma of candy, sugar, caramel and yeast. Nice complex flavour of sweetness, sugar and some indefinable spice, but it turns out very alcoholic at the end.

fresh 30cl bottle. copper body with a small white head which disapates quickly. Carmely smell with a hint of alcohol. The alchol shocked me when if first hit my tongue, but it quickly settled down. Sweet malt flavor with some yeastiness. Suprising thin for a quad. Bought a sixer, but it only takes one of these to make me warm and happy. Will try the others after some time in the cellar and update acordingly.

Bottle. Pours a cloudy burnt orange with fading white head. The aroma is very caramely with burnt sugar, toast, some plum, and some faint, sweetish yeast. The aroma has lots of burnt sugar as well, and quite a good sum of prune. The finish has some ashy hops, but the dryness balances the richness pretty well. There is, of course, some yeast in there, too, and not as much alcohol taste as it seems there should be for a 10%abv. I like this.

UPDATED: MAY 18, 2006 I had a different bottle, other disign.
Sweet smell like candy bitter aftartaste, lots of yeast, a shame that the only dutch trappistenbier is not my taste, to everwalming full and alcohol.
RE-RATE, 5-18-2006: used to be 2.9 had a wrong temprature ore bottle, now its much better,.. less overwalming and now I can fint the beauty in thise one.
Brown colour, very slightly hazy, huge head. A sweet, bready aroma with, I think, a little peach and some yeast.  Sweet taste of malt and alcohol. Warming, gentle, and very, very wonderful.

Bottle: Poured a dark black color ale with a huge foamy head with great retention. Aroma of cookie dough, which seems to be part of all beer from this brewery and is very enjoyable. Taste is also comprised of sweet malt reminiscent of cookie dough with some dry figs. Body could be more full and alcohol was well hidden. Still missing a little something to match the other great beer from this style thought.

This stuff is like drinking a liquid Krispy Creme Donut with Alcohol!  This stuff will rock your world.  A very tasty, sweet, bready, yeasty, fruity, honey-like quad.  Nice job on this beer.  I can only drink one tho.  And thats OK.

Wow.  A Tilburger!  I didnt know.  Ive got a special place in my heart for this now.  Plus, this is great beer.  Sweet green apple orchard on the nose.  Big head and pours red brown.  Tastes of alcohol, malt, and that delicious apple.  Medium finish with some malt showing through.  Thoroughly enjoyable.  There is a reason the quadrupel style rules the ratings.

Good size, tightly beaded, off-white head on top of a reddy amber body. Yeasty nose of broth and then some caramel. Velvety smooth but thick mouthfeel with warming alcohol and rich fruit, I also get some orange, prunes, spice, caramel and honey. Good presentation, even better aroma and the flavour is full bodied, a little complex but seems very sessionable. Just thin enough not to be cloying. Enjoyed this! Cheers!

Dark amber ale with orange hues, and a thin white head. Aroma of caramel, cloves, and alcohol. In mouth, sweet caramel malt with notes of coriander, and alcohol warmth wafting through. Bottle enjoyed at Pub Italia, 7.95$

Beautiful to look at: deep orange amber with a huge pillowy tan head. Caramelized banana, vanilla, cloves, and oak wood aromas. A bit fizzy with the alcohol immediate and warming. Pleasant flavours of sweet malt, toasted wheat, caramel and yeast. This was okay, but the sweetness and the alcohol made it feel cloying toward the end. I think maybe this isnt my favourite style, but I appreciate the craftsmanship.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: Bottle: Orangish amber, vibrant yet with floaters, large fine bubbled head, lovely lacing, strong carbonation.   For as old as this is, I am amazed as to how well this one looked.   Yeasty/bready aroma, pale fruit skin, and even a bit of dark pitted fruit on the nose.   Taste of heavy bread, fairly sweet, pale fruit skin to start, slight raisin/date/plum on the backside.   Not very heavy like other examples, light, but big in body and very well rounded and smooth.   Clean as well.   Sweet exit, with a slight alcohol warming that lingers.   Lighter than other examples, but it is still great stuff! &nbsp Thanks to Kevin of Bottleworks for sharing this one.

Bottle Via trade with afterexile.  Pours a clear dark mahogany color with a frothy ivory head.  Aromas of yeast, bananas, cookie dough, licorice and plums.   Big dark fruit notes in this one, mostly raisins.  Sweet and malty.  Caramel and spice with a bit of a licorice note.  Although the alcohol is present, its masked fantastically.

Pours a beautiful hazy brown amber color with a small white head.  Aroma is full of rich spices,bananas,nutmeg,plums and malts.  Taste is carbonated slightly with hints of bittersweet spices, especially nutmeg,plums,bananas and malts.  Excellent beer and very rich and satisfying.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2006 Pours a slightly hazy dark orange/brown color with a big cream colored, frothy and long lasting head that leaves a huge gorgeous lacing and film.
Aroma is yeasty and malty with notes of prunes, raisins, molasses, apricots and overripe berries. Delicately spiced. I can even fell some hops in the form of a resinous hint. Incredible development with warming. Complex. 
Delicious flavor, sweet with a great alcoholic kick and a semi-bitter finish. There are touches of liquor and ripe fruits like peaches and plums accompanied with caramel. Everything is well-balanced. I guess this heavenly brew would age well also.
Smooth velvety palate. Creamy texture. Carbonation is almost unnoticeable. The wonderful aftertaste lasts for long after a pleasant alcoholic finish. My body just feels warm and relaxed now. What an exquisite and criminally underrated beer!

The last of the beers I have from the Konings Hoeven gift set. Pours a nice dark orange with decent head. Yummy malty yeast aroma with tones of banana and a touch of alcohol. Flavor is fruity with notes of dark cherry, raisin, banana bread...almost like rum. A balancing finish with just enough spice and alcohol to compliment the sweet. Fizzy on the tongue and coats the mouth and throat with flavors for a moment. Glad I saved this one for last from the gift set as it seems to be the best of the four brews.

Mahogany colour with a good sized head. Aroma of fruit, oak and malt, very pleasant. Fair degree of carbonation notable in the taste, along with alcohol, but it is dominated by a fine sweet, caramelly flavour. Also hints of banana, plum, raisin. Malty of course. Very nice and easy drinking, perhaps not the awesome cacophony of flavours in Westy 12 and some other quads, but superb nonetheless.
Amber colour with a small light brown short lasting head. Aroma of malt and fruits. good bitter sweet balance, but the finish is slightly alcoholic.

This is a very pleseant beer to drink.
You dont get the 10% hit, its too easy drinking for that, which makes it kinda dangerous!  :)

Bottle: Hazy, amber coloured, thin, firm head, sticking to the glass; sweet, malty, bit yeasty (traces of turpentine ?) and fruity (raisins) nose;sweet flavour, malty body; slightly bitter and sweet finish; creamy mouthfeel; very well hidden alcohol, well balanced and astonishingly well quaffable. Sweet, but not cloying...............

Aroma:good caramel aroma,alcohol,dark fruit.....
Appearance:dark amber brown very good head...
Flavor:strong alcohol,dark fruit,nutsligh caramel........

Had several of these in my various European sojourns but never rated one. Pours a medium hazy mahogany amber with a medium size short lasting beige yellow head. Aromatic dried stone fruit and raisins, musty cellar and a touch of shoe polish and butterscotch aroma. Medium smooth, thinnish bodied lowish carb palate. Plenty of fruity malt sweetness and medium low bitterness start quickly transiting to a strange celeriac bitter and faint metallic after taste. Interesting enough but doesnt really rate too well up against the big named quads. Alcohol also comes through perhaps too easily at the end. Many thanks to Kook for providing this one.

I really didnt mean to drinki this tonite, as i ment to share it with pauline, however i dont think shell know until she reads this in which case i may have another by then, hehe. Aroma is dominated by dark fruits and as my work mate who only ever drinks lager, apricots play a part too, obviously malt and other complex things come in for the quadness. Taste is very similar with again the apricots having thier say in the matter, good not to sweet finish. This is without doubt the weakest and most lacking in character of quads iv had, in sayign that this is a seriously good beer, though not the deep colour i would want, keeps good head. I wonder if aging would actuially help this fellow, i think he may actually be best fresh.
A nice malty aroma with a balance of hops.  The color is a nice golden with an off white head.  Nice flavor balance of caramel sweetness and hops.

750. Pours a light brown color with a fizzy white head. Nose is funky and stale, like old gym socks. Taste is also kinda funky, makes me cringe and wince. Notes of some caramel, hints of yeast and malt.
excellent quad, but not as good as Three Philosophers. MIlder and less complex, with a gentle rolling head effect rather than knocking your socks off.

Pours a very cloudy orange with decent though thin head. Aroma is a little nutty, cherry and plum, a bit of spice. Shines in the flavor though, with excellent nuttiness, sweet syrup, cinnamon. Warming, and a wonderful beer to lick your lips after sipping for a bit of sweetness (even better to make out with your woman ;)
Clear dark amber with nice beige head. Pistache, toffee and almond in the aroma. Very smooth syrapy texture. Flavour is complex but balanced containig caramel, licorice and chocolate.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2012 Bronze appearance. Medium off-white lasting head. The aroma is excellent. A flavor of apples, grapes, and oranges. The alcohol is just right balanced. Some bitter and dry finish. A complex and likeable trappist style beer.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2005 August 2001 bottle. Poperinge had a porcelain/ceramic corked 16oz bottle in his cellar. Even empty it is a heavy bottle. Well carbonated with very tiny bubbles that maintain a thin light brown head. Barley wine aroma with some toffee and alcohol. Flavour is caramel, toffee and a touch of raisin and apple. A light alcohol burn in the finish.
Bottle from Beers of Europe. Dark Amber. Aroma of rich malts, chocolate, raisin, caramel, spice, yeast. Creamy body with soft finish. Pleasantly enjoyable.

30 cl bottle, bbe Feb 08. Light brown / dark reddish with a slight haze. Scarce sediment and pearling, thin frothy head. Sweetish, perfumed aroma with a nutty touch. Sweetish, abundant taste with banana and a long, bone dry, uncompromisingly bitter aftertaste. Alcohol not really hidden. Full, smooth palate leaving astringent dryness. In days past, the trappist order used to believe solely in God; now they seem to rely quite a lot on Bavaria NV, too.

11.2 oz bottle. Pours a great looking amber with an off-white thick fluffy head. Aroma of caramel and fruit, with a bitter in the aroma as well. Taste is fruity but dry, with a slight bitter hop aftertaste. After a few sips, my belly is warm from the alcohol. Its almost as if its... not done yet. Still a bit brash in the taste. Palate is just average, nothing exceptional. Nowhere near the almost-religious experience I had with St Bernardus Abt 12.
user_location: Waco (Buckle of the Bible Belt), Texas, USA

text: Big whiff of candy sugar, alcohol and what smells like artifical sweetner. Deep amber with a thick two finger head. Alcohol followed by more of the chemical sweetness I find in about half the bottles I try of this. I think it is newer bottles that taste this way cause the better samples I have had have come from shops with low turnover. Fruit mash, some caramel notes, yeast and riasins are present as well, but often that flavor is dominated by that chemical sweetness.
large off-white lasting head, brown-amber colour, some light malts, toasted aroma, few hops. Diverse aroma. Creamy texture, light bitter finish, bit sweet alcoholic, Heavy. Enjoyable!

Bottle (330ml).  At Pub Italia, Ottawa.  Poured ruby-copper with a clear small off-white head.  Aroma very strong of aroma esters, sweet malt - got that "Popeye candy cigarette" character again - losts of yeast and alcohol on warming.  Taste of mild sweet citrus & banana malt, raisins and apple - stronger on warming - and a touch of hops - oh, wait, here comes the alcohol.  Palate is average bodied, quite complex as it warms up.  Oveall good, if not very good, but not great - too much banana and alcohol for my taste.

Sampled from bottle. Pours a clear mahogany with a lasting tan head and intricate lacing. Aroma is not overwhelming and has notes of citrus fruits and molasses. Flavor is semi-sweet with a dry finish. Raisins, chocolate malt, and black pepper. Its full body is hidden a bit by heavy carbonation (but not gassy). Alcohol is masterfully hidden in this complex, but easy to drink ale.

11.2oz. bottle. Dark orange color with a thick tan head. Sweet aroma of malt, raisins and yeast. Flavor of sweet malt,
dried fruits and bread with a noticeable alcohol finish. Full bodied with a creamy texture.

11.2 fl oz bottle. Koningshoeven label, served in Koningshoeven glass. Poured a deep orange-brown shade. Had a very light haze. Retained a small layer of sticky tan head, very tight small bubbles. Sweet aroma, cookie-like, malty. Aroma becomes more fruity/estery as it warms up (mild banana-bread note?) Flavour revealed dark sweet malts, some alcoholic tang noticable. Lasting malty finish with some bitterness, slight dryness and alcohol warming. Superb drinkability, very smooth palate, mild carbonation, full mouthfeel. Alcohol never becomes intrustive. Rating #400.
[bottle from beers of europe] pours dark brown with a dense tan head. rich sweet aroma, smells of chocolate, toffee, cherrys, apple, nutmeg. good body with a long sweet finish.

14 Jun 2005 - Light hop and low malt aroma, with not much fruit or complexity.  Clear light brown-orange colour, ordinary head but good lacing.  Simple malt and sweet finish.  Big bitterness, with a lingering light mouthfeel
wow, this one is smooth...  bottle disappeared too quickly.  clean, tart & fruity.  will need to have another to savor the flavor before I can comment further, this was really good...

A common wisdom in Belgian is that foreign beer is crap. A second common wisdom is that the worst foreign beer is produced in Holland. The fact this beer is a Dutch trappist seemed a strange contradiction, but this beer exceeds all expectations.
It has a beautiful amber color, with lots of little acid bubbles and a smooth off-white head. A well mixed aroma, with toffee, chocolat, raisin, alcohol, ginger and a little citrus and strawberry. Creamy and full mouthfeel, very well balanced between bitter and sweetness, both fruity and malty, with subtle spicing. Sampled together with a Rochefort 10, this beer is clearly better balanced and has a more softer mouthfeeling. The finish is very sticky, with more malty tones. Together with St-Bernardus, this beer will be my preferred alternative to the sold out Westvleteren.

330 ml bottle.  Ruby-orange tinted inside a fairly light brown coloured beer.  Thick, stable tan head.  Some floaties in there, but not a lot.  Massive plummy aroma, clove and nutmeg.  Aroma gets a bit spicier as it warms up.  Flavour is very fruity, cherry, plum, along with a big bready malt backbone.  Light toast towards the finish.  Soft spice with a touch of pepper.  Warming finish.  Nice balance.

Translucent and magnifying bronze with a copiously foamy, tan-to-grey head.  Aroma is nice and sweet, comprised of ginger, cinnamon, cloves, nutmeg, apple pie, golden raisins, candi sugar, and the slightest trace of strawberry crème.  Flavor unfolds in a consequential manner.  Toffee, chocolate, light figs, caramel-dipped golden delicious apples and a prevailing candi sweetness.  Excellent assertive spicing, bundling generous handfuls of ginger, nutmeg and cinnamon at one time and dashing each composition with anise and cocoa powder.  Sweetened profile envelops elements of brown sugar crumble and maple ribbons, and theres nothing that can shake this sweetness, which seems to exponentially increase with each sip.  Medium bodied and dry at times.  Finishes like a seasonal cinnamon spice ice cream, some recently fallen leaves and a note of earthen tobacco, which is inevitably overcome by a humming sweetness, gingerly beckoning all other elements to fade into the night.

330ml bottle served in my La Chouffe tulip: Nearly ruby in color with a long lasting off-white frothy head and outstanding lace. The  nose detects aromas of candi sugar, juniper berry, cardamom, dates, ripened apple, earthy hops and a touch of barnyard yeast ester. The taste starts as expected with lots of sweetness up front but at no point does it go over the top. I get a lot of ripe fruit and balanced spice in midesection and finished off with some surprising bitterness and even a hint of oak. The feel is lush and sticky, but again it is not over top top. It is warming of course and more than one bottle could be too much. I like this and glad to have a few more in the cellar. Yummy!

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2005 Lighter brownish red body with almost no head. Aroma is malty. Raisins and plums with some alcohol. Unfortunately, theres that basement feeling like their other beers that I cant stand. Flavor luckily lost the basement part and was an enjoyable Quadrupel. Add in caramel too. Nothing huge like Rochefort but still sweet, complex and enjoyable.
Amber appearance and poured with a big head. Quite sweet with a very dominating alcohol presence as you would expect. Pleasant but a bit too heavy for me.

(Bottle 30 cl) Dark amber colour which hazes if you pour the abundant sediment. Fairly small head, but it sticks to the glass. Lovely aroma of figs. Sweetish and extremely potent with lovely, fruity ale-esters. Notes of chocolate, nuts, figs, dates, caramel - all the goodies. Lovely beer. 311002

Pours dark brown with nice beige head that fades quickly. Aroma is full of over-ripe fruit and spices. Although a little musty and subdued, very nice. Flavor is all sweet malt up front with some apple and banana throught the middle. Huge alcohol kick at the end is killing this for me. Overall takes a hit from the alcohol.

In the 750 ml bottle from Gomers. Floral aroma and flavor. Dark Brown amber in color. The head was faint and did not last long. Thick, syrupy, and chewey. Smooth palate without a strong alcohol burn. Not as awesome as I had hoped, but good. I think the triple from this brewery is best.

The bottle poured a dark amber or light brown liquid with a thin beige creamy head. The head did not last long and left no lacing. The aroma consisted of sweet ripe fruit and spices with notable alcohol spiciness. The body was full with a sharpness due to ample carbonation and the texture was smooth. The flavor starts off sweet malt and matures showing off the fruit and spices. The finish is long lasting, sweet with almost no hop character and an ample alcohol notes that make your ears warm.

I heard this is no longer being made, glad to have the chance to try this. Pours a light amber with lots of little floaties like most quads seem to have, almost impossible sometimes to get a perfect clean pour. Sweet caramel apple flavor with tons of estery spice. Very well carbonated to keep it from being overly heavy and the carbonation really brings the spices to life.

Less complex taste then you would expect from a quadrupel but a nice drink nonetheless.  Quick finish with hints of caramel, cereal, red, hazy, aminimal head, light sweetness, lightly bitter, lightly sour, medium body, slick feel, average carbonation

Tap at Delaneys in New Haven.  Proper glassware!  Yeah Delaneys!  Has that definite Belgian yeasty aroma, but also corriander, clove, vanilla, (green?) raisin and other light fruits (banana, orange peel) and just a hint of rum.  It looked gorgeous in its glass, decent head sat atop a somewhat hazy orange body.  First sip is fruity and sweet, and you cant really detect the alcohol at this point (dangerous)  As it warms, it becomes a bit more astringent, but thats nicely balanced by your tongue going numb.  It finishes sweet and smooth with a slight dryness as it glides down your throat.  Compared to other belgians, the aroma and flavor are a little light, but its still an excellent beer.

Bottle.  A good head with generous bubbles, the body has an amber clear color.  The alcohol is evident in the aroma, some spices, coriander, hops, orange peel.  The taste is rich and round with well concealed alcohol. Balanced sweetness.

Lable as Koningshoeven.  75cl bottle.  Some loose floaters, a few chunky lazy bubbles jumping...amber/brown...no real head, but some clinging lace.  Aroma slight moist cork.musty, definite plum, raisin, grape, leather, slight alcohol behind it, but pleasing overall.  Full, sweet body w/o obvious thickness...lingering...Flavor is set off by the sweet finish, and highlighted by the dark fruits & alcohol...madeira to an extent...complex sweetness a bit of clove and vanilla begins to come out in the nose now...and the sweetness is just right...not too much or too thick.  Excellant beer.  Late night sipper, elegant.

Orangy red with creamy off white head.  Aroma has a bit of a fingernail polish character then some nice malts.  Flavor is very malty and smooth with some great sweetness and roasty flavor.  Large robust complex flavors.   Bananna in the flavor and aroma.
Sweet malt aroma with hops. Clear light red colour with fair head and lacing. Strong spitirus malt flavour. Smooth palate.

yummy, ive had this many times before i rated beer, always a pleasure. aroma: fruity(pineapple, peach, citrus and more), rum, raisins, plum, lots of esters. taste: sweet, bit bitter, rum, raisin, bit dark chocolate, fruity, bit yeasty. finish is very long and rum lingers on. mf is full with good carbonation. very very good, very very complex!   750ml crock costs me 3,15 euro haha.

More my style.  In the strength of other trappist beers.   Nice brown amber color with the smooth caramel strong creamy taste of brother brown ales but doesnt have a signature like a Rochefort or Westvleteren.  

Available at Downtown Wine & Spirits in Somerville, MA

poured a dark amber color with a big head that dissapated quick but did lace up on th esides.Smells and tastes fruity.This was a step up from the triple.dark fruits like figs and raisains surround my buds.warming going down but the alcohol was hidden well.Very clean finish. I am glad i enjoyed this expierence.

2001 vintage. This dark amber ale poured with a short tan head that dissipated quickly, eliciting a pleasant fruity aroma. The flavor is very full -  fruity, creamy and slightly carbonated. Aging has caused the flavor to be richer and more mellow than a fresh bottle I had recently.

The aroma is huge - peach, bubble gum , banana and sweet candy have a great and interesting interplay.  The body is full and nicely chewy.  Candied plums and figs dominate the body - which is velvety.  Great stuff.

Bottled (BB 06/2007)
Dark red with decent brownish head. Aroma  has caramel malts, soil and raisins. Fully-bodied. Liquerish sweetness bursts into your mouth when you first zip this. Alcoholic, sweetish with plums dominating. Some earthy notes also in the flavor. Hops ride into the scene in the finish. Good stuff, but no so complex than the best trappist Abts.

A Mes rate:
What a crrrracker! This one is a regular purchase for me. This more than any other beer I have tried so far has an aroma that says "Im going to get you drunk!" Dark amber body topped with a nice even head that is sadly gone a little too soon but no matter, it leaves a good coverage that lasts for the rest of the glass. Lots of different fruits in the nose  but what really gets me is something that I can only describe as reminding me of Amyl Nitrate. I swear you could loose yourself just smelling this stuff. Typical quad with just a bit of something extra. Mouthfeel is medium bodied but verging on the full side and I must say the palate is great. The swoosh of sweetness at the back of your mouth at the finish is great. Fantastic flavour with quite a lot to get excited about! Bananas, pineapples, apples and a bit of sweetness but just the right amount is the order of the day. Finish is briefly bitter then almost instantly gently sweet and lengthy. Complex and well balanced pretty damn good all round.

Bubblegum, raisins, figs, dates, brown sugar and rich, thick velvety malts in the enticing aroma.  Opaque amber-brown with decent, fine-bubbled, tan head that recedes to a lasting cover.  Some yeast/protein in suspension.  Fruit and bubblegum esters are pervasive with some toasty, bready and caramel malt flavours.  Mild peppery spiciness in the finish along with a soft touch of alcohol and very low bitterness.  Full bodied in the mouth with a creamy texture and gentle carbonation that becomes somewhat syrupy over time.  Light alcohol warming.  Wide tulip, cellar temp. Bottle (June, 2005).  Thanks to both ClarkVV and radiomgb who each brought me a bottle of this at the Mondial gathering.  Cheers, guys!

04 bottle. Pours dark amber with dark red hints.  Nice fruity aroma, plums and sweet matly sugars and peppery Belgian yeast.  More of the same in with flavor, but now I picked up raisins and prunes and plums.  Body was a bit thin for a quad tho.

Pours brown with healthy carbonation and a thin tan head.  Smells very fruity with cherries, apples, oranges, coriander, raisins and grapes present.  taste is sweet with brown sugar, pepper, cinnamon, raisons, prunes, apples, caramel and toffee present.  Sweet slightly alcoholic finish.

Bottle: #900.  Aroma is very fruity with some candy sugar and apple.   Pours a transparent copper with a small white head that diminishes quickly.   Very fruity up front with apple barely making itself noticeable.  Finish is a little rough with a little too much alcohol flavor coming thru.  Doesnt blend very well with the fruitiness.  Alcohol warmth is there, but not as much as the flavor.  Sitting this for a some time to let the alcohol flavors mellow would really be beneficial.

Dark, thick brown body and a medium tan head.  Smelled like a quad, tasted like a quad.  Well balance flavor of yeast and golden raisins.  This got better as the bottle emptied.  Pretty standard quad.
Sweet aroma with a head that disappeared quickly.  This one was full flavored yet smooth in line with what I would expect from a quad.

I happened to have a Westy 12 today as well as drinking this, and I think this compared favorably, though not completely.  The biggest differences were: the palate wasnt as soft (it was more fizzy than frothy), the flavor was sweeter, with more obvious sugars less balanced by hops, and a marginal gap of flavor complexity.  Still, there was a fair amount of stuff to like here, including the broad malt profile, the Belgian sugars, the alcoholic bite on the palate, and the generally attractive beer in your glass.  Life is good.
I think that (for me) this is the quad of quads.  Very smooth, well balanced, complex.  12 oz bottle that I had sitting in the cold cellar for about 2 to 3 years.
Good smooth taste, a bit more sour then I expected, no stong alcohol taste. Very good aftertaste,
Dark amber color, large, long lasting head with nice lacing.  Somewhat sweet with an easy finish.

Bottle from 2001. Poured a reddish brown with a thick white head and plenty of floaties. Aromas of alcohol, apples, cinnamon, yeast. The flavour was alcoholic but not overly so also noted were apples, rasins, and a medium sweetness. Good but not quite on par with the other quads Ive tried
