can i just say one thing upfront before i forget? this is a trappist quadruple-- in a big fancy wire bound "bomber"-- for three bucks. three bucks! westvleteren is so expensive and precious that i have to pay a monthly royalty just for thinking about it. so unless its just dirt and donkey bile in this bottle, i conject that im going to be very pleased. the cork popped with a nice solid "thwock!" --  much like the sound of smacking a smart aleck nine year old on the head with a croquet mallet. where snifter and pour came together, there arose a murky brew, a buckskin orange-- the  color of a healthy pronghorn antelope.  the blog of yeast on the bottom was like the imagined fertile soil where you could plant a beer seed and expect big beers to grow. minimal head but with a pleasing feeling of effervescence. nose of apple butter, aging apple sap-- indeed, a great compost of apples amid african violet  potting soil. sweet tasting, with figs and brown sugar-- lots of it-- churning in mulchy malts that were raised in a swamp of raisin muck and apple cider;  a bit of sherry and lemon weave through the quagmire of belabored malts. thick and formidable as chewing tobacco. more lemon bitterness emerges late, but only to offer to help clean up the sticky malt bomb. good buzz, thoughtful complexity, and i AM pleased with my 3 dollar quadrupel, but you cant base a whole banquet on just apple butter.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2006 Bottled, its not on my top-list, but served from a keg lovingly cared for, this is a powerful, full-bodied beer that belies its Belgian-inspired heritage the moment you draw first blood: Rich, fruity from esters and warming on the coldest of days -- theres no denying that this is a quadrupel. Beautiful it is too.

bottle from brickskeller (labelled as konigshoeven now, not la trappe).  pours an amber-brown with full rich tan head.  this is a delight: aroma is alcohol, esters.  flavor is a tad yeasty (probably as a result of my mediocre pour) with big complex malts in the fore.  no noticable hops here.  great brew.

750ml bottle courtesy of csbosox: Murky amber-brown at its darkest, golden-amber towards the edge of glass, small light tan head.  There wasnt a huge amount of pressure released when I popped the cork like I expected.  Aroma: nice bready malts, fruity yeast, musty flowers, and just the smallest hint of citrus or lemon tartness.  Plenty of carbonation despite the almost nonexistent "pop" after uncorking, but not too much that it takes over the taste.  Medium-full bodied, sticky, sweet, slick in the mouth.  Taste: alcohol soaked bread up front, lightly spiced, then the malts and yeast shine through showing off pear, plum, fruity & earthy yeast, caramel, pizza dough, light banana & clove, wholegrain bread.  Finishes with a lasting spicy & sweet malt flavor in the mouth with a lingering taste of sweet grains.

Found this baby at Kenwood liqours in Cicero.It is La Trappe,an old 3 pack.Pours a copper dark amber with a huge creamy tan head.Might be a little sour but still get a lot of fruits,and some aromatic spices.Still very good not sour like I thought.Plenty of fruits here.Ripe bananas and dates.Very nice
A bit syrupy and sour, with too much bitter in the finish for my taste.  Alcohol is slightly noticeable, but seemingly drowned out by the molasses and sour taste.  Average.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Pours a dark and syrupy brown.  Not much head.  Spicy nose.  Pretty average.
UPDATED: DEC 10, 2006 Very frothy head, it doesnt go away- and nice lacing.  Fruity/floral malty aroma and flavor.                               Strong alcohol  after taste.             - but nice .

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2005 Pears, malt, alcohol aroma.  The aroma is dominated by fruit.  Dark amber.  The thin head doesnt last long, but the carbonation does.  Lots of sediment floating in this beer.  Flavor is generally sweet.  There is malt, more fruit, chalk.  Dry finish.  Sweeter and thinner than St. Bernardus or Westvleteren.

(2002/2003) Dense, creamy and extremely persistent foam. Clear brown color, limpid and loads. Much bubbly. Determined and much flowery scent. Complex and sweetish . Strong taste, decided, much rich one. Notes of liqueur and yield mature. Longest persistence.

Tonight I had a LT Quad and a Rochefort 8. They are both good but I think that I much prefer the La Trappe. Full, fairly sweet, and very tasty. I dont know if I have tried any that are any better. Yehaw!!!

Draught at Ølbaren. Reddish colour with a lasting off-white head, that makes laces.
Sweet aroma with yeast, fruit and dried fruit.
Nice sweet flavour with notes of dried fruit, yeast, muscavado, liquorice and spices.

(on tap at Ølbaren, both 2003 edit. and 2005 edit. Great idea guys, thanx)2005 edit: Clear, rubyred color. Some caramel and a LOT of banana. Somewhat soft mouth with plums and Pot Marigold. Sticky, canesugarish finish. Nothing compared to the 2003 edit: Hazy ruby color. Low carbonation and a mild taste of prunes, moscovado, elderflower og lime. A slow flowerish finish with great balnce of alcohol. Smooth longdrink
As good of a beer as one is ever going to find.  Deep, multi-layered fruit and caramel flavors, very mild hoppiness, light carbonation, translucent amber color.  I love this beer.

very light tan creamy head, does not last long.  cloudy dark orange ruby color with lots of yeast chunks.  aroma is raisin, plum, caramel malt, light alcohol.  flavor starts dark fruity sweet, like plumped raisins in rum.  bready malty middle then slight alcohol and faint banana.  very light hop bitterness, but balanced with a citrusy nip - like orange and grapefruit.  juicy mouthfeel!

had this in a bottle in amsterdam at amendnest.  huge nose on this thing....most noteable was sweet molasses, maple, bourbon, dark fruit and maybe some alcohol. nice fig and roasted choc malts push a warm alcohol feel.  pretty big beer and definately the nicest of the la trappe products.

Pours a hazy amber color with dark orange highlights and a thin offwhite head. Aroma of fruits (including raisins and plums) and alcohol, theres some sweetness that can be felt too. The flavor is very similar: fruits (raisins and plums), alcohol and a sweet finish. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Its a good beer, definitely the best of La Trappe.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2005 750ml bottle. 51°. Served in my Duvel glass.  Not sure of the date, bottle says K28K1. Pours orangy brown with a moderately small  off white head. As the head receeds, it leaves foam dots and when swirled, the beer fully coats the glass. Aromas are bananas and spice. The taste is the same, bananas and (blow, just kidding) spice that transitions to a slight alcohol taste then to a mildly hoppy finish.  There seems to be a slight feeling of alcohol in the finish, but it doesnt take away from the experience. The finish is malty and yummy. Mouthfeel is full and has a substantial weight.  Really nice.
Not the best of trappist ales, but readily available.  A bit more alcohol to the taste than desired but not overpowering.  Smooth finish.  Clean.

Purchased at New Beer Distributor in Chinatown, Manhattan, NYC.  Pours deep brown, foamy white head.  This is a smooth, somewhat mild quad; not particularly alcoholic in flavor.  Caramel notes.  Delicious.

Pours deep amber,  with slight but beautiful bubbling and a thick tan head that laces beautifully.  Nose is sharp apple and citrus fruits with a fun caramel overtone.  The flavor is complicated yeasts and creamy caramel, with more bitter grapefruit, as well as pear, apple, and dates.   There is a slight smokiness to the finish.  Alcohol is powerful and pervasive throughout, but not in an unpleasant way.  This is good.

33 cl bottle. Served in Westmalle goblet. Pours a brownish amber color. Moderate, off-white head. Aroma and flavor are big, warmly malty and very satisfying. Complex. Firm alcholic kick in the finish. Impressively full mouthfeel.
330 ml bottle. Orange brown in color, some fine sediment present. A little sweet with the taste of raisin and plum.

33 cl bottle. Amber color with a rich tan head that leaves plenty of lacing. Aromas of green apples, caramel and dried fruits. Taste is really complex. Taste starts of on the sweet side with malts and chocolate before the high alcohol gives way to figs, rum, banana and clove. Medium bodied and really good.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2010 33cl, cool, in a broad Duvel Tulip glass. Close kin to the excellent (and cider-murky) tripel. Clear deep amber, slight lingering head. Forward aroma honeyed and overripe ripe fruit then whiff maple syrup. Flavor is big - amazing tropical fruit-like presence at front , diving into roasted malty and brandy-like sustain finishing with a gentle bitterness. Stately while at the same time friendly. Rounded bitterness re-emerges in elegant swells. Mouth embracing, slight candy feel, warming sweet/alcohol sensations in palate and back of mouth - opulent with aromatic information. Evolves constantly!!!!  I could smell the empty glass for hours. Less austere and more exuberant than some Trappists. One of the most fragrant and generously flavorful things Ive tried.

Big ceramic bottle with a swing top bought from Internet wines back in 2002.  Pours a nice amber-brown colour with a small tan head.  Nice malt aroma in the beginning, with port and prune notes; but later the aroma becomes much sweeter. Strong, thick-bodied, the taste is sweet and malty; the alcohol is hidden well, but for me this boy is a little too sweet.  It finished more dry than expected, with some spiciness too.   I wish it had some bitterness to balance things out.  I liked it more as it warmed, but it still lacked some balance.  I liked it, but its not my favorite trappist ale.
Awesome. The aroma of bananas gave me a hint that I would enjoy this beer even before the first sip. Wondeful and warming. This was the perfect beer for a winter evening on the front porch.

Quite clear for the style with a loose off white head. Amber. Aroma of pear,some honey, apple, bread, a touch of cat pee. Clean and straight forward for a quad. All the flavors are there but it seems like some of the magic isnt. Really a good rendition but without any element that makes it shine.

Body is a cloudy garnet with minimal tan head.  Aroma of plum and fruit, very malty and alcoholic, with some bread and yeastiness.  Flavor is quite alcoholic which overshadows a lot of the flavor.  More vinous notes in the flavor, but the body is a bit on the thin side.  Im not very impressed.

Cloudy amber brown color with a few floaties, tan head. Plummy aroma, other fruit, light booze and some malt. Flavor is also pretty fruity, some raisin and plum, some booze again. I like the body but the alcohol is too apparent. Id imagine a cellared version would be less harsh and very nice. As it is, its still pretty nice, but for a quad its not as well made as some of the others.

Clear golden brown with off white head. Raisen cherry nose with light creamy toffee. Rich mouthfeel with a big sweetness that lingers. Cherry with some medicine quality to it in a good way, rich malt and a background of light toffee. Wow!

Almost had to chisel out the cork.  Poured a darkened amber with a light tan head.  Speckled with sediment throughout.  The aroma alone is enticing.  Strong yeasty, bready aroma...this is quite a bouquet of fruits as well... prunes, apples, grapes, plums and peaches.  Flavor is all malt with an apple like sweetness up front that fades into plums and prunes with a touch of woodiness and  a grapey, yeasty finish.  The body is very full and thick.  Nice.

smelled of 2 distinct items that I could not pick apart, but hints of a sweet flowery aroma was in it, the smell was very pleasant.  Had a thin white/offwhite head over a cloudy copper body.  The palate was highly carbonated w/ a medium body and a smooth finish the flavor was very sweet, too much so for my taste w/ hints of rose light carmel a smokey wood, and brown sugar, with a hint of tart in the finish and a small touch of alcohol as it warmed.  Overall a pretty complex taste that was good but to sweet to have gotten a better rating from me.

Pours out a rich peachy-red colour with some nice lasting head. Very nice aroma, sweet & fruity. The taste is like candy-apple and prunes. Alcohol very well hidden. Enjoyable to drink, my only knock against it is its just a little sweeter than Id like.

Small bottle.  This ale poured perfectly.   frothy head that diminished to a lace in 6 minutes.  Deep russet color.  Rich nose that invites.  Excellent balance between the caramelly malts, raisins, and alcohol.    Really a nice winter warmer.  Think Ill triple my pleasure with the three-pack.

Nice brew. A bit less wellbodied and complicated as Westvleteten and Rochefort but very tasty. Fruits dominating, especially grapes and apple. Raisin also present. Sweet, how surprising..
BTW La Trappe = Koningshoeven = La Trappe, and no, this isnt Trappistenbier anymore because of commercialisation. Only 6 left of them...
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2010 Nice strong beer.Fruity, smooth malty taste. Light bitterness. Very tasty beer. Take some.
Pours reddish-brown with a tan head.  Aromas of dark fruit such as raisin or plums.  Lots of malt sweetness in flavor as well as fruits.  Well carbonated.  Decent quad, but not overly special.

UPDATED: FEB 19, 2005 pours deep amber, slightly reddish brown. smells musty pruney, like an open box of raisins and gerbers baby food. rich foam adheres evenly on the glass as head subsides. bottle conditioned. gentle carbonation. soft and rich on the palate. tastes of cognac without the high alcohols, and dry fruit with hints of grape, candy sugar and toffee. subdued bitterness. alcohol presence so well hidden. quite complex. nice treat at the end of an evening.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2005 Color reminiscent of a strong apple cider. Pours with a ceaselessly foamy beige head... leaving a nice lace. Aromas of grapes, brandy & ... orchids (?) Tastes a bit like a Granny Smith taffy apple. Leaves a pleasantly sour aftertaste.  Satisfying finish (I tried one on an empty stomach and it left me with the feeling that Id eaten).  Id like to have this on hand as it could become a "comfort food".
<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Wine & Spirits, Countryside, IL<font size=-1>

750 ml bottle that the cork was damn hard to remove!  Lasting light beige head on a hazy medium amber orangish body.    Sweet toasty, bready malt w/ a some light diacetyl.  Some solventy notes of alcohol in the nose.  Light vinous raisiny & Rome apple notes.  Flavor is well balanced, but a little alcoholic.  Flavors of buttery diacetyl mend well with the apple flavor to make a caramel apple that is sweet up front.  Some floral plum flavors as well.  Bready malt, and did I mention alcohol.  It becomes more fruity/estery as it warms, but too many of these will make for a head banger of a morning.  Light spicy yeasty finish with plums.  Semi sweet aftertaste, but just enough not to be cloying.  Aftertaste is clove yeast & toasted malt.  Higher carbonation, but not has high as one would expect.    Smooth, surprisingly well hidden alcohol given the flavor and aroma profile, & medium bodied.  I like this more than the tripel, but still a little too sweet to drink a lot of at one time.  And that comes from a malty beer loving person.

Bottled.  A mahogany brown coloured beer with little head.  The aroma has caramel and banoffee pie.  The taste is sweetish with caramel, toffee, bananas, malts and alcohol.  A nice full bodied strong hoppy beer.

11.2oz bottle. Poured a nice murkey off copper brown.  Very sweet. Fluffy white head at first. Lots of apple and raisin and some brown sugar.Also some mints and a slight toffee. Lots of malt. Retains a lovely smoothness throughout.  highly enjoyable. I need to try the others now!!
UPDATED: JAN 16, 2006 From a small bottle.Worn out Leather trousers in colour.Little head.Old wine and north african fruits,strong malt.Computer says no.

Mellower nose. Candy, fruits, maybe some grain. tastes like.. apple juice? lots of fruity flavors swilring around. sometimes apple, sometimes raisin or plum. solid backbone here, assertive malts and sweetness, very light herb bitterness. like a beefed up dubbel. slight hint of honey.

Thin white head. Very dark and cloudy brown body. Aroma is overwhelming bubblegum and some pears. Also a hint of clove. The taste was bananas and clove. Also some hints of pepper and appples. The alcohol is detected, but not overwhelming. A nice quad, but nothing special.
pours a amber color with a small rimming head.  aroma and flavor is caramel rasin and soy sauce.  body is rich and smooth.  i like this pretty well.

Last of the Koningshoeven La Trappe gift pack (four 11.2oz bottles.. blonde, dubbel, tripel, quadrupel, and glass).  The quad is considerably stonger and more flavorful than the others.  They are all much the same in appearance and aroma, malty and fruity, with a creamy head that quickly disappears.  There is more complexity in the quad.. flavors go in every direction.  Mainly sweet malt base but then a variety of dark fruits and spices explode on the tongue, The sweetness, fruit flavors, spices, bitterness, and carbonation offset each other evenly and create a lively and interesting brew. Almost a sensory overload at times.  No fault to be found here.. quite excellent!  All the beers presented in the gift pack were variations on the same flavor theme, and all were imensely enjoyable.  Others seem to prefer the quad, while I found them all appealing.

Insanely strong esters of coconut milk, strawberries and pineapple. Promise  of thick creamy body, of tropical candies.Thick creamy head, bulbous in middle, leaving a nice belgian lace on the glass. Rises softly. Orange-red opaque. A wonderfully complex brew that shines with its esters that fill the air once the bottle is poured and appeal even the most harsh critics of beer. One brew to recommend to start out for a classic belgian taste. Very creamy body, head glides on the cheeks. Sour and astringent tastes in palate, quite shocking tastes of spices and pepper in palate.

The aroma of earthy maltiness with leather,brown sugar,cloves and alcohol.The off white moussy head was impressive as was the clear reddish brown ale( I drank this warmer then reccomended @65F)Bottle conditioned 
It is malty sweet to start but finishes with a spicy creaminess that is nice.Try one Today...The La Trappe name was not on my bottle. Labeled  Konings Hoeven Quadruple but listed the La trappe website on the label.

Beautiful looking brew. Slightly hazy apricot in appearance w/ a decent amount of carbonation. Has a lot of aroma. You can tell just by the smell that this one is going to be strong but fantastic. Nice sweet spicy flavors but not too sweet. Cant quite put my finger on all the flavors I pick up; there are a bunch of them. A tad bit of alcohol flavor but it feels great as it warms going down. Simply the best Quad Ive ever tasted, without a doubt.
Im not sure how to decipher the code to tell the age. This stuff was more amazing than I remember. Very similar to St. Bernadus 8 with a tad more oomph but still so smooth. Have to buy more.

Llight raisin with strong caramel. Light spice and alcohol there too. Hazy brown/dark armber with small lasting off white head. Sweet caramel flavour balanced with mild dark fruits and light spice. Smooth, medium-full feel. Lacks depth in flavour though, a little boring for a quad/abt.

33 cl botttle; Foamed out of the bottle. Highly carbonated with excellent fluffy foam, dark yellow, almost orange and hazy. As you drink this beer it will leave fat belgian laze don the sides of the glass - absolutely gorgeous! A really beautyful beer with a lot of character. No particluar aroma - but the flavour is strange and excellent. Powerful phenols that is almost overpowering, but ends up being piquante. Flavour is sweet, but the extreme - almost champagne like - carbonaton lends it some room, and prevents it from being cloying. An excellent beer, that masters the art of balancing extremely well. A lot better in bottle than it is on tap!

Initial pour produced plenty of fluffy soapy head.  A very bubbly and attractive amber color.  Nice spicy "fall" aroma too it.  Went very well with the turkey and stuffing dinner.  Light and easy to drink with a sweet malty finish
amber body with orange. big cardboard off-white head. smells apple and spices. taste is equally as good with some anise, clove and more apples and pit fruit. aftertaste is same. strong beer

Bottle. Nose is sweet and smells like Juicy Fruit gum. Notes of cherry, bread, brown sugar, dried fruit, and alcohol come out. This is much, much better than I anticipated. Very nice. Clean and devoid of any problems. I would happily drink this anytime.

UPDATED: MAY 14, 2005 pours a murky dark brown with a thin layer of head . yeasty sweet aroma of raisins. chewy dark fruit taste. creamy texture that is enjoyable. nice lingering bitter pepper finish. enjoyable brew, a little dry for my taste but nice none the less.11-17-04 7 3 6 2 13 ov 3.1
rerate 5-14-05. bought the bottle just for the glass. dont know why. i dont have room for more, but hell i needed to blow some cash on something i guess. so ill rerate this puppy on a saturday morning while i watch season 1 of scrubs. pours dark amber with a white head that faded to a ring soon after i poured it. of course i had to spend  a few minutes fighting the cork out. never had one that stubborn before, damn good thing ive been working out. musty yeast and grapes and some floral notes as well. sweet up front taste like a wurthers candy. pepper comes in and leaves a dry powdery finish. a bit watered down apple and nutmeg is in here too, maybe not nutmeg, but some other spice, cinnamon maybe. a touch of alcohol is noticeable on the finish, but not to the point i would think this is a 10 percent beer. 7 4 7 3 14 ov-3.5

A fragile beer - have had it bad on more than one occasion, tending toward heavy esters - fluffy/creamy mouthful of mild dates and raisins and light spice when its one. More often thinning and estery with a definite fusel flavor.
Amber color with a strong alcohol nose and a big foamy head.  Cherry flavor with breadiness and a sharp alcohol aftertaste.

Label says Konings Haeven Quadrupel.  Deep clear ruby copper color with a thick off-white head.  Rich bready yeast, brown sugar, and some dark fruits (cherries).  Lively carbonation with a full body.  Starts sweet and ends a little less sweet, followed by a long bready aftertaste.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2005 Poured a brownish orange color with a small head.  Not as carbonated as their triple i had prior to this.  Aroma is sweet of apples, caramel, apricot, and bubble gum.  Flavors of caramel, dark fruit, and alcohol.  Some spice at the end.  Medium bodied.

RERATE:  Very different this time.  Hazy dark copper with thin off white head and plenty of floaters.  Aroma of fruit, leather, cheese, and sugar.  Flavors of spice, bitter, and fruity underneath with a dry finish.

Lovely deep orangish/ruby color with a colossal white head.  Aroma of malt, barnyard, multiple dark fruits and berries, toffee, scotch, and cabernet.  Tastes malty, fruity, and with great balance and complexity.  We have a winner here, people!  For my money, this one kicks Orvals ass!  This one just made it onto my Christmas list!!!

Pours a cream, five finger plus (pour very slowly) head that goes slowly leaving a good lace.  Clear amber color.  Medium carbonation.  Nose is a sweet malty nutmeg.  Starts smooth and sweet, has a mellow finish.  $8.54 for a 750ml  bottle from Olivers Beverage Albany, NY.
Amber color, heavy sweet fruity aroma and taste, full body, light sweet alcoholic finish.
Very muddy brown color. Pretty light lacing. Aroma is sweet and nutty. This beer kicks ass! I love the tastes of the pineapple, grapes, and candy. This is so far the best I have had!

UPDATED: JUL 20, 2005 Pours a sweet amber color with reddish hints with a frothy off-white head.  Has quite a spicy aroma, dried fruits, extra sweetness.  Definite alcohol present in both smell and taste.  Quite sweet in flavor, strong on dried fruits, a caramel maltiness, lots of spices.  A bit syrupy.  Good warming drink for Chicago Winters.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Interestingly complex nose that I cant quite decipher.  Flowery?  Its good, however you describe the nose.  Nice Belgian lace forms on the glass.  Flavor is equally as complicated, with spicy notes of alcohol.  Also had banana flavors, with just a hint of bitterness.  Great beer.

Deep murky amber, fluffy off-white head.  Nose is a rich combination of ripe dark fruits, spices, brown sugar, caramel, fresh bread dough, and cotton candy.  Flavor is loaded with intense notes of raisin, plum, caramel, with a hint of sweet molasses.  Full bodied, creamy, soft carbonation, lengthy warming dark fruit finish.  Very nice for a nightcap.

I feel this is the best beer in the world, or at least it becomes the best beer once its been aged for about 4-5 years.  The last few aged bottles Ive had were stunningly good; now that its rebranded as de Koenigshoeven, it should be easy to find again in the US.  The taste is the same between the two labels, incidentally.

I always find the bubble gum ester to be a good way to tell whether the beer has aged long enough.  While that particular flavor is good, it vanishes with age and allows the natural richness of this beer to shine through instead.

09.24.04  11.2oz bottle.  Bottle has LaTrappe but label say Koningshoeven...Im assuming its the same.  Pours a rich, dark, reddish amber with slight wispy head.  Aromas are very nice fruits (jammed berries) and bready (like raisin bread) with light spicing.  Tons of banana.  Flavor is super sweet and malty, banana is present from front to back.  This beer is out of bananarific control!  Slight nuttiness to the malts adds depth to the finish.  Body is a bit thin for a quad, I thought and the beer is refreshing, even.  Well, certainly not the best example Ive had of the style, but not a dog, either.

bottle:  pours a nice dark amberish red with a bog biege head.  the aroma is very spicy and fruity.  plum rasin, cinnamon, some banana ,maybe a little clove. a little peppery.  the taste is alot of raisin and cinnamon like flavors.  quite spicy and malty.  subdued bitterness.  nice warming feeling of the alcohol.  very clean and smooth.
Amber brown with a beigh head.  Very fresh clean aroma of banana cream pie!  some cinnamon.  Flavors of tootsie roll, pie crust, adn a deep caramel lingering clean finsh.  Absolutely wonderful!

Pours a dark brown with a surprising head that faded into some small fine lacing. Pretty sweet aroma, lots of candi sugar. The flavor is sweet, maybe overly so, and missing the yeast character that I really like in Westy and Rochefort (which fits the description as a Quadrupel, but what the hell, I like the yeast...)

The beer poured out hazy dark orange in color with a tall blooming head.  The aroma was spicy and sweet with orange peel, coriander, and candi sugar.  The taste was sweet and tangy with an allusion of bitterness, and was backed by a good deal of spicy warm alcohol presence.  The mouthfeel was clean and creamy.  I did not feel that this beer was quite as complex as most quads, but was satisfying in its own way.

The aroma was a lot of banana, in fact it slapped me and the pre-wife in the face.  There was also some rumy raisins and then a hint of bubblegum.  The body was a light brown with some particles that eventually made it to the bottom of the glass; also a fine white head that didnt stick around for a long time.  The taste was dominated by raisins, but then the rest of the fruits showed up.  Some other dark fruits like plums and then some tart/sour cranberries, with a kick of bananas thrown in for good measure.  Oh ya, there was a nice alcohol overtone that lasted a looong time in the finish.

Koningshoeven Quadrupel
Appearance is amber/red color with a thick foamy head and a very sticky lace. The head diminished quickly and left a fine layer. Aroma was primarily of malt, bubblegum, bready and some spice background. The taste is sweet and malty with a light hop bite that lingers. The mouthfeel is smooth and carbonated, yet seemed to remain on the tongue well past the last taste. 

Is there a difference between this quadrupel and the La Trappe Quadrupel? This beer did not seem to be well proportioned (heavy flavors and not a lot of character).

UPDATED: MAR 28, 2006 Poured a ruby plum color with a big bubble but thin head that resembled a web of some sort...smelled sweet with caramel and other malts, with present alcohol...tasted very sweet with the aroma present in the taste...prunes and bread and yeast too...well balanced...nice and underrated...if the mouthfeel was a little thicker this would easily compare with the Rochefort and Westys...alcohol and sugar in the finish...

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2004 My first beer from the netherlands is a ripe and sweet chocolatey success.  Orange and delicious.  Brown sugar essence put rochefort to shame at times.  wild!  rerates even higher

Clear chestnut with orange shine; amberish tinted head, leaving good lace. Chocolate, vinous and a meaty nose, sweet brandy aromas. Taste is fruity, like ripe brambles, alcohol comes out in the taste. Quite sweet but in a positive way, fruity and vinous. Again a bit of chocolate, warming up, ending, if one can make this concept, heavy Bordeaux laced with sweet but dark chocolate. Creamy mouthfeel, alcohol, but little burn, full bodied (surprise...) The original and olnly quadruple. Actually a very nice beer, which deserves more than being an advertisement gimmick for a non-existent style. And in an Albert Heijn bottle, at that...

Great beer with light-brown color and with orange shine. The froth is fluffy and has a bone like color. This is a rich beer with complex aromas of dried fruits orangepeel nice malts and coriander. This beer is dens and sticky with a warm caracter. The rich taste has hints of dried plums and orange marmalade. The afthertaste is turning dry.

As a matter of principle, I am forced to give this beer a 19 overall.  Were I to esatblish this beer a 20, twould not leave room for expansion.  But, dang, if this aint the best beer Ive ever had.  Bought it at a packatge store in Georgia, and boy, did it pay off.  A smooth dark beer that does not overwhelm your tastebuds at all.  The taste is so complex and complete, it reminds me of a symphony.  If you took the best characteristics of your favorite porter (like Anchor Porter) and your favorite ale, combined those into this quadrupel-ly fermented pleasentry, youd have a happy time.  So, go buy this.  And then drink it.  Because its good.

This beer makes me want to sing Lets Get It On to it. Because drinking you can never be wrong, with a beer so true... I dont see anything wrong with this beer. Its taste is smooth and full of a spicy cloves, bread and cinnamon and maybe some bananas too. Its got a 10% ABV but it doesnt taste like it. Its just a very pleasant and warm (I had it around room remperature to bring out the tastes and complexities). Well, until I find something wrong with this beer Ill leave it with a perfect rating I think.

Dirty orange-brown body with plenty of "floaties," topped by a thin off-white head.  Cloves, banana, and bubblegum (Dubble Bubble) along with bread, cinnamon, and a touch of chocolate comprise the aroma.  Chalky body, quite spicy, with toast, clove, cinnamon, banana, dark fruits (raisins, plum/prune) and potent yeast.  Complex with a dry sweetness (is that possible?) that complements the spice.  Alcohol provides just enough warmth at the finish but is otherwise contained nicely.

Bottle from Pitfield Beer Shop, London. 330ml. Served in a chalice. Pours a deep, dark orange with a fluffy and thin white head. There is plenty of banana in the aroma, and no alcohol apparent. First sip is soft, rich and mild with many contrasting flavours. Dried fruit (raisins/sultanas), banana milk shake and spices, mild alcohol. Very, very nice.

Bottle at 55 degrees F. Pours hazy orange/amber with a generous off-white head. Aroma of caramel covered apricots, spices and fresh yeast rolls. Initial taste is very sweet reminiscent of peaches, apricots, vanilla and fresh bread. Sweetness is dominant but somewhat curtailed by the 10% alcohol which gives this brew a slight mid-palate bite. Very smooth and full-bodied mouthfeel. Finishes with a faint hop presence. A very tasty Trappist Quad.

UPDATED: MAY 24, 2005 Bottle, Ciros, Toronto. Wonderful aroma with notes of perfume, peach, and warm alcohol.  Fantastic hazy orange colour.  Intense alcohol flavours, slight bite, yet very sweet as well.  A very enjoyable experience, thanks Doug.

Re-rated at International Night of Swill at Gregs (obviously a break from the swill).  Thanks to Jan Primus for the bottle.  It was interesting going back, as this was one of the first experiences I had with the style last year.  Now I was not near as impressed.  I thought it still had a fantastic aroma, but didnt find anything truly impressive of its appearance.  If anything now, I found that it was a little too one sided and unbalanced - the strong malt character and alcohol were overwhelming.  Sharp was the word that came to mind and the whole package was a little watery.  Having said all this, I still found the beer to be very enjoyable and I would have it again, I just wasnt as wowed as originally when I gave it a 4.3.  Original ratings were 8/5/8/4/18.
Dark brown with nice head and very good lacing. Aroma is sweet with caramel as the most dominant note. Flavor is full of caramel. The high alkohol content is not that evident.

Poured a medium brown with nice lacing and pillowy head, lots of floaties. Smelled of leather and spice. Very warming and huge maltiness that kept reminding me of the Fullers 1845 for some reason. Alcohol bite at the end that was very pleasant.

trappist glass, K26G2, 09:55, room temp.: huge off-white head; slightly airy and cremey. dark and murky brown with ruby highlight. cremey and slightly lively palate. altogether flavor and aroma: full, mild and pleasantly bitter indeed! quad? wow! malty and slightly syrupy; toffee. hops hops hops... egh, what hops? its slightly bitter and i cannot pinpoint the flavor accompanied with it. fruity? hardly; a little bit berry... its great! it's  smoooooth...

My serving of this was not all that great, if I can get this served in the propper way and under some better conditions then I will definately re rate this thing. Lighter in colour than the tripple with a sweetness to it that is just phantastic, mostly suggar you can really get that out of this thing. The nose and taste are both sweet, the taste is kind of chalky and yeasty, that suggar is really there.

Man i wrote a review of this but my mozilla lost...that sux D. Well anyway good brew but could certainly be better. Looks ok. mouthfeel could be a tad bit less watery opn the forefront. Nose is minty and citrusy. Flavors are complex but the yeast overpowers. Good brew, could be better.
G-rat

Bottle (al little warmer than fridge temp)- pours a deep amber with a slight off-white, beautiful frothy head with wonderful lacing.  Aromas of a typical quadruple ale of straw, yeast and light aroma of nuts.  Hops are barley detected in the aroma.  Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with a sweetness that tingles your tonsils.   I dont know if my bottle wasnt stored properly but thier is a coppery/metallic overtone. Nonetheless, the flavors that I pick up are of yeast, light bananas, a little soap, and brown sugar/honey.  A little sweet but not overbearing... overall, not as impressive as Id hoped.

Extremely spare head that produces a nice lace nonetheless. Sparkling red-brown color. The aroma filled the room with the first POP. Caramel, vanilla, orange and leather. Light body and a creamy slick alcoholic palate. No hop bitterness. Fruity sweetness hides the alcohol.
Poured a dark, hazy amber, with almost no head. Lots of particles. Aromas of yeast, bread, fruits and sweet (sugar). Tastes like it smells -sweet and fruity. Alcohol well hidden.

This belgian pours with a deep amber body topped by a medium thick, off-white head with some lacing.  The aroma is sweet and malty with a caramel note, a nice spiciness and notes of alcohol.  The flavor is sweet and sugary with a slight spiciness and a touch of alcohol.  Full bodied, surprisingly smooth and a touch dry.
Dark color with good off white head and lacing.  There was a spicy/malty smell.  Rich taste with a little spice.
Many flavors. Cloves,nutmeg and a nice touch of cinammon. Rum and mocha. Rich mouthfeel. Warming alcohol. Hops and juicy fruit finish.

750 ml bottle.  This pours chocolate brown with red-amber highlights when held to light and a moderate off-white head that left fair lacing.  Aroma is malty, yeasty and spicy - includes hints of citrus and cloves.  Flavor is rich, sweet and spicy with brown sugar, yeastiness and alcohol present as well.  Medium body and mild carbonation.  Nice Belgian style and definitely worth the $7 I paid for it.

A very satisfying Belgian. Well balanced. None of the  many flavors overpower one another. Pours a brown red with a small head. Flavor begins with some nice sweet malts. Some yeast and candi sugar is present. There are some dried fruit flavors in it as well. Develops into a dry finish with hints of spice. Alcohol is well hidden.  Superb.
sweet orange and corriander nose.  Sweet malt with candi sugar and some yeast.  Nice earthy hops.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2009 Bottled. Certainly a big, big taste at work here. Starts with lots of foam, but that subsides quickly. The brown hazy body shows off a cascade of golden bubbles when I pour more into the Belgian glass. Nice brown sugar smell. Even my non-drinking wife wanted to taste it, and declared it delicious and sweet. Yep, good candi sugar sweetness. Extra alcohol smoothness gives it the texture of a sweet dinner wine. Or maybe I can compare it to a barley wine, just missing the hop bouquet.

Rich reddish-copper color, with a very thin head. Aromas of raisins and malt. Full bodied, rich and heavy with lots of dark fruit flavors and some sweetness. Aftertaste is lightly malty with lingering  spiciness in the back of the throat, masking any bitterness and giving a very balanced finish. This is a rich, rounded, strong and complex. Didn't really notice the alcohol content.

Slightly hazed amber body. The head is a pillowy beige affair. The aroma is  swwet, candi sugar, some fruitiness. Nowhere near as complex as the Westvleteren or Rochefort quads. The flavor is fairly sweet, though not quite as sweet as the Achel Extra. Adjunct sugars and some dark fruit are predominant. The finish is fairly dry, which is the only indication of the high ABV. The body is medium with a fizzy palate. As with most quads this is a nice beer. However, it is a great distance from its true Trappist bretherns.

10% huh? I would never have known. It hides it very well. Pours mahogany with an off white head. Lots of fruit sugars in the aroma and flavour. Flavours are fruity and spicey. Some banana and yeast notes. This was the fifth beer in a night of high alcs. Worth the re-rate henceforth in a fortnight. Regardless, it was very nice.

Cool, bright, deep crimson color, full, fresh, bubbling beige head. Aroma: alcohol and yeast step forward, fresh baked bread, mixed with light, yet delicious fruity, slightly citric flavor, lemony, sweet, deep, unique, softly spicy, vanilla. cardamom, clove, unearthly, if ever this was bitter, it went away, as this bottle is over 3 years old, if I can trust the label. 
Oh, so very smooth, light, perfect balance, maybe I hit this aged bottle at it's peak, but it's different from all the times I've had it before, more mellow and fully integrated, less forceful in flavor, less dominant, though still toasty, tasty, spicy, and very rewarding...wow, I wish that I'd stashed more than this one bottle away...the aging did good work on it, for the alcohol is less felt and the flavor is appreciably softened, not that I didn't love it before. 
Ratings over, now it's time to just chill with the remainder...
Clear, brown-reddish bocy.  Brownish fizzy head, fully diminishing and fairly lacing.  Lightly hoppy aroma.  Lightly sweet, lightly bitter initial flavour, lightly bitter finish.

Pours a mahogany colored body and an insanely fluffy ivory head. An orchard of Fruity notes.. filled with plums, apricots, peaches, apples, and oranges. I thought this would be darker bodied than the Double but it’s not. This is like a cross between a Triple and a Double. Extremely fruity and yeasty.. some sweet and toasty notes of molasses along side. 
 This is really damn good! The palate is exceptionally velvety and luscious. I’m surprised how citrusy and sweet this Quad is…. Notes of caramelized sugars, banana and even some ginger in the finish…. Halliluja!!!!<b/>

nice malt aroma; the same cloudy orange look as their tripel, and the same long-lasting head - these 2 beers set the standard for appearance; the taste isn't as good as the tripel, but still very good - there's no hint of alcohol

Pours a transparent amber color with lots of floaties and a robust 3cm off-white head.  Aroma is very yeastly with a musty banana aroma.  Start is fruity with the middle having some mild banana taste to it.  Finish is malty and smooth with a hint of caramel.  Nice finish.  Has a wonderful palate and the 10% isnt even close to being noticeable.  I wish there was a little more complexity flavorwise, though.  All in all, a nice brew.

Brown, with a large bage head.  Aroma is sweet, like brown sugar or syrup, but the alcohol is apparent in the aroma. There are also some leathery or horse banket aromas/flavors in the mix too.  Flavor is sweet. Body is full and sticky.  Good beer to sit by a fire an dream.

A good quad. Decent sized head. Orangy color, somewhat foggy. Nice aroma. Citrusy, malty, and slight alcohol hints in the aroma. Nice sweet flavor. Acidic, citrusy, and some malt as well. Overall pretty decent! A nice treat from AD at the Beer Sellar in Knoxville, TN!
fruity banana... Light medium body... Dies rather quickly when it comes to aftertaste...

Now called koningshoeven,I sampled the 750ml bottle and the bottle still had the word trappist on it.  The awesome smells of raisins and plum complimented it's beautiful deep mahogamy color.  The average creamy head stayed throughout.  the sweet, malty flavor was well carbonated.  Alcohol and citrus notes were noticed towards the finish.  Not as good as st.bernardus abt 12 but a good competitor.  Look out for the alcohol sneaking up on you. wooooo

UPDATED: AUG 8, 2011 12oz bottle that has the Koningshoeven label yet embossed with LaTrappe. Poured a slightly cloudy amber-brown with a beige head that is quite thick and leaving scattered lacing. Outstanding aroma of fruit, sweet malt and yeast with notes of figs and raisins. Mouthfeel is velvety with a crisp lively carbonated feel. Quite smooth. The flavor is also outstanding. Fruity and candy sugar sweetness envelopes the strong malt flavor and a bit of alcohol is also detected. A slight warming sensation in the finish. Overall a high quality Trappist ale. Update 6-15-05. This is truly an under-rated brew. It seems to get better everytime I drink one.Update, draught available in Naples for the first time. This is sensational! Lucsious malty fruity treat of a beer. velvety mouthfeel, fruity malty yeasty love beer!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text:
UPDATED: MAR 9, 2008 (Bottled, BBE 12/2008) Dark red-amber with a large, foamy, tanned head. Very sweet and caramely aroma with some alcohol, dried fruit and grainy malt. Grainy, very sweet-sugary-malty flavor with dried and fresh fruit. The sugariness does hide the alcohol. Medium-bodied, sticky palate with lowish carbonation. Ok, its quite nice in its own dessert-kind-of way - but way too sweet and not very complex. Once again, not up to the trappist scale. Koningshoeven may technically be a trappist brewery - but qualitywise, theyre way behind the Belgians.
(0.33l bottle, 2002/2003 version, rated 2/20/2004, was 6-5-8-4-14=3.7) Deep, dark, clear, red-amber color. Medium, lacy head. Slightly stuffed, fruity, toffee aroma with hints of alcohol. Caramel-malty, cherry flavor - fruity, banana finish. Sweetish. Hides the ABV very well. Sticky, full-bodied palate. Long, sweet and fruity aftertaste.

UPDATED: APR 22, 2005 Re-re-rate 
Small sample from 750.  Last place finisher (of 9) in Abt/Quad shootout.  heavy carbonation.  Aroma soured, with some cheese in the nose.  Flavor much more crisp than previously noted.
Re-Rate
33cl sample this time in Koningshoeven bottle.  Finish more clean this time...not seeming like 10% in taste, only in the nose.  Strong carbonation.   Caramel, but not too complex.
750ml bottle.  Poured dark reddish/brown with a scent and taste of raisins and dates.  The only negative is the strong alcohol finish (it is 10% ABV).  Really a winter treat, esp. for $5.99 with a free glass!

This pours a cloudy amber/orange color.  Head is dense, large off white colored that dissipates quite slowly.  Aroma is sweet, mostly orange with a touch of spice.  Taste is quite sweet and alcoholic, but not overpoweringly so.  Body is medium.  Aftertaste was quite mild.  A nice brew.

I found this to be about the same as the tripel, but maybe a little sweeter. Aroma is spiced (cardamom) dark fruit or brown sugar covered orange. Body is a dark murky copper with a nice creamy off-white head. Sweet fruit alcohol taste which sweetens up in the finish. Creamy palate. Good beer and a little stronger bodied than the tripel, but a little too sweet.
I had this a couple of years ago and it was so good. I had it last night and I was disappointed. It was good. Clear orange in color. Fruity aroma. Too sweet though.  Too harsh of a finish. ok.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2004 750 ml bottle, undated. Pours a clear orange with floaties and a big, tan head. Nice fruity aroma. Raisins all over the place. Palate is sweet and starts full, round, and nice. But it has a harsh finish. The alcohol is well hidden. The beer is rather sweet. I just dont like the finish. Close to being a great beer.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Slightly hazy copper colour with a small off-white head. Warm and inviting aroma of boozy raisins and sweet malt. Nice smooth mouthfeel, and flavours of malt, yeast & plums. Warm and slightly harsh alcohol finish.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2007 November 2007. On Tap @ Beer Bistro. Dark amber brown body with a big light fluffy off white head. Proper glassware helped here I think. Aroma is muted, and the glass is a detriment here, not funneling much of it to the nose. Muted sweet mild, and mild notes of alcohol. Lightly musty hints, sugary. Sweet malty-sugary flavour, notes of caramelized sugar, brown slight, light touch of fruit lingers. Sweet light alcohol warming in the finish. (7+) Smooth average palate is nice, but thinner than I prefer for the style. 7+/4+/7/3/15-16

Re-Rate May 05 Orangey amber body, with a massive billowy white head. Sweet malty aroma, bit of alcohol. Flavour is sweet, a touch of caramel in the malt. Dry alcoholic finish is underwhelming. Medium bodied palate. 6/4/6/3/14

Original Rating A disappointment from the first pour. I was expecting a dark malty beer along the lines of the dubbel, but this was so much like the tripel I had to double check. Bit of alcohol bite in the aroma, sweet lingering aftertaste. A good beer but not what I was hoping for. 7/3/7/3/16
Dark amber colour. Medium-sized, off-white head. Flavour is malty-sweet, with hints of fruit, like banana and berries. Tasted highly alcoholic. Nutty, bitter finish.

Beautiful creamy head on a hazy orange amber colored body. Nose is very fruity with plum, berries and a delicate alcohol note. Flavor is sweet but turns into a nice sour bitterness. Spicy with strawberry and orange notes. Hides the high ABV very well!
Light amber coloured beer with a big creamy off white head. Caramel and alcohol aroma and taste. Like the blond there is a light woody taste. Quite ok.

Pours a hazy copper color with an off white creamy head and nice lacing.  Sweet aroma of fruit (banana), sugar and yeast.  Overwhelming taste of fruits, especially melon, apples and citrus, some caramel, spice, and alcohol as well.  A little pepper taste on the tongue.  Mouthfeel wasn't as enjoyable as I was expecting.
fuzzy, hazy brown. White creamy lace. Perfumy aroma, sweet, alcohol. Strong yeast flavour. Very strong alcohol taste, I didn't really like that aspect of it though it did warm me up a fair bit.

an almost perfect creamy/frothy head. A clear dark amber color. The smell is very hoppy, caramel, resin. Taste nice sweet, a light oily, creamy texture & well-balanced  soft carbonization. A very nice (but strong) beer!

One of the finest of Trappist brews.  Very full bodied, almost port-like, with a warming alcohol glow that makes my cheeks light with happiness.  Sweet and long finish.  An excellent example of how noble a beer can be.

11.2oz bottle- Color is a deep rusty brownish orange with big chunks of yeast hanging out at the bottom and suspended within, medium beige head retains a bit before fading to a thin collar and has very minimal spots of lace. Aroma is largely wafting with phenolic yeast and an ethonal alcoholic punch with a modest sweetness of malts lending dulled citrus of melons and orange with hints of banana, raisin, and plum and some touches of caramel skirt underneath. Taste has a nice medley of dark fruits noted in the smell and a malty smooth sweetness with nice yeasty underlaying notes of clove and bits of medicinal plastic. Overall very soild in its length of malts, dashing with dark fruits and trailing with caramel, lighter toffee, and slight mild spice in the finish. The alcohol hardly makes any appearance but there is some warmth sneaking in. Feel is nice and smooth, lightly chewy and creamy with a lighter side of the heavy or full but yet, not medium either. Quite a nice feel, fits well with the malts and yeast. Well balanced and pleasingly smooth and quite quaffable for having 10% ABV, although that sneaks up on ya quickly lending a bit of respect and engaging you to slow down and enjoy it. Best of the La Trappe IMO.
Brown-amber color with ample head.  Aroma strong with a fruity tinge.  Smooth and thick and strong in flavor.  Impressive beer.

Tasted in Toronto from LCBO (2003).  Tasted in Westmalle 1836 Trappistenbier glass.  Tasted at 10C.  Appearance is light brown / orange / rust colour.  Light white head, small but sustained.  Aroma is strong in alcohol and has a distinct candy like presence. Flavour is very sweet.  i am picking up a strong artificial sweetness, like brown sugar or something post fermentation.   Very overwhelming.  Seems like a very cheap knock-off of a proper quad/abt.  Very disgusting.
(750 ml Bottle)  Pours an orangeish-cooper colore with a large white head.  Has an apple and alcohol aroma.  Descent tasting Trappist ale.

750 ml. brown, corked & caged bottle. No freshness date that I can decypher. Poured out a bright orangey copper color, with an immense off white head. It lasted until the bottom of the glass. Aromas are of bananas, bread yeast, subdued hops, and slight maltiness to it. No aromas of alcohol, somewhat fruity in aromas as well. Tastes of bananas, malts, and slight hops bitterness as it is swallowed. It has that classic Belgian beer profile to it, even though it's not brewed in Belgium. Sweet on the tongue, not very warming as it goes down, either. Hides it's alcohol very well. Finished sweet, but not cloying. A well made trappist ale, all in all.

Well for 500 I was going to have my Westy 12, but dopey me broke my trappist glass. So it's going to have to wait I little longer. This was good enough to be #500. Bottled at Monks Cafe in Philly. This beer was fantastic. Nice sweet malty taste to it.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2003 Alcohol is hidden well, tastes good too, but for those of you who can get headaches from alcohol - this IS one of the beers that causes headaches.  I only mention this because most Belgian beers don't do this to me, but this one did.
This beer poured virtually with no head. The whole taste of this beer tasted like medicine. A little too sweet for my tastes, not enough hop bitterness.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2003 What can I say other than I absolutely loved this Quad. Poured into a trappist glass with a huge tan head. nose was super sweet.  Flavor reflected the nose, very sweet and malty brings toffee and some fruits to mind.  Alcohol is suprisingly subtle  but I can  assure you that it is present.  Head and shoulders above DeKoningshoeven's other attempts. One of my favorites.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2008 Yet another one courtesy of the dynamic duo of Icelandic beer culture, Haukur and Eiríkur. Theyre a bit too generous as I was getting a bit out of shape along the tasting...

I do remember being pleasantly surprised by this big boy. It warrants a re-rate for a better description, but truly one of the best Ive had. Underrated here in my opinon.
(Rating: Ar. 8 App. 5 Fl. 9. Pal. 5 OA. 18)

Re-rate: I was a bit surprised seeing how high Ive rated this one as La Trappes other beers havent pleased me much.

Surprised by initial lack of head and, if not for seeing through the brown bottle, how light in colour it is. The aroma is big, however.

Sweet aroma with some dark fruitiness and caramel malt. Same goes for flavour which is, if I remember right, not nearly as complex as the other Trappist quads. Mainly caramel, or maybe rather nouggat, and it feels theres some nice hoppy freshness on the finish.

Reminds me a lot of Chimay Rouge this time around, although its not really that similar. A whole lot sweeter too.

Its not awesome as I thought first time around but still very pleasant. It would probably rate higher for me if it had something to back up that sweetness.
Dark cloudy brown. Thin beige head. Sweet honey aroma. Cloying brown sugar flavour at first Mellowing out to Caramel and honey notes. Alcohol not that noticable. Slight dry hop bitter notes.

A medium dark cloudy amber with a thin off white head. Very sweet dark fruit aroma with some caramel.  A nice warming palate.  Flavor starts very sweet with apples, plums, and caramel then ends with a nice combination of spice, cloves, cinnamon and raisins.
I must say my prayers more often, this brew is an old trappist recipie, this stuff is one of the best ive ever had. I have to re-rate with comments later.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2010 what a beer! I wasnt expecting much since the other La Trappe beers have been very ordinary.. beautiful amber color, with a big head, great yeasty, candyish aroma.. taste is very special and very unlike the other abt´s/quadruppels score 4.7

re-rate 10 jan 2010

malty and tasty, high levels of sweetness. Unlike other tappists, yes, but not entirely in a good way. Good beer nonetheless
Amber color with a big beige head. Aroma of yeast, sweet malt and candy. Flavor is sweet, dark fruit, acidic, and a little toffee and nuttiness.

2000 vintage, 750 ml. Bright amber body with millions of fine floating particles and a soft, thick head. Fresh fruity aroma of caramelized apples, lemon, cloves, and yeast. Smells like unbaked apple crisp. Tart sweetness. This beer has a nice malty richness balanced with refreshing acidity and a bitter finish. Flavor builds nicely as the complexities gradually shine through. Benefits immensely from cellaring.
Amber color, slightly unclear. No sediments. Rich head. Yeasty, malty aroma. Full-bodied , quite sweet with pine needle bitterness and a dry nutty finish.

UPDATED: JAN 14, 2004 33cl bottle into La Trappe glass. Dark orange colored, hazy with lots of sediments. Head is off-white and small, diminishing. The aroma is very pleasant, yeasty with sweet malty candy fruitiness reminding peaches, plums and green raisins without forgetting alcohol notes. Good medium to full mouthfeel, rather silky. The taste is not as refined as the scent, it's toffeish, peachy, very malty and sweet with a flowery spicy and hoppy finish that does not grab me particularly.
This beer has a dark body - hue with a sweet initial flavor and a middle body.

Glowing amber, small white, creamy head and lace. Traces of slow rising carbonation. Nose of huge malts, pears, some spice,  slight peach, bit medicine and wood. Full bodied, rich, sweet (not even close to overly so) with flavors of big bready malt, cotton candy, candied sugars, citric hops?, bit of wood, spicy alcohol but not that "hot" alcohol. the 10% is hidden wonderfully, mellow, flavorful, rich and warming. A great beer.

Pours a very viscous looking hazey golden color with very little head (no head for mine - bad bottle?).  The aroma was somewhat damp and musty and spicy; sort of like walking into a 200 year old basement.  The flavor is quite fruity and malty with some bitterness to help it out.  There is a bit of alchohol noted.  Each swallow produces a new flavor progression that ranges from the dry start to the malty finish.  There is an aftertaste of french bread.  The palate is quite hearty with each mouthfull like taking a bite if bread.  This is better as it warms; and in turn, it's warming me.  Overall, yes this is a unique expereince for somebody who has not yet had any of the Trappistes.
Golden Orange, with a big white head. Grainy, "beery" aroma. Crisp aand hoppy at the start, but a thick, "bread in a glass" finish. Ends up clean, though, with very little after taste.

Bottled. Sampled at Stockholm Beer Festival 2003.
Amber, a bit hazy.
Warm alcohol-aroma.
Really sweet with flavour from dried fruits. Marshmallow-bananas(?).
Medium amber body, off-white small dense head, slightly plastic, slightly sweet nose. Alcohol well hidden, berries and dark fruits. Some sweetness, some off-flavors. No Westy 12, this.
Draught: Dusty dark amber coloured. Medium quickly diminishing beige foam. Malty, sweet and yeasty aroma. Flavour is a bit vinous and spicy. Malts present. Has a quite nice alcahol burn in the end.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2005  Bottled. 
Deep amber/Cognac flavour. Sweetish and yeasty, maybe sugary aroma and flavour, hints also of marshmallow banana and plum. Sweeter than La Trappe Dubbel. A sourish undertone.
UPDATED: NOV 7, 2006 Draught at Monk´s cafe, Stockholm. Amber, huge lasting offwhite head. Very fruity, pears, pine apple, veryfresh aroma. Fruity, malty flavor, alcohol is very well hidden.

Very nice lacing, puffy head and a burgundy auburn hazy color. ruit aromas filled with banana nut bread, cloves and a slight alcohol note. Flavor is zesty & acidic, lightly citrus with hops in the background, candi sugar and specialty malts in the foreground. Mouthfeel is slightly musky with a yeast feel and slightly metallic. Overall this has a nice sweetness to it with some yeasty overtones and a noticable but well hidden alcohol bite.

Had this in the smaller bottle at Old Chicago.  $8 for this little treasure, but it was so worth it.  An incredible pour, very deep rich which gives way to a deep ruby color with a huge creamy head.  I mean as soon as you open the bottle and begin to pour, the aroma fills the room, with a fragrant floral aroma that is likened to walking into a flower shop that is right next door to a bakery and maybe a produce department for the fresh fruit aromas.  The taste is like a very very good brandy, or scotch.  The burn is their but quickly fades in a texture on your tongue that is very exciting.  An incredible mouthfeel, with flavors that are too long to list.  Extremely complex and lively.  One of my new favorites.

UPDATED: MAY 11, 2004 75 cL bottle, La Trappe glass, 50 degrees.  Toughest damn cork I've ever fought against.  First pour yields no head because I'm an idiot.  Deep red-brown body is murky and opaque without any visible particles.  Aroma is strong enough to let its presence be known from 2 feet away.  Cookie, caramel, and slightly nutty (walnut) malt is dominant; earth, cobweb yeast is the next most powerful aroma; also resent are prune, date, unripened banana, peach cobbler, some sort of sweet wine, toffee, and a some fusel alcohol.  That's a nose full!  Heavily sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter flavor becomes a moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly bitter finish.  The acidity has a fruity sourness to it.  Second pour produces a gigantic, creamy, frothy, off-white head that lasts well.  The mouthfeel has also become much smoother now.  Alcohol burn starts up front and continues throughout, but is not nearly as bad as I was anticipating at 10% ABV.  Very smooth oily/creamy texture, medium-heavy body, lively carbonation.  I pick up some grape flavors that weren't in the aroma, but everything else translates quite well.  The bottom line is: looks, smells, tastes, feels excellent, 10% ABV, 75 cL, and a free glass for only $6?  I'm sold

Smooth draw and then a burst of flavor when it hits the back of your throat. Good bitter flavor but an aftertaste that lingers. Can feel my cheeks flushed after only 
a couple of sips

Sweet mother of mercy. I thought the Dubbel kicked ass ... this is incredible. The aroma isn't there, but it's nice and cloudy, with a lasting head and a colour and flavour reminiscent of black cherries, not to mention malt, spice, and corner-store toffee. A bit syrupy, a bit of fizzy carbonation. I caught a hellafied buzz off this one.
sweet fruity aroma, pours with a crimsonhue and a good head, long, smooth, oily, syrupy and fruity, the finish is warming and has hints of coriander.
Awseome, sugary, rock candy aroma!  Sticky mouthfeel.  Syrupy and sweet followed by some bitterness to end.  Radiant amber-orange colour.  I like.
Sweet malt taste, strong banana aroma, and yeasty aftertaste.  This bottle was in the back of my fridge for six months, I should have opened it sooner.

Orange/amber tint with a lot of yeast floating around.  Tightly bubbled head.  Fruity, cotton candy nose.  Alcohol and funky/different aftertaste are prevelant.  Doesn't taste like the aroma at all.  It's warm and soothing on my throat which is nice.  Some bitterness in the middle.  Not bad and not great.

Clear amber with a thin white head. Soft bubble gum aroma. It is too sweet for me, and I like sweet. Candylike and stopping just short of cough syrup. It forms an odd aftertaste taht causes me to regeret my purchase, the ABV doesn't really pull it out for me either. Maybe its a bad bottle but its the second time I've had it and I will not venture to go for a third.

Aroma is spicy, but not very specific.  Color is a nice slightly dark oragne, with a thin amount of head.  Flavor is very fruity.  A little bit of banana flavor is present.  Body is full with a good hop feel.
Nice amber color and a light spicy aroma.  Nice head that quickly goes away.  Tastes nice and fruity with a pleasant sweetness.  Very enjoyable.
White head, diminishes quickly. Amber colour. Fruity aroma. Sweet taste, gentle and smooth, well-hidden alcohol. The more I drink the La Trappe beers the more I like them...

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2003 Beautiful color and nice white foam. Nice fruity aroma. Excellent sweet fruity taste, with a sweet but excellent aftertaste. Update: Just had this on tap, and the alcohol comes through a little better, but that is not a bad thing on the contrary, it was better on tap than the bottle version.
Awesome aroma and complex, fruity taste; however the alcohol is a tad too evident. Very sweet and will definitely drink again and again!

Draught.  Pours an amber color with little head.  Basically, this beer's strong points were the consistency in flavor and the lack of off flavors.  However, the flavor that was present was a bit drab and unexciting.  Really not a terrible beer, but not something worthy of constant and consistent comsumption.
Complex fruits, strong alcohol taste (obviously, at 10%).  Good colour.  My first quadrupel, so I'll likely rerate this one later after more tries.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2003 Aroma is sweet, slight molasses, a bit of cherries and a wee bit of alcohol - altogether - pleasing. Bourbon colored appearance with floating sediment.  Flavor is bready with fruity undertones. Also detect some raisins. Improves as it warms - would make a good bellywarmer in the winter. Alcohol is hidden well - although after a 1 pt 9.4 fl oz - you know it was there!

Can someone tell me what exactly is a "quadrupel" and if any other companies make it.  And since when is there a holland trappist.  I have tried all 4 La trappe beers and they all have the exact same aftertaste.  It seems very artifical now and this is making me very suspiciouDOES ANYONE HAVE ANY INFO on THIS BEER
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: Very much like a dark belgium.  Strong but with a minimal dominantion of alcohol.

UPDATED: APR 6, 2008 Poured a medium head that lasted fairly long. There was no lacing on the sides of my mug. It had a sweet aroma to it. It was a fairly smooth drink.

Re-Rate:Medium sized fizzy ivory head that mostly diiminished, floaties, hazy, fizzy carbonation, and a reddish hue. Nose was fruity, alcohol, malt, and some caramel. Nose was sweet, lightly bitter, malt, caramel, fruity, vinuous, and a dry finish. Tingly, warming sensation  mouthfeel. Medium body.Quaffable, sipping beer for sure, nicely balanced, would be a good beer to have on a cold, snowy winters night, would drink this again and again, and worthy of a try.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2003 This brew poured a medium head of light brown bubbles and a cloudy brown body. It has a nice mild malt aroma and a strong yeasty taste of spices, smoke, and some burnt flavor from the alcohol content. I rather liked this brew and would love to have a fresh sample. This brew is definitely a keeper.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2004 Aroma is excellent. Appearance is a murky brown. Flavor is of pears, pineapple, grapes, and oranges. A highly complex and underrated Belgian. The alcohol is very well hidden. Palate is smooth and fruit filled. Quite a shock for $5.99 a 750 ML with a free glass! Overall a hidden gem and one I will certainly try again and again!

UPDATED: JUN 19, 2006 Dark red hue with a light tan head, with large frothy bubbles.  Smells like apples and syrup, sugar, and alcohol.  A little tingly on the tongue at first sip, and then has a strong alcohol bite along with a mellow and soft fruit/malt flavor.  The finish is a little spicy, and I was pleased that it did not taste as syrupy as it smelled.  Overall a really wonderful belgian strong ale, rivaling at times my best experiences with Westvleteren and Rochefort.  I praise the beer gods for allowing me to have this one gem in the beer starved southern plains.

Clear red amber w/ tan head. Pours w/ a nice sizzle but the head dissipates a little quickly. Rich malty nose w/ hints of fruit (oranges, plums) & spice. Smooth, oily feel. Warming beer w/ good malt (caramel, brown sugar) up front, a soft fruitiness in the middle (oranges, blackberries?), and a dry, spicy finish.
UPDATED: MAY 15, 2003 Thin head with good carbonation.Aroma of alcohol and malt. Easier to drink than I thought it would be. Smooth finish that hides the alcohol.

Surprisingly light in color--deep copper, I was expecting darker. Straightforward taste oddly fruity though, with just a hint of sourness.  Sweet finish, which is somewhat balanced by hops.  Fine, but I want more complexity of flavor out of this beer

This beer pours an odd amber with a bunch of stuff floating around.  The aroma is of alcohol and fruits.  The head is small and fairly weak.  I found the taste of this beer to be a lot stronger than anticipated.  This beer is fairly thin and hence not too hard to drink.

Thin head which does not last long but decent carbonation.  Aroma of apricots and alcohol.  Color of rusty amber with ok clarity.  Flavor is excellent with hints of yeast, fruit and alcohol.  Alcohol not overpowering though.  Finish is smooth, slightly bitter and leaves a thin coating on the mouth.  A very pleasant and good tasting brew that hides its alcohol well.  Not as complex as some of the other Trappist beers but highly recommended for people that do not like a real thick beer.
Yeasty spicy apple aroma.Dark bronze appearance with particles.Fruity spiced apple flavors balanced by mild ferbal bitterness.Very smooth with no alcohol detected.Reminds me of Beatrix.

Head is initially average sized, off-white and quickly diminishing. Body is hazy medium orange-brown with dense particles. Aroma is hoppy and includes citrus and  bread with notes of alcohol. Flavor is sweet, moderately acidic, and slightly bitter. Finish is sweet, acidic, and lightly bitter.

Pretty sure this was 2002 vintage.  A bit of fruity alchohol in the nose, but not overpowering in the taste.  Cloudy copper colored.  Not much head.  I almost expected flat since the cork broke off and when I used the wine opener on it there was no pop from pressure in the bottle.  Somewhat sweet taste. Hints of fruit and caramel.  Maybe this was a bit young, as I didn't get any of the bitterness that some others had.  Still, quite good!

Always nice to drink a 10%er that doesn't blow you away with alcohol. Very pleasant strong ale. Very fruity. Amber color with an offwhite head that goes away quickly. Touch of bitterness near the end. Worth a second look.
its been a while since i had this one so i'm going to sing you a song; ahem......

Clear coppoer colored w/ lots of tiny bubbles, it has nice lace to a quickly diminishing head. The flavor is slightly sweet, almost a 'subtle syrup'. The nose has a honey-like smell. The bottle had 2000/2001 on the back. The alcohol was Not noticeable

A slightly hazy amber with a thick but quickly dissapating tan head. A rich thick fruity nose with alcohol and wood tones. Sweet honey with warming alcohol and a mildly hoppy bitter middle. Yeasty esters evident. A smooth warm finish, liquid velvet. A good dessert beer like a tawny port or cream sherry.
UPDATED: DEC 7, 2003 Little head on the pour, and it has an opaque rusty orange color.  The flavor was way too sweet for me, it tasted like smoked maple syrup.  Next time I guess I'll try the triple.
My first beer from La Trappe and I must say it's a good one. The taste is very good.

2000/2001: Pours with little head, eventually dies completely; murky, dark amber in color. Interesting aromas waft from the glass: fruity alcohol, dark fruits, and earthy yeast. Mouthfeel is very soft, slightly watery, and barely carbonated. Malt flavors are cakey and sweet. Alcohol shows up in the finish, but not as much as I expected. Some spices seem to come out more as it warms. Bitterness resides on the tongue after the swallow. Enjoyable, but not too complex.
A nice, well rounded belgian ale, with a fairly mild flavor and nice color. Good, but not exceptional among belgian strongs.
Terrible.  No head, pure alcohol....just not what a trappist beer should be IMHO

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2007 bottled, at hell hunt in tallinn. glad to be able to update my rating as the old one made no sense. much better than i remembered. stewed plum and pear aromas, quite warming, lots of pear and some brown sugar. not subtle but good anyway
Nice amber colour. Sweet and fruity aroma and flavour. Medium-bodied. A very strong brew but not unpleasant. Has a warming effect.

2000/2001 is printed on the back label. This one pours a clear, dark amber color with a medium sized, off-white head. The aroma is malty, very nutty, and slightly alcoholic. Full bodied, smooth, and warming, the flavor is yeasty, fruity, and malty. The finish is long and sweet, with hints of alcohol and fruit. Similar to Avery's The Reverend but much better and more subdued with a more refined flavor. This is an excellent brew from Holland and sure beats the hell out of Heineken. Very nice!

UPDATED: MAR 21, 2003 [Re-rate] Dark amber colour, good head, not really lasting. Caramel and peach in the aroma. The flavour is dominated by sweetness, with strong traces of chocolate, caramel and fruits (banana and peach). The aftertaste is sweet and alcoholic too, with sour traces (citrus) and just a touch of bitterness. If this beer was more balanced it would be delicious. Unfortunately the sweetness dominates the flavour. Good, but it could be much better...

Strong, singular banana aroma. Very sweet; obviously heavy on the candi sugar. The sweetness is offset by a stronger bitter finish than is present in most Belgian-type beers. The 10% ABV was definitely noticeable. The flavor was full and bready, with the majority of the complexity coming from the yeast, rather than fruity flavors or malt flavors.
Aroma of a spiced fruit cake. Delicious dark sugar and allspice comes through, love the lasting sweetness. Noticeable warming effect comes soon after the first sip. Delicious!

This beer rocks!
The aroma is malty and soapy with notes of caramel, butterscotch, candy sugar, cinnamon, brown sugar and fuzzy fruits.
This crystal clear mohogany colored beer has a creamy white head.
Flavors of caramel, candy sugar and a huge blast of fruit cake. 
Full-bodied with a syrupy mouthfeel and lively carbonation. Long, semi-sweet, semi-bitter finish.
The high ABV is well hidden throughout.
Very good quad!

This beer poured a reddish gold color and formed an off white bubbly head that left some trace circular lace. Some carbonation was present. An aroma of butter and slightly of clove. A flavor of butter, clove and malt. Some alcohol is apparent in the finish. A good beer
A good ale.  ABV well hidden. Light bitter flavor.  Spicy, malty toffee flavor.
This is excellent. Imagine a trappist ale from Holland
Big ol' malty aroma.  Color is a slighty cloudy brown.  Abit of roasted malt in the flavor.  Alcohol is not as potent as I would have expected for a quadtrupel. Pretty damn good beer.
Big pear, banana and berry flavors which also show up in the nose.  Sweet, but never overly so.  I think this is a well-balanced high octane abbey beer and would love to repeat the experience.
1/17/03:  bottle.  cloudy, light orange- brown color.  a bit yeasty with some maltiness.  slightly fruity (maybe an orange flavor?) with hints of candy on the tongue.

Brown leather body with a nice, tan head.
Aroma of candy sugar was immediately evident. Maltiness is also nice in the aroma.
Dry, full taste with quite the malt backbone. Hops are a bit more noticeable over the yeast than usual for a Belgian strong. Overall well-balanced.
Very carbonated and slightly rough on the tongue.
Alcohol was not evident.

2002 version. Tasted on 10/02. Malty sweet aroma. Clear reddish caramel color with a tannish white head. The head died after a few minutes but the beer bubbled like champagne the whole time. Very sweet. Malts and candi sugar dominate but there is a faint bitter aftertaste. I didn"t notice the alcohol.
Musty sweet aroma, slightly fruity.  Ruddy brown in color.  Winey and toffee flavor, very soft on the palate.

Sugar sweet nose with cinnamon tones. "too strong to smell" says Shelly. Copper gold color with a lacy head. Yeasty tastes with hints of orange and a spices. Tight bitterness at the end. Medium body with a strong alcohol kick.
yeast and alcohol nose - with nice apple tones. Orange red body, soft carbonation. Apple and oranges are the fruits which leads the flavors. Not very strong.
Sweet, but not as sugary as I expected.  Medium malts, nice dry but lingering finish.  some toffee flavors, hoppier than I thought it would be.

Bottle conditioned. Copper orange, moderate head and condition. This smells like bad hombrew, reedeems itself with a Malty sweet/ coconut flavour and a chewy sweet and alcoholic finish. Dangerously unbalanced.
Very wine like and quite sweet.  Noticable alcohol bite.  Reddish color,  foamy head.  Slightly dry finish.
Nice "winey" Belgian. I can barely tell the diff from their XXX and that "aint bad" either.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2003 Updated: Red-amber color with small foamy head - short retention.  Rich aroma with bubblegum and banana.  Smooth sweet cinnamon and chocolate flavor.  Candyish.  Lingering light phenolic finish.  Alcohol is well masked, body is light and slick on the tongue.  Very nice - beer flavored candy, mmmm.
Eh, not wow spectacular, but still wow, not bad... it has the nice, velvety palate I love, with the fruity, honey-like maltiness you would probably expect. Did look quite good though...
This is even tastier than the tripel!  However it has a slightly sweeter taste, but not overpowering.  A crisp and smooth flavor, very enjoyable.
2000/2001 version. Deep amber color. Stark white head. Warm fruity nose with honeylike overtones. Comparable flavor, sweet and syrupy. Nice lingering flavor. Alcohol was noticably present.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2003 re-rate 2002 version: yeasty aroma. Dark orange/amber color, off-white head, very good lace. Sweet, apple, alcohol very much present, syrupy. Average long lasting finish and sweet. Has become more sweet with less complex flavors. Another example of beers turning towards the masses. 1998 version: 4.1
Hazy amber with tiny bead. Long nose. Smooth velvety full bodied malt taste

Mine had a slight metallic tinge. Vaporous, alcohol, something floral. Same maltiness as an altbier. Bit of earthiness. Nice frothy off-white head and lots of lacing. Opaque caramel-red, like very strong brewed tea. Smooth medium carb with a light oiliness, but mostly a thicker watery base. Sweet, tinge of sour/salt - tangy. Alcohol. Sweet nuttiness to after. No real distinct flavors and a bit watery - maybe I just had a bad bottle? Decent aroma and nice palate, but didnt make a strong impression.
Amber beer with a strong winey aroma.  The flavour is very strong and syrupy with slight liquorice hints.  Overall it does not represent the Belgium beer style well.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2003 Like most people visiting Holland, I cannot remember a hell of a lot between the coffee bars and pick-pockets. La Trappe was, however, a memory I did bring back from the Netherlands. Nice rich flavours and finish. Highly recommended!

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2012 Rating reflects aged sample Bottled 0.3 liter, eight years old (2001 vintage). Still some head after all these years. Amber coloured. Very complex nose, raisins, nuts, fruit, some port notes. Still a pretty sweet flavour, complex, some bitterness, alcohol is well hidden. Previously I never really noticed the effect of aging (after two or five years), but finally after eight years it starts to show. Very nice, and substantially better than fresh.

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2003 1994 edition sampled 2002: poured dirty with lots of floaters and a halo of froth...aroma was old malts and sourdough bread..flavor was very sweet..very old tasting..aging made it taste aged..very bready...to the point of..I dont want anymore of this...
Wow. I am used to danish strong beer. La Trappe gets much more taste, aroma, flavor and all in a strong beer compared to a strong danish beer.
Great stuff.  Ten times better than the dubbel I had before.  I had this on tap, and the head was amazing and full.  Very spicy taste and relaxing slightly hoppy, bitter aftertaste.
