2000/2001 bottling:  pours hazy deep amber with beautiful carbonation and a thick off white head.  complex aroma of yeast, spice, fruit and candy.  more fruit and spice with hints of caramel and chocolate in the flavour.  alcohol shows though more in the finish.  very warming.  very tasty.
A good fruity brew with a nice abv. Has the smell of grapes as well as an acidic bite. This is decent, nothing special.
This is a very good trappist beer. I had one dated 2000/2001.  It poured a deep amber, almost brown, with a huge, rocky, white head.  A very good beer to savor on cold nights.
Sweet and fruity, nothing like I expected it to be.  Unfortunately, the alcohol overrides all the other flavors.  it loses out in cost to enjoyment ratio, expensive stuff.

[2000-2001] Re-rate: I was VERY unfair to this beer in my original rating.  I had a bit of a head cold, so that may have had something to do with it.  This beer has a beautiful head and a dark amber color, with an aroma rich with fruits of all kinds.  It has a very full body with a malty and sweet flavor.  I still taste a lot of fruit and chocolate in this one, but I find it more pleasant this time.  The alcohol content is very well masked.  Original rate: 3 - The aroma of this beer is dominated by fruit (raisins, apples) and alcohol, which is also what is most present in the flavor.  The alcohol presense swells gradually in your mouth, until your tongue receives a burning/cleansing sensation that I expect more from wine than from beer.  There are some subtle notes present, though.  Chocolate being the one I notice the most.  Its pretty good, I guess.

UPDATED: AUG 12, 2011 Rerate: Orange color, slightly hazy. Beautiful thick lasting head. Aroma combined of malts, spices, sweetness, and candy bubblegum. Alcohol is present in taste, but not too overwhelming. Sweet malts, but in a triple style, not double. Bit thin, but definitely highly enjoyable!  

Original rate: 4 Very much alike with the Hertog Jan Grand Prestige. With 10% a really strong ale, nice dark-amber appearance. The hops smell good and the taste is strong, but the alcohol is definitely present.

This an interesting beer, but it seems to be lacking something.  Something?  Im not sure exactly what that something is - Some of the strength is missing.  Obviously high alcohol content and very fruity.

Though still made in the Koningshoeven monastery the actual brewing and distribution is controlled by the Bavaria brewery who specialise in low to medium quality pilsners. The dominant quality of this quadrupel, even with my three year old bottle, is the alcohol - it burns like a spirit or liqueur, and warms the stomach ulcers. The nose is warm rum-soaked raisins and damp wooly blankets.  Initially a shock of liquid brown sugar, this is quickly slashed with a steel knife of acid. Then the melted christmas cake flows around the mouth before the alcohol starts to kick in, growing, blossoming, swelling to a deep, deep burn. The whole subsides to damp cardboard followed by a warm gentle bitterness. There is chocolate, wood smoke, orange peel and celebrated dark Oxford prune juice. Sounds good? Well, its actually fairly clumsy. The journey joggles along like a Rusian taxi driven by a trainee train driver; yet the destination is constantly predictable. The are no surprises here - no rewards. Despite the range of flavours and the high strength this is a rather dull beer.
A moss of molasses saintly dwells on the sweet, fruity malt...Dunking Christmas cookies in stagnant dark rum...Extremely posed and reverend...

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2003 2000/2001 Batch:  Tastes fruity as most strong ales do, at least to me.  Very alcoholic aroma and flavor, however if you look past that you can almost feel an extremely excellent balance of hops and malts melting on the back corner's of your tongue.  It has a thick copper to amber coloring.  The beer is at first thick and syrupy and then the finish is much more thinned out.

Hazy auburn color with a rather sticky tan head. Very bready and perfumey aroma with a noticeable alcohol presence. Immediate harsh bite that is quieted by the strong malt presence. Flavor profile touching a moultitude of dry fruits and alcohol. As the beer approaches room temperature the bite softens and a smoother texture develops. There are many better Belgian strong ales out there with this one falling into the category of not setting my heart on fire.

This is an excellent Belgian! Pours well, nice head although it did not stay as long as I wanted it to, lace remained the whole way through. Incredibly fruity with a strong apple presence. Yeasty and sweet with pleasent finish. Better as it warms as the malt and apple tastes become more prevalent. Strong alcohol presence as my blurred vision can attest to. All in all an excellent Belgian strong ale!
A great beer that has a powerful aroma and palate that doesnt become boring fast like a lot of other beers. Looks great too.

Very smooth and sweet but not cloying at all.  Aroma is wonderful with some ripe fruit (fig, raisin, apple)notes.  Taste is complex and very  well balanced.  La Trappe does a fantastic job of hiding the 10% ABV.  Great ale.
Dark red-brown colour with a lasting head. Sweet, fruity (apple) aroma. Sweet taste, with a little bitter developping near the finish. Well balanced and complex; Lovely.
Light nut brown color with a tall tan slightly rocky head.  Oily, hints of prunes and dark corn syrup. Slight orange hoppiness. Dry and warm finish with a touch of coriander.
Dark brown- almost muddy; Lots of prunes in the nose; Head ranaway quickly. Lots of caramel upfront. Cloyingly sweet with awlnuts. Lots of port hints as well.
Deep dark brown color. Nice long lasting head. Sweet fruity aroma. Taste is sweet (and i mean SWEET) with strong hints of bitterness. Too sweet for my taste!
a little light on flavor,  but a much better beer then  the triple.  the more, the merrier.
Deep amber color, delightful malt taste, with a hint of pineapple in the aroma.  A bit more metallic than most Belgian ales.  Still a solid good taste.
Fruity and very flavorful with nice malts. An excellent Belgian Strong Ale. One of my favorites.

I may have had an old bottle because it had the Koningshoeven logo on the front and not the La Trappe logo. Either way the cork popped very weakly and there was not nearly as much head as I had experienced in the triple. The color was deep brown and had a faint aroma of banana and flowers. THE TASTE WAS STRONG of fermented bananas with a thick sweet mouthfeel. Overall indeed good but I think I liked the triple better.

The best beer I have ever had.  Strong and fruity/floral flavors explode to fill your mouth on first taste following through to the finish which is clean an winsome.  Very happy beer drinking experience.

A very complex brew! Very fruity with a tone of banana and pineapple in the aroma. Slightly parfume flavoured which goes well with the strong alcohol flavour. Fine balance between the beautyful dark nut/orange colour and the expectations for the palate.

Im really digging these trappist brews of late, especially since I have a local distributer finally. This Quad is just as excellent as any imports Ive had lately. Nice grainy aroma, beautiful amber color and just enough lace. The taste is very clean, and nicely malted. I can tell it is rather alchoholic, but it is so well balanced it is not a bit distracting. One thing Ive really grown fond of with these trappist beers is the simplicity and lack of intense flavor. Ive always been such a huge fan of thick stouts and Imperials, its nice to find brews that are excellent without overloading your senses. Like fine dining.
Rich amber/ruby glow.  Strongly alcoholic, but not overpowering.  Well balanced with a slight residual sweetness and a hint of citrus.
Amber color with a head that turns to a fine lace. Malty aroma with some alcohol coming through. Sweet musty flavor. High malt with just a hint of bitterness at the end.

Similar appearance to the tripel, maybe a bit darker orange, familiar specks floating though.  Overwhelming alcohol presence in the nose, touches of sweet malt and some dark fruit.  Very sweet body, alcohol abounds.  Dry.  600th, thanks La Trappe.
This one is far from bad, but not excellent too..
Not a summer-beer. Very fruity and parfumated smell. I like the sophisticated mixture of strong violent alcohol together with the smooth fruit-notes.
Extreme, almost overwhelming, banana and apricot aroma. The flavour is rather strong, sweet and very fruity. I found some toxic notes as well.

UPDATED: FEB 20, 2005 [A 3 year old bottle of this surfaced in my cupboard and I noticed, that it was the first beer I entered on RateBeer 2½ years ago and therefore some 3500 sampled beers ago, so I thougt Id resample it] A clear red beer with sediment floating around and a nice light brown head. The aroma is fruity with notes of yeast and spices I pick up coriander. The flavor is very sweet with the alcohol giving it warmth, it is very fruity with notes of prunes and wood as well as oranges and plums. Not much change in the ratings, but a better description than first time around. Im pretty sure, I wont go thru every beer Ive had to rerate them.

[Original rating: A very delightful fruity smell. A good flavor but a little too much alcolhol taste - La Trappe triple is better. 7/4/8/3/14]
Definitely strong, but the alcohol is well masked. Not quite as well balanced as I would like.  Still above average, but not what youd expect from a Trappist.
unsuccessful attempt of a westy 12.  Had the typical chocolate/fruit/yeast taste, but it didnt come together like it should have....not bad though.

Nice reddish brown.  Not a lot of carbonation, compared to the great Belgians.  Aroma is qquite nice, with some dry fruit notes.  The first sip was sort of thin.  Not the big body I expected.  It fills out a little as you drink it, with a nice full aftertaste and mouthfeel in the finish.  The flavour is good with some more fruit like plum or raisin.  I found the alcohol to be quite noticeable.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2006 Awesome beer! Dark reddish brown. Very carbonated. Tastes flowery and spicy like any trappist ale should. Highly recommended. Even my girlfriend loves this beer! ***Re-rate: The previous rating was based on the older version of the beer. The "Koeningshoeven" version is excellent as well but lacks some of the alcohol and spice the previous version had and adds more sweetness. Still a great and HIGHLY recommended beer but not as mighty as it once was.

***Re-rate 750mL bottle - corked and caged. Numbering on the back is 13:13K24.5. Not sure what that means though. This is the first time this beer has been back in the Tidewater area in years. I was quite shocked to see it actually. Dark coppery brown with a small dense foamy white head. Nose is very malty and fruit laden. Pleasant spicy notes, flowers, candyish aromas and light bitterness. Taste is malty and sweet with caramel and candied fruit notes, light spices, Belgian yeasts, flowers, and light alcohol. Mouthfeel is medium-full with lots of carbonation tingling the palate. Finishes with more sweet malts, candied fruits, Belgian yeast, spices and light alcohol notes. As I noted before, this isnt as "grand" as I remember it being, say, 10 years ago, but it is still quite good.
dissapointing overall, must have been stale (was in one of those gift cans with the other 3)
big body, low carbs and easily drank.  alcohol is very well hidden.
makes my eyes droop, lacks the carbonation that turns me off to most belgian styles, sweet and strong like a russian mail order bride

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2004 I am fully convinced that someone put carrot juice in my bottle instead of beer. . . i will have to try this again, must be an acquired taste.
Rerate. Finally gave it a second chance.  Much better appreciation for it this time around.  Aroma is actually quite pleasant, full of bosch pears.  Not sweet, just crisp pear aroma mixed in with some slight alcohol notes.
Flavor has some pear flavor, but also sweetens much towards the middle offering some raisin flavor.  The alcohol is high, but quite tasty and this beer is not astringent.  I still dont think this has quite the complexity of better trappist ales, and Im not sure if Im in to the acidity level in this, that is quite high.  Decent carbonation level and less than average sediment.

UPDATED: JUL 8, 2011 2011-01-07, vintage 2000/2001, 10 years old, bb 2004-09, batch 14:38K03I1, 7-5-8-3-16=39Brown color; medium sized head. The aroma is mild, but also perfumy and fruity, with caramel. It has a good caramel flavor and malt, with decent residual sweetness, well balanced by some bitterness and a light, sweet nutty touch. Smooth and elegant vintage, very enjoyable.2009-06-17, draught at Monks Café - Wallingatan, Stockholm, 7-4-7-3-13=34Bright amber color, creamy head, nice lace. Malty aroma, lightly fruity (apples, and this is not a good sign). Medium body, sweetish caramel flavor. The bitterness is surpassed by the alcohol warmth; the final is a bit fruity too. Boozey.2002-07-07, bottle, vintage 2000-2001, 7-4-7-3-14=35Amber-brown colour, misty. Nice malt aroma in the beginning, with porto notes; but later the aroma becomes poorer. Strong body, sweet and malty; the alcohol is quite hidden, but the mouth is too sweet; also the palate is not enough balanced with bitterness, and the hop aroma is quite poor. Getting warmer, it develops a deeper caramel character, evidentiating mostly in the palate. Pleasant, but nothing to be compared with a real trappist ale.
Good beer all around.  The Quadrupels get you hammered to say the least. Taste is good but nothing super unique or complicated.

UPDATED: FEB 9, 2004 Sweet spicy aroma, quite smooth, syrrupy texture, spice, orange peel, apple, peach, and perhaps coriander or ginger, but a bit one dimentionally sticky, its ok though, warming, not bad, but nothing to write home about.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2003 2/7/03:  Hazy amber body with minimal head.  The aroma is sweet rock candy, slightly fruity, almost like a Jolly Rancher.  Taste is cloyingly sweet, orange/berry fruity, and malty smooth.  Finishes with a slight alcohol burn.  The overwhelming sweetness just didn't do it for me. 

7/3/02:  Red-brown body, with nice head.  Sweet fruity aroma.  Malty sweet, complex with strong alcohol presence.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2003 Aroma is very malty, with caramel/toffee and with a few whiffs of black olive. This is considerably different on tap than bottled.  Flavor is very fruity/melony and malty.  Excellent.
Lots of alcohol present in the taste.  Plums are present.  A tad malty.

Soapy head lasts quite awhile.  As soon as I poured from the bottle I could smell the aroma.  First thing that hit me was green apples.  Citric aroma.  Light amber color.  Sweet, but finishes with a little spice.  Fruity taste on the tongue.  Smooth on the palate, and I found the alcohol to be well masked; however, it is still present.

Nice aroma of heavy fruits (banana) and maybe some citrus. Sweet, alcoholic, fruity and pretty complex flavour with a mildly bitter finish. Complaint: can be too overwhelming due to the high alcohol content and maybe a bit acidic.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2003 Re-Rate 2/5/03:  Bottle.  A copper color with a quickly laced off-white head.  The nose has dark fruit, brandy, and a rich malt.  The flavors burst with a spicey, peppery, fruit, and ginger push to compliment the malts.    Original Rating: Tap.  A nice amber bronze appearance.  Strong alcohol presence but also a smooth finish.

Re-Rate 06/12/02: This bottle is the 2000 vintage, been rest in my Cellar for the last year and a half.
Clear cherry red, creamy beige head, tons of lace. Nose is malt, plummish, earthy, sweet. Front is sweet, the top medium to full, the finish is hop spicy, acidic, dry, robust, and quite pleasant. Age has improved a bit, but I still like the double and triple better.
Raisins. And Molasses cookies. Soaked in Rum. Thats what I get out of this beer. The beer was a little flat, especially for a trappist beer. Good beer, but Ive better beers.
Different. Not hot in flavor with a 10% abv. Spicy apricot rich malts. Color a lot lighter than I expected
This just doesnt stand up to the La Trappe Tripel. The Quad is too medicinal/spicy, and the malt flavors arent as sweet.  The 10% alcohol IS well hidden.

The sampled bottle was from 1992. Redorange beer with a fruity nose. Lots of blueberries and raspberries. It´s huge and just keeps going, like a mix of The Green Giant and the Duracellbunny. The flavor is sweet with toffee and marsmallowtones.Fruity with a peppery tone and some sharpness. A true world class beer that definitely gets better by the years.

Sampling of the 1992 version in 2002: Dark amber. Aroma of berries and malt. Very malty, rich, bready, big toffee flavour. It has matured and developed better wonderfully, gone is the syrupiness, and you cant notice the alcohol. Worth waiting for...

An interesting beer.  Cloudy peach color with a medium sized head and a big spicy and yeasty nose.  Lots of malts with apricot and light fruit flavors.  Spicy with a bit of a dry finish.  Interesting and quite enjoyable.

Good but cant stand with the great trappist breweries. Smell molasses but only faintly. A very warming beer but tastes better when it is still cold. Gets an almost stale aftertaste at room temperature.
Smells of mild molasses. Hazy peach colour, almost no head. Strong alcohol, plums, and sherry. Warming finish, (at 10%, I guess) Complex. Fantastic!
What is a quadruppel?  Easy to drink even at its high alc content.  Lacking in a special something...
Tastes just like the Trippel.  You would not know its quadruppel, altho shouldnt a quad be 4%?

UPDATED: DEC 13, 2016 Re-rate from 0.75 bottle 25 Anniversary edition. 
Nutty, dark caramel, sugar, iodine aroma, light fruity estery notes. Hazy red amber, offwhite cream.Medium full body, mellow sparkly mouthfeel. Dry mineral, Weizenbock-like fruity notes, some complexity in spices, leathery/wooden finish. Preserved fruits (berries, prunes) retronasal, almond in the burps. Initially heavy and a bit rough, actually comes together nicely as it warms in its glas without losing drinkability. Overall a bit too heavy for my taste, but well put together and enjoyable nonetheless.  

old rating: 7 3 7 4 13
Ligth brown. Nicely balanced aroma and taste. Only a hint of alcohol in the nose. Quite easily drinkable the strength considerd.

Delightful floral aroma.
Tastes good.  Sweet with 
a slightly bitter, dry finish.
No hint of the high alcohol
content.  Very good.

Sweet, malty aroma and a slightly cloudy amber color are the first things I noticed about this beer.  That, and the giant head that tried to overflow my glass.  It disappeared quickly, though, but I cant say the same for the taste.  Its sweet, pungent, and bitter all at the same time.  Its not too carbonated, there isnt anything to detract from the not-so-complex mixture of tastes.  The sweetness is cloying at times, sticky on the lips as well, and there isnt much middle to the one---just a caramely sweetness and then the pungent alcohol finish.  To summarize, its good but a bit off balance due to the sweetness and alcohol.  It is hard to drink more than a few sips of this one without pausing for a long while.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2014 malty aroma, a sweet and fruity taste with alcohol. Lacking in complexity, compared to the Belgian Trappist ales, but certainly very nice to drink
Re-rate from tap: Peacharoma. Malty flavor with cherry and peach. Alcohol clearly present. Much fruitier as the bottled version. 
Re-rate from tap, 2004 version, tasted in december 2009: Large snifter for only  2,20 in Café Morshuis Albergen. Youre too kind Eduard. Malt, sherry, cherry brandy in the flavor. Some dust and tartness reveal the age of this brew. Almost full bodied, thick and sticky on the tongue. The aroma could be a bit more outspoken, but this is a very tasty brew.

Bottle, labeled as La Trappe Quadrupel 2008, bought in 2013, tasted in march 2014. Amber color. Malt, caramel and butter in the mellow aroma. Malty sweet, slightly alcoholic flavor with toffee, butter and upcoming porto and sherry flavors. Bubblegum, Well controlled oxidation. This beer really matures well.

I have to say that I was a bit let down by this beer.  I cant claim to be an expert on trappist ales, but after trying all three Chimays I had my hopes set high.  Upon pouring, I saw a nice color and head, which was complimented by a hoppy smell with hints of pear and peach.  But the flavor turned out pretty unbalanced - not badly so, but something about it made it rather difficult to drink.  It seemed like the alcohol was too much for the flavor.

UPDATED: MAY 27, 2006 750ml bottle. Head is mostly lasting. Body is hazy medium amber. Aroma is lightly malty (bread), lightly yeasty (mold), with a strong note of alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is moderately sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic.  As I was rating this, I thought maybe I was being too harsh, but in the end I decided that my gut feeling, which was that I wanted absolutely nothing to do with this beer based on the boozy, lacking aroma and the sweet, burning mouth experience. Very unpleasant.
Alcoholic warmth definitely shows through rather heavy for a 9% beer.

More like a wine, perhaps because it didnt seem very cabonated. Very sweet
                     smell, and innitially a very sweet flavor, quickly followed by a sour aftertaste. Maybe
                     this is the way a trappist Ale is suposed to taste? A first experience for me.
                     Definately an ale Id like to try again.
UPDATED: AUG 1, 2007 Fruity nose, dark color, slight bitter aftertaste.  Right up there with Rochefort and Chimay.
My firtst belgian style ale, and I dare say it wont be my last. very complex, with a wonderful flavor.
Very good trappistenbier
This was my first intro to a Trappist Ale and I was astounded at its flavor! Wow.

Powerfully vinous nose. Pours a nice light amber color, with a medium head. Sweet flavor, with strong hints of wine and nuttiness. Alcohol is not well masked, and it burns a bit going down. Finishes with a bit too much bitterness.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2005 re-rate:  I just enjoyed this with a complex and dark Havana Partagas Churchill deluxe after dinner.  The acidic and sweet level of this beer paired perfectly with this cigar.  11.2 oz/ "00/"01 bottling:  This is one complex ale.  Much better out of the small bottle, for some unusual reason??  This has aged into a wonderful brew and should do so for a good five more years.  Pours an off tan very sticky head with great retemtion.  ARoma of plastic?, prunes and other dark fruits.  Copper color like an American barleywine, especially Foghorn.  taste is very rich and sweet, similar to Brown Shugga by Lagunitas.  Rum, candied fruits and molasses come to mind in this mind boggling ale.  This is a beer which will receive many mixed reviews because it comes in so many forums. (crocks, corked and small bottles)  If found in good condition, you won"t be disappointed.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: 2000/01 bottling.  Notes of molasses and figs among other sweet things in the subtle nose; body is cognac-like, in color and texture (no head to speak of); flavor very rich and malty, sweet but with a hint of bitterness, chocolatey-plummy-bready.  I didnt think it overly yeasty, as some have complained; very close to some American barley wines.  Whatever you want to call this complex and intriguing beer, its a great one.

Magnificent. Well worth the price, this is full and strong (although the alcohol is a minor taste component) and almost wine-like (think a good tawny port). A lady friend of mine who ordinarily cant stand ales loves this stuff.
Smooth thick caramel that refuses to dry out with age like many other trappist brews.  A touch of sherry and plum add to the complex character of this deceptivly massive beauty.
This is a very likable beer - almost too easy to drink.  I want to savor it, but I want to gulp it down.  What a dilemna!
Overall a great beer. Heavy Plum scent, prevalent alcohol/yeast finish. Watery mouthfeel is a little disappointing, but on a cool/cold night this is a perfect selection!
Very unimpressive. Flavors were very subdued and almost watery. Somewhat spicy/fruity aroma. This beer reminded me of drinking apple juice when i was a kid... watered down apple juice.
Got this in a Christmas gift box and therefore I thought it was rubbish - until I showed it to Ceasar: he went out of his mind! Anyway, it´s nice stuff and definitely NOT rubbish.

Compared to its dubbel cousin this was slightly harsh, the alcohol was more prevalant as was a yeasty feel in the finish. While this does have the same general flavors as the dubbel, and it still is very good, it wasnt as enjoyable.

Not quite as refined and easy as the dubbel.  Same primary flavors, including plum and oak, and almost equally as malty.  However, yeast is too strong a characteristic, and detracted slightly from my enjoyment. Bolder alcohol character as well, although not to the point that it negatively impacts the flavor or aroma, which again is chocolate, brown sugar, and plum.  The experience is similar to Westvleteren 8.

Wow. Way better than their dubbel or blonde. Deep ruby color. Nice thick head that leaves Belgian lace all over your glass. Ripe fruit (plum?) aromas and flavor. Maybe a bit too malty and sweet but thats nitpicking. Way too drinkable for 10%
Incredibly smooth, very fruiy malt, but flavor becomes a bit bland as it warms... alcohol content covered very well.
verty nice - how come more breweries dont make quads?
Ages well. The newer the quad, the sweeter it is. I personally dont like the Quad fresh off the shelf. THe trick then is to store it for awhile or purchase older versions in the Clay bottles.
Like butter. Its not a strong taste for a beer that probably is very strong. Very nice flavor, very nice beer. A Gulden Draak was ordered with this and this one blows that out of the water.
I liked this stuff.  Interesting orangey hue, and slightly sour fruitiness mixed with the hop and alcoholic tastes.  Worth a try, to be sure.

I had Westvleteren 12, Rochefort 10, and this on the same night, and this one trails the other two by quite a ways. Of course, most beers trail those mega-ales.  This one is sweet and smooth, but not too complex for its high strength.  Not bad, but nothing to write home about.
2000/2001 bottling. Far too fruity, in an unpalatable manner. Yeast hulks in the background just in case you get past the tutti-fruitiness.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2005 2 y.o. - red-brown colour, fine head and a correct lacing, apple, malt and licorice in the nose, sweeties-like, medium to full-bodied, oily with a tart bitterness, the finish is dry and malty with more notes of fruity bubblegum
I like the Tripel better. Sweet. It is amazingly smooth to have a 10% alcohol content.
sweet, a bit overpowering.  Definetely warms the chest.

Not too bad.  I like the dubbel and tripel better.  This one is just a bit too sweet.  Im impressed, like others, that at 10% ABV its remarkably smooth and has little to no alcohol presence in the flavor.
Pretty good, and surprisingly mellow for 10% abv.
Soft, smooth body leading to a malty finish
